taxonomicNotes: Lepus castroviejoi was described relatively recently, being separated from L. granatensis, a split supported by genetic evidence. While the range of L. castroviejoi partially overlaps that of L. granatensis and L. europaeus on the Iberian Peninsula, no hybridization has been detected with these forms. Recent studies have shown that instead, based on ecological, molecular and morphological characteristics, it is most closely related to L. corsicanus; some believe these two are conspecific (Alves et al. 2008, Acevedo et al. 2014, Ballesteros 2018). Additionally, two different occurrences of introgression of mtDNA from L. timidus into L. castroviejoi have been documented – indicating that these two forms have come into contact and hybridized two different times in the past, most recently during the last deglaciation (Melo-Ferreira et al. 2005, 2012; Ballesteros 2018). No subspecies or geographic variation in L. castroviejoi have been described (Flux and Angermann 1990, Hoffmann and Smith 2005, Ballesteros 2018).
Identified as a new species by genetic analyses, this species combines morphological features of both P. austriacus and P. auritus.
The validity of this species needs to be confirmed (Wilson and Reeder 2005, G. Amori pers. comm. 2006).

At present there are five species of this genus recognized from the Canary Islands. There are no species recognized from Fuerteventura, La Gomera, El Hierro, however on each island at least one undescribed species exists.

With the exception of P. raricostata, which is easily recognizable, the described species are very similar, and by contrast the shells of the undescribed species are quite distinct. In addition on each island the animal has a different colour.

The taxonomy for these species is confused and the group is in urgent need of a major revision, however, the ability to undertake such a revision is severely limited by a lack of living material. A further problem is that the shell is thick and is able to withstand erosion, hence dead shells may represent a long time period, even centuries under certain conditions.

Ophrys melitensis is treated by some as one morphologically and phenologically highly variable entity of Ophrys × flavicans. The total range of Ophrys × flavicans extends from Cataluna across the Balearic Islands, southern France and mainland Italy to Dalmatia, Sicily and Malta (Pedersen and Faurholdt 2007).

The type locality is off Ireland (51°54'N, 11°57'W) in the northeast Atlantic. Because there are so many undescribed species in this genus, the distribution of Helicocranchia pfefferi outside the northeast Atlantic is very uncertain. It is likely that the species referred to around Hawaii as H. pfefferi is in fact a different (and probably undescribed) species (Young and Mangold 2014).

This is the type species of the genus. The type locality is off Messina, Italy. The identity of C. sicula remains uncertain as two similar species appear to be present in the Mediterranean Sea and it is not clear to which the original description pertains (Young and Vecchione 2006).  Hence, it is not possible to determine the true distribution of C. sicula and further taxonomic work is urgently required.

Gleadall (2004) erected Muusoctopus for Benthoctopus januarii (Hoyle 1885) on the grounds that Benthoctopus was no longer valid because the type species has been recognised as a Bathypolypus. We have placed all species previously assigned to Benthoctopus in Muusoctopus since preliminary genetic data provide no evidence that this group is polyphyletic (as has been previously suggested).

There are taxonomic issues surrounding this species. Only the holotype can be confirmed as this species. It is possibly a junior synonym of Muusoctopus normani (Massy 1907) but there is considerable distance between the known distributions (separated by deep water). Furthermore, although it shares the small suckers and VV funnel organ, its gill lamellae counts are marginally outside those of M. normani.  It is likely a valid but poorly known species.

This species forms part of the Mastigoteuthis glaukopsis species group. It is currently composed of three species: Mastigoteuthis atlantica, in the Atlantic Ocean; M. famelica, in the Pacific Ocean; and M. glaukopis in the Indian Ocean. There is little difference in the morphology of M. glaukopis and M. atlantica and the two species may be synonymous (Vecchione and Young 2007).

This species, originally described as Cirroteuthis umbellata Fischer, 1883, is the type species for Grimpoteuthis. It is known only from the type specimen, which is in extremely poor condition (Collins 2003, Collins and Villanueva 2006). Because G. umbellata remains poorly described, the ‘true’ form of Grimpoteuthis remains unknown. New collections from the type locality (between Fayal and San Miguel in the Azores at 37°55'N, 20°22'W and in 2,235 m of water) are required to solve the taxonomic issues. This species may be the senior synonym of G. discoveryi or G. wuelkeri (Collins 2003).

According to Bank (2013), accepted subspecies are:
Delima (Delima) blanda blanda (Rossmassler, 1836)
Delima (Delima) blanda conspurcata (Rossmassler, 1836)
Delima (Delima) blanda fulcrata (Rossmassler, 1836)
Delima (Delima) blanda schmidti H. Nordsieck, 1993
Delima (Delima) blanda tichobates (L. Pfeiffer, 1868)

There is a large range of synonyms to the species.
Confirmation of the taxonomic status of this species with respect to other Zonites is required.

Charpentieria spezialensis belongs to the group 1a nobilis-calcarae as listed by Nordsieck (2002:34). As Nordsieck stated, the species has been probably already collected in the same locality and Erhmann recognised it as a new species and named it Delima (Priodelima) specialensis but never described it.

The species on the Canary Islands were placed into the genus "Ferussacia" based on shell characters, however the generic placement was tentative, pending fuller research into the generic status. There are big differences between the introduced species Ferussacia folliculusand the recent extant species represented there, and in addition, fossil records of representatives of the genus Amphorella were found in Gran Canaria (Hutterer and Groh 2014). 

The current thinking is that these species are likely to come from an endemic Canarian genus related to the Madeiran Ferussaciids and this is under investigation.

Furthermore there are sometimes strongly ribbed specimens of "Ferussacia" valida on Fuerteventura which makes it probable that this species is placed within the genus "Sculptiferussacia", which is probably closed associated to the other Canarian species.

The Canarian "Ferussacia"species are self-fertilising breeders, so in fact all of them are clones and the species limits are hard to define, given that they are quite variable in the shell shape. Additionally the shell has only a few distinguishable characters. Revisions in the species status await further research, preferably by genetic methodology.

As listed in Bank (2013) and Nordiseck (2013) Charpentieria calcarae has three distinct subspecies: C. calcarae calcarae, C. calcarae belliemii (Brandt, 1961) and C. calcarae orlandoi (Liberto et al. 2016). These taxa have been described only upon shell taxonomical characters, thus their real status and validity should be further investigated with an advanced anatomical/molecular approach.

According Welter-Schultes (2012) the name Bulgarica fritillaria (Frivaldsky, 1835) covered many closely-related forms, currently recognised as separate species; Bulgarica fraudigera, B. hiltrudae, B. varnensis, B. urbanskii, B. pseudofraudigera. From all those taxon names, “fritillaria” is the oldest, but also the one with the most variable characters that are often close to, or even overlap the other forms of the group. Also the species “fritillaria” has the most unclear and dispersed distribution. For example Wohlberedt (1911), Hesse (1916), and Urbanski (1977) published this species for Varna district on the Black Sea coast, but according to recent data only B. varnensis could be found in that region.

Urbanski (1960, 1964), and Nordsieck (1973) attributed this species to the western Rhodopes Mts., Bachkovsky Monastery, Chepelarska River valley (= Chaja), but in the valley of Chepelarska River it occurs only as different variations of Bulgarica fraudigera. The situation is similar with the reports for Trakija lowland, Plovdiv, Maritsa River valley (Hesse 1916, Körnig 1983). Also according Nordsieck (1973) the species occurs in the Stara Planina Mts., Sliven, but most probably it is just forms of B. urbanskii. Probably, typical “fritillaria” occurs in the foothills of Stara Planina Mountains, and some regions of Sredna Gora Mountains – areas of Stara Zagora, Kazankuk, Karlovo (Georgiev and Georgiev 2002, unpublished information). Welter-Schultes (2012) found minor differences between all taxa in the “varnensis-fritillaria” complex, and suggested more detailed studies on this group of species.
This species was distinguished from Arion fuscus by Falkner et al. (2002). This species is taxonomically doubtful.

Limax canapicianus has been described by Pollonera (1885). Nevertheless this species has not been recently revised and its identity is doubtful. It is present in both Manganelli et al. (1995) and Bank  (2013) checklists.
There is some ongoing debate as to whether to regard this species as valid, or as part of a species complex (Kornilios et al. 2009).

Nordsieck (2006) lumped bosnica and the at that time undescribed montenegrina under marcki, widening its range. But in 2007, Nordsieck separated the taxa leaving D. marcki restricted S-Velebit and Plješevica.

According to Welter-Schultes (2012) this taxon is a synonym of Carpathica calophana (Westerlund, 1881) because of the following reasons: (1) only very few specimens have been found, (2) obviously there is some variation in the expression of the membrane at the lower side of the shell, and it is possible that the denticles (characteristic for C. denticulata) are not a unique specific character, (3) the anatomy of C. calophana seems to be quite variable, and C. denticulata seems to fit in this complex, (4) it is also necessary to know more about the life cycle of these animals to determine which of the specimens studied by Grossu (1983) were fully adult.
Bank (2017) followed Riedel's monograph and maintained as a valid species.
According to Nordsieck (2016: Checklist of recent Clausiliidae) vrondamassa is assigned to the genus Isabellaria and is a subspecies of Isabellaria butoti.
Oxychilus fuscosus is currently assigned to the subgenus Oxychilus, but more taxonomical research is needed to assess its systematic position within the family Oxychilidae.

According to Fehér et al. (2013) Alopia livida has the following subspecies: A. livida bipalatalis (M. Kimakowicz, 1883), A. livida deaniana Cooke, 1922, A. livida julii A.J. Wagner, 1914, and A. livida livida (Menke, 1828).

Vitrea trolli has been described upon shell features only (Wagner, 1922). Its shell slightly resembles that of V. subrimata with differences found in growth of whorls and mouth shape. Its validity, as with many other Vitrea species, must be verified yet with further taxonomic studies involving anatomical and molecular investigations.
A. narentena is considered a synonym of A. exarata subsp. neumensis (Fehér 2003).
According to Fehér et al. (2013) Alopia nixa fussi (M. Kimakowicz, 1894) is a subspecies of Alopia nixa.
This species might be only a local form of Vitrea illyrica.
No anatomical data appears in literature, thus its actual genus assignation is based exclusively upon shell features.
Bank (2013) lists three subspecies: Herilla pavlovici pavlovici (A.J. Wagner, 1914), Herilla pavlovici hiltrudae H. Nordsieck, 1971, and Herilla pavlovici trescavicensis (A.J. Wagner, 1914).
According to Fehér et al. (2013) Alopia plumbea bellicosa (M. Kimakowicz, 1894) is a subspecies of Alopia plumbea.

Bank (2013) lists three subspecies: Isabellaria isabellina isabellina (L. Pfeiffer, 1842), Isabellaria isabellina osculans (E. von Martens, 1876), and Isabellaria isabellina thebana (E. von Martens, 1876).

This species group is in state of revision and the distribution information that has been published is conflicting. There will be new species descriptions from some islands. This conservation review is based on unpublished information from A. Frias Martins (pers. comm. 2016) and is based on anatomical data supporting identifications for the distribution data.

Coilostele acus (L. Pfeiffer, 1854) was described from Seville and has never been found again. The shell is only known by an image published by Kuster and Pfeiffer (1845-1855; Taf. Fig. 69: 12-14). The type material is not available for study. Later, Bourguignat (1880) described seven new species of Coilostele from Seville, from river debris.

Boettger (1905) and later Audibert (2010), also consider the species described by Bourguignat to belong to the same taxon as C. acus, although they state that some of the species have some features that distinguish them from the rest. Neubert in Audibert (2010) also indicates that they correspond to the same taxon, C. acus. The syntypes of the seven species of Coilostele described by Bourguignat are deposited at the Muséum d'Histoire Naturelle in Geneva (Switzerland).

Subulona anarum (Altimiras and Bech 2000), described from a population found in Badajoz (Spain), most probably can be considered a junior synonym of C. acus. The specimens of this population are currently reviewed by Martínez-Ortí, Prieto and Uribe (in press). The type material of S. anorum is deposited in the Museu de Ciències Naturals of Barcelona.
The date of description of this species is sometimes cited as 1972, however Brandt published the species description in 1962 (Brandt 1962).

Muticaria neuteboomi was described by Beckmann (1990) from a single locality: Cava d'Ispica (Ragusa, Sicily). Giusti et al. (1995) at first considered M. neuteboomi as a local morph of the widespread M. syracusana. A few years later, M. neuteboomi was recognized as a valid species and since then this statement has not been denied (Nordsieck 1997). In 2010 Colomba et al. by means of molecular taxonomy proved the validity of the taxon and its independence from the widespread M. syracusana. In the same paper, they also assumed that M. neuteboomi has a wider distribution than previously thought. They stated that M. syracusana is distributed along the coast at lower altitudes while M. neuteboomi is commonly found inland within a broader area than the previous one and at higher altitudes, although they did not provide any map or locality list.

According to Bank (2013), accepted subspecies are:

Delima (Delima) albocincta albocincta (L. Pfeiffer, 1841)
Delima (Delima) albocincta rufa (Kuster, 1876)
Delima (Delima) albocincta sororia (A. Schmidt, 1868)

There is a high demand for a revision of the genus Gibbulinella. It is yet not clear if all island subpopulations are conspecific, and hence genetic and anatomic studies are necessary. Alone on La Palma there are three different species known to exist, one of them under description.

According to Bank (2013), accepted subspecies are:
Medora stenostoma klemmi H. Nordsieck, 1970
Medora stenostoma stenostoma (Rossmassler, 1839)
The taxonomic authority of this species is frequently given, incorrectly, as A. Villa & J.B. Villa (R. Bank pers. comm. March 2022).
The genus Vermetum was moved from Gastrodontidae to Pristilomatidae (Holyoak et al. 2014).
This species is considered synonymous with Ichoatia inchoata by Uit de Weerd et al. (2009), but Welter-Schultes (2012) regards it as a separate species in the genus Sericata.
Welter-Schultes (2013) commented that this species was initially described as a subspecies of Bulgarica vetusta, and could belong to that species.

Following Nordsieck (2013), for Charpentieria septemplicata two subspecies are currently considered as valid: C. septemplicata septmeplicata Philippi, 1836, and C. septemplicata alcamosensis Brandt, 1961. One subspecies has been recently described by Beckmann (2004): C. septemplicata hemmeni but this is considered as a junior synonym of. C. septemplicata alcamoensis by Nordsieck (2013) by virtue of the similar shell features. Absolutely further taxonomical research is needed to clarify its real status and distribution.
Charpentieria grohmanniana belongs to group 2 of the Charpentieria (Siciliaria) as stated by Nordsieck (2002).

Oxychilus uziellii is a medium-sized species with a subdiscoidal shell, flat below, yellowish with about 5 1/2 6 1/4 regularly growing whorls. Anatomically it is characterized by the peculiarly development of the penial flagellum, the reduced proximal penis and the internal ornamentation of the flagellum and proximal penis. The species is well distinguishable from all other species from Tuscany and the Emilian Apennines (Manganelli and Giusti 2000).
Both Welter-Schultes (2012) and Nordsieck (2016) consider this species as belonging to the genus Isabellaria.

Cecilioides actoniana has been described upon shell features only and no anatomical data is currently known. Further taxonomical researches are needed to establish its validity and its relationships with other Sicilian Cecilioides species, thus its current status is uncertain.

Falkner et al. (2002; see also Falkner et al. 1999, Falkner and Falkner 2002) and Nitz et al. (2010) started to revise the Limax complex from Corsica, with redefinitions of previously valid species and recognition of at least three new species still to be described. The species here assessed does not correspond to Limax wolterstorffi s.st. but to the wolterstorffi-complex as defined by Nitz et al. (2010).

This is an extremely variable species as the shell morphology, and the taxonomic and nomenclatural stories of L. candidescens are quite complicated, with many names introduced by past authors to describe its great polymorphism. While some authors did not give any credit to subspecific differentiation (Giusti 1971, Manganelli et al. 1995), recently Nordsieck (2011) revised the genus, presenting a distribution map and assessing the (sub)specific names. He also introduced new names at subspecific rank, thus elongating the already long list of subspecies for this species.
The relation of this species to Tandonia cavicola requires confirmation.
Cecilioides stephaniana has been described upon shell features only, within a group that shows high shell variability. Its real status and validity must be assessed by further taxonomic research.

Although many nominal species were described in the 19th century, the radiation of Oxychilusin Corsica was rediscovered only recently by Falkner et al. (2002), who revalidated nominal species and inferred the presence of five new species (one of them has been described since) within three different lineages (subgenera Oxychilus, Ortizius and "Subg.?", still unnamed). The rarity of the native Oxychilus species in Corsica, and the fact that most species are conchologically very close and can only be differentiated by anatomy, explain how hard it is to gather valuable data on distribution, and that further prospections are required to provide data on taxonomy, distribution and ecology of these proposed species.
The genus Schistophallus is sometimes placed as the subgenus of Oxychilus.

The specific status of this taxon is doubtful as it is conchologically intermediate between F. lanzarotensis and F. attenuata (with which it might be found together) and the type series is very variable too.

There are big differences between the introduced species Ferussacia folliculusand the recent extant species represented there, and in addition, fossil records of representatives of the genus Amphorella were found in Gran Canaria (Hutterer and Groh 2014). 

The current thinking is that these species are likely to come from an endemic Canarian genus related to the Madeiran Ferussaciids and this is under investigation.
Furthermore there are sometimes strongly ribbed specimens of "Ferussacia" valida on Fuerteventura which makes it probable that this species is placed within the genus "Sculptiferussacia", which is probably closed associated to the other Canarian species.

Additionally the shell has only a few distinguishable characters. Revisions in the species status await further research, preferably by genetic methodology.
According to Welter-Schultes (2012) this taxon is a synonym of Daudebardia langi.

The species on the Canary Islands were placed into the genus "Ferussacia" based on shell characters, however the generic placement was tentative, pending fuller research into the generic status. There are big differences between the introduced species Ferussacia folliculus and the recent extant species represented there, and in addition, fossil records of representatives of the genus Amphorella were found in Gran Canaria (Hutterer and Groh 2014).

Furthermore there are sometimes strongly ribbed specimens of "Ferussacia" valida on Fuerteventura which makes it probable that this species is placed within the genus "Sculptiferussacia", which is probably closed associated to the other Canarian species.

Additionally the shell has only a few distinguishable characters. Revisions in the species status await further research, preferably by genetic methodology.
Bank (2013) lists three subspecies: Isabellaria perplana perplana (O. Boettger, 1877), Isabellaria perplana josephinae (O. Boettger, 1880), and Isabellaria perplana triodos H. Nordsieck, 1974.

According to Fehér and Szekeres (2016) its subspecies are:

Montenegrina helvola magna Fehér & Szekeres, 2006
Montenegrina helvola carinata Erőss & Szekeres, 1999
Montenegrina helvola ornata Erőss & Szekeres, 1999
Montenegrina helvola pageti Brandt, 1962.

Although many nominal species were described in the 19th century, the radiation of Oxychilusin Corsica was rediscovered only recently by Falkner et al. (2002), who revalidated nominal species and inferred the presence of five new species (one of them has been described since) within three different lineages (subgenera Oxychilus, Ortizius and "Subg.?", still unnamed). The rarity of the native Oxychilus species in Corsica, and the fact that most species are conchologically very close and can only be differentiated by anatomy, explain how hard it is to gather valuable data on distribution, and that further prospections are required to provide data on taxonomy, distribution and ecology of these proposed species.
Riedel (1992) discusses that this species might be conspecific with Vitrea argolica Riedel, 1962 and some other taxa described from Greece.

The species on the Canary Islands were placed into the genus "Ferussacia" based on shell characters, however the generic placement was tentative, pending fuller research into the generic status. There are big differences between the introduced species Ferussacia folliculusand the recent extant species represented there, and in addition, fossil records of representatives of the genus Amphorella were found in Gran Canaria (Hutterer and Groh 2014). 

The current thinking is that these species are likely to come from an endemic Canarian genus related to the Madeiran Ferussaciids and this is under investigation.

Furthermore there are sometimes strongly ribbed specimens of "Ferussacia" valida on Fuerteventura which makes it probable that this species is placed within the genus "Sculptiferussacia", which is probably closed associated to the other Canarian species.

The Canarian "Ferussacia"species are self-fertilising breeders, so in fact all of them are clones and the species limits are hard to define, given that they are quite variable in the shell shape. Additionally the shell has only a few distinguishable characters. Revisions in the species status await further research, preferably by genetic methodology.

This species is very difficult to distinguish from the closely related A. subfuscus (Draparnaud, 1805); A. fuscus (O. F. Muller, 1774); A. lizzarrustii Garrido, Castillejo and Iglesias, 1995; and A. molinae Garrido, Castillejo and Iglesias, 1995. Even behavioural observation and dissection may be insufficient. Genetic data have been used to determine certain populations in Wales, UK as belong to "Arion cf. iratii" rather than to A. subfuscus (Rowson et al. 2014). More research on the three Garrido et al. (1995) species is required to clarify their distinctness, and their Red List statuses should arguably be considered provisional until then.
This species may be only a strange form of Vitrea kutschigi and further research is required.

Charpentieria tiberii has currently two subspecies: C. tiberii tiberii and C. tiberii scalettensis Beckmann, 2004. The subspecies differ from few different from each other by virtue of few minor features of the shell (Nordsieck 2013).
This species belongs to the subgenus Kimakowiczia (Fehér et al. 2013).
Mediterranea polygyra is easily distinguished from the other Mediterranea species by virtue of its peculiar shell shape and the internal ornamentation of the proximal penis.
There is some ongoing debate as to whether to regard this species as valid, or as part of a species complex (Kornilios et al. 2009).
Riedel (1992) discusses that this species might be conspecific with Vitrea argolica Riedel, 1962 and some other taxa described from Greece.
Waldén (1983: 268, note 27) commented that two forms are found: a  larger and a smaller (normal) that do not seem to intergrade.
Backeljau et al. (1994) concluded that A. urbiae and A. anguloi are most probably conspecific, whereas the genetic types of A. subfuscus may represent two different species.

According to Fehér et al. (2013) Alopia nefasta has four subspecies: A. nefasta helenae R. Kimakowicz, 1928, A. nefasta mauritii R. Kimakowicz, 1928, A. nefasta nefasta (M. Kimakowicz, 1894), A. nefasta zagani Szekeres, 1969.

Arion franciscoloi is clearly distinguishable from other Arion species by virtue of the high number of genital muscles, the clearly distinguishable vas deferens and epiphallus, the internal structure of epiphallus containing longitudinal folds only and the spermatophore that is completely lacking of denticulation (Boato et al, 1983). This species has a clear taxonomical identity in a usually very complicated group.

According to Bank (2013), accepted subspecies are:

Medora italiana garganensis (A.J. Wagner, 1918)
Medora italiana italiana (Kuster, 1847)
Medora italiana kobelti H. Nordsieck, 1970
Medora italiana milettiana Giusti, 1967
Medora italiana punctulata (Kuster, 1850)

Giusti et al. (1986) came into the conclusion that M. italiana can not be distinguished from M. macascarensis albescens, and moreover they saw no sense of the subspecific differentiation. Therefore Welter-Schultes (2012) treats M. italiana conspecific with M. macascarensis. Colomba et al. (2012) studied the molecular phylogeny of several Italian Medora populations and came into a contrasting conclusion: they assumed that Italian "M. italiana" is a complex of more than one species. Until this debate is clarified, Fauna Europaea (Bank) system follows Nordsieck (1970) and treats the Balkan morphs (M. macascarensis) and the Italian morphs (M. italiana) as distinct species.

The species shows a conservative genital anatomy while remarkable variations of shell size have been detected. On Kythira occurs a form which is bigger on average, with a wider umbilicus stronger radial striae and less flattened upper side. The real identity of these subpopulations have yet to be assessed (Riedel 1992).

Riedel (1992) discusses that several other species (Vitrea keeana, V. matsakisi, V. schuetti, and V. sporadica) might be conspecific with Vitrea argolica Riedel, 1962 or forms or subspecies of it. Until further research is undertaken these taxa ought to be treated as separate species.

Some subspecies might be distinguished, and there is some discussion on whether they should be considered subspecies or different species (Gargominy et al. 2011). There are still taxonomic issues with this species, as it remains unclear if there are two subspecies, or if these forms are actually two different species (C. meisneriana and C. adjaciensis).
Welter-Schultes (2012) considers this species as probably a synonym of P. pseudofallax.
The year of description of this species is frequently erroneously given as 1975, however it was described in 1969 (Gittenberger 1969).

Although many nominal species were described in the 19th century, the radiation of Oxychilusin Corsica was rediscovered only recently by Falkner et al. (2002), who revalidated nominal species and inferred the presence of five new species (one of them has been described since) within three different lineages (subgenera Oxychilus, Ortizius and "Subg.?", still unnamed). The rarity of the native Oxychilus species in Corsica, and the fact that most species are conchologically very close and can only be differentiated by anatomy, explain how hard it is to gather valuable data on distribution, and that further prospections are required to provide data on taxonomy, distribution and ecology of these proposed species.

The species on the Canary Islands were placed into the genus "Ferussacia" based on shell characters, however the generic placement was tentative, pending fuller research into the generic status. There are big differences between the introduced species Ferussacia folliculusand the recent extant species represented there, and in addition, fossil records of representatives of the genus Amphorella were found in Gran Canaria (Hutterer and Groh 2014). 

The current thinking is that these species are likely to come from an endemic Canarian genus related to the Madeiran Ferussaciids and this is under investigation.

Furthermore there are sometimes strongly ribbed specimens of "Ferussacia" valida on Fuerteventura which makes it probable that this species is placed within the genus "Sculptiferussacia", which is probably closed associated to the other Canarian species.

The Canarian "Ferussacia"species are self-fertilising breeders, so in fact all of them are clones and the species limits are hard to define, given that they are quite variable in the shell shape. Additionally the shell has only a few distinguishable characters. Revisions in the species status await further research, preferably by genetic methodology.

Bank (2013) lists three subspecies: Isabellaria thermopylarum thermopylarum (L. Pfeiffer, 1849), Isabellaria thermopylarum blanci (E. von Martens, 1876), and Isabellaria thermopylarum faueri H. Nordsieck, 1974.
There is some ongoing debate as to whether to regard this species as valid, or as part of a species complex (Kornilios et al. 2009).
Welter-Schultes (2012) considers this species a synonym of B. fritillaria, but this is not accepted here.

This species is a member of a group of large Arion species which have often been confused with one another, and sometimes require dissection for successful identification. These species include, amongst others;

A. ater (Linnaeus, 1758);
A. rufus (Linnaeus, 1758);
A. vulgaris Moquin-Tandon, 1855 (=lusitanicus auctt. non Mabille);
A. lusitanicus Mabille, 1868; and,
A. flagellus Collinge, 1893

Although many nominal species were described in the 19th century, the radiation of Oxychilusin Corsica was rediscovered only recently by Falkner et al. (2002), who revalidated nominal species and inferred the presence of five new species (one of them has been described since) within three different lineages (subgenera Oxychilus, Ortizius and "Subg.?", still unnamed). The rarity of the native Oxychilus species in Corsica, and the fact that most species are conchologically very close and can only be differentiated by anatomy, explain how hard it is to gather valuable data on distribution, and that further prospections are required to provide data on taxonomy, distribution and ecology of these proposed species.

The taxonomic authority of this species is frequently given, incorrectly, as A. Villa & J.B. Villa (R. Bank pers. comm. March 2022).

According to Fehér and Szekeres (2016) its subspecies are:

Montenegrina cattaroensis umbilicata (Boettger, 1879)
Montenegrina cattaroensis antivaricostata Fehér and Szekeres, 2016

M. c. antivaricostata was introduced as a nom. nov. for the junior homonym Clausilia umbilicata costata (Boettger, 1907).

According to Fehér et al. (2013), A. canescens canescens (Charpentier, 1852), A. canescens haueri (E.A. Bielz, 1859) and A. canescens striaticollis (M. Kimakowicz, 1894) are subspecies of A. canescens.

The species on the Canary Islands were placed into the genus "Ferussacia" based on shell characters, however the generic placement was tentative, pending fuller research into the generic status. There are big differences between the introduced species Ferussacia folliculusand the recent extant species represented there, and in addition, fossil records of representatives of the genus Amphorella were found in Gran Canaria (Hutterer and Groh 2014). 

The current thinking is that these species are likely to come from an endemic Canarian genus related to the Madeiran Ferussaciids and this is under investigation.

Furthermore there are sometimes strongly ribbed specimens of "Ferussacia" valida on Fuerteventura which makes it probable that this species is placed within the genus "Sculptiferussacia", which is probably closed associated to the other Canarian species.

The Canarian "Ferussacia"species are self-fertilising breeders, so in fact all of them are clones and the species limits are hard to define, given that they are quite variable in the shell shape. Additionally the shell has only a few distinguishable characters. Revisions in the species status await further research, preferably by genetic methodology.

According to Welter-Schultes (2012) this taxon is a synonym of Daudebardia langi. However, this point of view is not supported by arguments, and the species is retained until more research confirms its status.

The species name is frequently miss-spelt "dacida", however the correct spelling is "dacica" (Z. Fehér and Z.P. Erőss pers. comm. 2016).

The species on the Canary Islands were placed into the genus "Ferussacia" based on shell characters, however the generic placement was tentative, pending fuller research into the generic status. There are big differences between the introduced species Ferussacia folliculusand the recent extant species represented there, and in addition, fossil records of representatives of the genus Amphorella were found in Gran Canaria (Hutterer and Groh 2014). 

The current thinking is that these species are likely to come from an endemic Canarian genus related to the Madeiran Ferussaciids and this is under investigation.

Furthermore there are sometimes strongly ribbed specimens of "Ferussacia" valida on Fuerteventura which makes it probable that this species is placed within the genus "Sculptiferussacia", which is probably closed associated to the other Canarian species.

The Canarian "Ferussacia"species are self-fertilising breeders, so in fact all of them are clones and the species limits are hard to define, given that they are quite variable in the shell shape. Additionally the shell has only a few distinguishable characters. Revisions in the species status await further research, preferably by genetic methodology.

Niethammer (1937) described the species from Ischia (southern Italy). Limax gerhardti is not listed in Manganelli et al., 1995 whereas Bank (2013) considers it as a valid taxon. Its taxonomical status must be assessed as most of the Limax species.

Wollaston (1878) recognised three forms of this species:

a) major from laurisilva zones at intermediate and high elevations; this was the larger, more highly coloured form, with a long thin subvertical ventral lamella and a truncated, expanded columella (Seddon 2008: Plate 8C).

b) minor from exposed submaritime cliffs on Madeira; this was the smaller, paler form, with a short subvertical ventral lamella and a truncated, narrower columella. Waldén (1983, p. 268, note 25) suggests minor is probably an “ecophenotype” rather than a true subspecies. This form is smaller - 6.5 mm height, three mm breadth (Seddon 2008: Plate 8D).

c) intermedia from exposed submaritime cliffs on the Desertas Islands and Pico Branco; this form was intermediate in size, with a subvertical ventral lamella better developed and positioned further from the angle of the lip.

The specific status of C. scarificata is clear and well established while its generic assignment is quite controversial. It was previously considered as Siciliaria (Favilli et al., 1995) but Beckmann (2004) and Nordsieck (2002, 2007) considered Siciliaria as a subgenus of Charpentieria. Liberto et al. (2015) in their revision, proposed again the name Siciliaria as a valid genus. More taxonomical research is needed to clarify the generic assignment of this species.

According to Welter-Schultes (2012) Daudebardia ponorica is a synonym of D. cavicola. In Hungary, Pintér (1971) placed D. cavicola as a synonym for D. rufa, which was probably described after an abnormal colourless specimen. Fauna Europea retained Daudebardia ponorica as a valid species until a decision based on targeted research has been taken.

This is a species of very unclear taxonomic position. It was described on the basis of external traits (anatomy is unknown), and the holotype was not found (it was probably destroyed when the Hungarian Natural History Museum was burned in 1956) (Wiktor 1987, 1996). Wiktor (1987) found a very young specimen in Wagner's private collection assigned to this species, however he considered that it did not differ externally from T. robici Simroth, 1885. Further taxonomic research is required to confirm the identity of this species.
Nordsieck described a second subspecies as Albinaria almae efthimia Nordsieck, 2015.

The species has been described as a fossil (Esu, 1978) from Nuraghe su Casteddu (eastern Sardinia). It was later found alive in a nearby area (Cala Gonone) (Manganelli et al., 1995; Welter-Schultes, 2012). The anatomy of the species is still unknown thus the generic belonging to Hypnophila is only provisional, waiting for a taxonomical review.
This species is currently subdivided in two subspecies, Zonites p. parnonensis and Zonites p. fallax.
This species co-occurs with L. marginata, and both species are anatomically very similar and might be confused with each another. Some authors synonymize the two taxa.

Oxychilus oppressus is reported for the whole of Sardinia and it is found in a vast variety of habitats, from extremely dry sand dunes to waste areas and also amongst halophile coastal vegetation, a few meters from the sea. Nevertheless, these records are based mainly upon shell characters that are known to not be extremely reliable in Oxychilidae. Thus, a thorough anatomical and molecular revision is highly recommended, and it would not be surprising if further research revealed a more complex situation within Sardinian Oxychilidae.

The status of Charpentieria incerta is far from being completely clear. Its taxonomy is still lacking of a recent revision and its relationship with other Charpentieria subgenera (e.g. Stigmatica, Gibbularia etc) and species must be investigated yet.
Welter-Schultes (2012) considers this species to be a synonym of B. fritillaria. This requires confirmation.

The are currently two accepted subspecies of Lampedusa lopadusae: L. lopadusae lopadusae from Lampedusa Island and L. lopadusae nodulosa from the Island of Lampione (Bank, 2013). The validity of this subspecific dichotomy must be verified by a taxonomical revision of the species, including both a morphological and a molecular approach.

Charpentieria eminens was originally described by Schmidt (1868) as a subspecies of Charpentieria cressicostata. The species has been overlooked by Favilli et al. (1995). Nevertheless recently recognized as a valid species (Beckmann, 2004), its systematic and taxonomic status must be further evaluated.

According to Bank (2013), accepted subspecies are:
Medora lesinensis dimorpha (Westerlund, 1881)
Medora lesinensis lesinensis (Kuster, 1847)

According to Nordsieck (1993) another synonym is Medora caesia Westerlund 1878.

Pollonera (1890) described Limax ciminensis from Monte Cimino (Viterbo, central Italy). Even though Bank (2017) lists the species in the European checklist, Manganelli et al. (1995) considered the species doubtful as it was described only on the basis of body colouration. The species has not been revised and more taxonomic research is needed.

Walden (1983) considered that this species was described on the basis of an immature Trochulus striolatus (C. Pfeiffer 1828). The affiliation of the species to the genus Keraea Gude, 1911, is doubtful as well. Currently it is unclear whether this is a species in it own rights, or a synonym of T. striolatus.

It is important to note that the name A. lusitanicus has been incorrectly applied to an unrelated species, A. vulgaris Moquin-Tandon, 1855 that is now a widespread pest. The widespread species is still sometimes called "A. lusitanicus auctt. non Mabille, 1868" (e.g. Dreijers et al. 2013). This account concerns the true A. lusitanicus Mabille which is restricted to Portugal (Castillejo 1998, Quinteiro et al. 2005, Welter-Schultes 2012, Dreijers et al. 2013, Pfenninger et al. 2014, Rowson et al. 2014). Systematic and nomenclatural work by several authors are ongoing.

This species is a member of a group of large Arion species which have often been confused with one another, and sometimes require dissection for successful identification. These species include, amongst others;

A. ater (Linnaeus, 1758);
A. rufus (Linnaeus, 1758);
A. vulgaris Moquin-Tandon, 1855 (=lusitanicus auctt. non Mabille);
A. lusitanicus Mabille, 1868;
A. flagellus Collinge, 1893.
The genus Mediterranea is sometimes used as a subgenus of Oxychilus.

Vitrea minellii has been described upon shells and anatomical features (Pinter and Giusti 1981). Its shell closely resembles that of V. trolli and V. subrimata and can be distinguished only by virtue of small shell features. An anatomical comparison reveals to be hard to be performed as the knowledge of the anatomical features of the whole group is still scanty and insufficient. Thus the validity of the species need a revision work involving both a morphological and molecular approach.

In Nordsieck (2002) Charpentieria leucophryna sensu Pfeiffer (1862) is considered as an intermediate form between C. tiberi and C. grohmanniana and is considered only provisionally as a valid species, thus in need of further taxonomic research. C. leucophryna sensu Boettger (1879) is closely related to C. crassicostata and probably refers to what Schmidt (1868) described as Clausilia eminens. Nordsieck (2002) selects and depicts a lectotype for both species in order to avoid taxonomic ambiguities. Charpentieria leucophryna belongs to group 1b as listed by Nordsieck (2002: 34).
Following Nitz et al. (2010), Limax vizzavonensis Falkner and Nitz, 2010 should be used as a replacement name for Limax minimus Pollonera, 1896 non Forsskal, 1775.
Bank (2013) lists two subspecies: Isabellaria clandestina clandestina (Rossmässler, 1857) and Isabellaria clandestina subsuturalis (Westerlund, 1893).

According to the Bank (2013), accepted subspecies are:
Medora agnata agnata (L. Pfeiffer, 1842)
Medora agnata cognata (O. Boettger, 1877)
Medora agnata porcellanea (Westerlund, 1898)
Riedel (1992) discusses that this species might be conspecific with Vitrea argolica Riedel, 1962 and some other taxa described from Greece.

Anatomical studies on topotypical specimens of Hyalina fragrans (road from Scilla to Melia, Reggio Calabria, Italy) revealed a substantial concordance with Schistophallus carotii and thus the former taxon has been considered a junior synonym by Manganelli et al. (1988).
Fauna Europaea lists two subspecies A. m. meridionalis and A. m. pseudotransiens.

Altonaga (1988) and Altonaga and Puente (1991) considered O. farinesianus a junior synonym of O. cellarius. All localities assigned to Zonites farinesianus or Hyalina farinesiana in Spain by different authors, such as Hidalgo, Servain and Fagot (among others) belong to the species O. cellarius. Welter-Schultes et al. (2011) considered O. farinesianusa variety of O. draparnaudi, but Falkner et al. (2002) recognized it as a valid species.

In respect to other Tyrrhenian Oxychilus, O. pilula is well characterized by its Retinella-like shell. Anatomically it shares characters with Oxychilus s.str.: penis with flagellum and internal ornamentation of penis consisting of pleats and rows of papillae. Its nearest species is O. cellarius, but it differs from it by virtue of the 10-12 rows of polygonal papillae in the inner penial complex.

Ariunculus isselii is the only native Arionidae species in Sardinia. Pollonera (1890:32) introduced the subgenus Ichnusarion based upon anatomical (genital) features. The validity of Ichnusarion must be confirmed with further taxonomic investigation.

There is a strong need for a revision of the genus Gibbulinella. It is yet not clear if all island populations are conspecific, and hence genetic and anatomic studies are necessary. Alone on La Palma are three different species known to exist, one of them under description.

Bank (2013) lists eight subspecies: Isabellaria saxicola saxicola (L. Pfeiffer, 1848), Isabellaria saxicola aperta (Küster, 1861), Isabellaria saxicola charpentieri (L. Pfeiffer, 1849), Isabellaria saxicola limbatula H. Nordsieck, 1993, Isabellaria saxicola lunellaris (L. Pfeiffer, 1849), Isabellaria saxicola negropontina (L. Pfeiffer, 1849), Isabellaria saxicola suturalis (Küster, 1861), and Isabellaria saxicola thessala (O. Boettger, 1886).
Sysoev and Schileyko (2009) consider this species to be a synonym of L. jaroslaviae.
Brandstätter and Kapp (2014) reviewed this species and found it to be restricted to the French Alps, with records from other areas referred to other Limax taxa.

According to Fehér et al. (2013) Alopia lischkeana has the following subspecies;

A. lischkeana boettgeri (M. Kimakowicz, 1883)
A. lischkeana cybaea (M. Kimakowicz, 1894)
A. lischkeana galbina R. Kimakowicz, 1943
A. lischkeana lischkeana (Charpentier, 1852)
A. lischkeana livens (E.A. Bielz, 1853), and
A. lischkeana sarkanyi Szekeres, 2007.

According to Bank (2013), accepted subspecies are:
Medora almissana almissana (Kuster, 1847)
Medora almissana mariae H. Nordsieck, 1970
Medora almissana schmidti H. Nordsieck, 1970

Charpentieria ferrox is considered by Nordsieck (2002: 34) only "provisionally" as a valid species as more taxonomical research is needed. The species is not listed within both of the two morphological groups he introduced (2002:34) as its shell presents different features that discriminate it from all the remaining species in the genus.
Bank (2013) lists two subspecies: Isabellaria riedeli riedeli R. Brandt, 1961 and Isabellaria riedeli distanta Szekeres, 1999.

The species is also frequently spelt (and apparently originally described as) Arion vejdovskyi (or 'Arion vejdovskýi') Babor and Košťál (1893).
The status of the species is uncertain (Welter-Schultes 2012).
Wiktor (1987) considered that this species may be conspecific with T. totevi, however there is no relationship between both species (E. Neubert pers. comm. 2017).

According to Fehér et al. (2013) Alopia glorifica has the following subspecies: A. glorifica deceptans Deli and Szekeres, 2011, A. glorifica elegantissima Nordsieck, 1977, A. glorifica glorifica Charpentier, 1852, A. glorifica intercedens A. Schmidt, 1857, A. glorifica magnifica R. Kimakowicz, 1962, A. glorifica subita M. Kimakowicz, 1894, and A. glorifica vranceana Grossu, 1967.
According to Welter-Schultes (2012) this taxon is a synonym of Daudebardia langi.

Nordsieck (1969) described the subspecies C. kuesteri sassariensis upon material kept in the Senckenberg Museum (Frankfurt a. Main, Germany). Later, Giusti et al. (1995) did not mention this taxon in their check list. Bank (2013) considered the subspecies valid. Cochlodina meisenriana (Shuttleworth 1843), once considered as junior synonym of C. kuesteri, is endemic to the Island of Corsica (Bank 2013). C. kuesteri shows a remarkable variability as regards shell shape and features and is in a strong need of revision.

The validity of this species must be evaluated with further taxonomic researches. In addition, the assignment of this taxon to the genus Cecilioides is also questionable, as based upon shell features only, in a group that shows high shell variability. A more appropriate genus for this nominal taxon could also be Hohenwartiana. This taxon belong to group of congeneric (?) species described by Benoit (1862) and in a strong need to be taxonomically revised. Beckmann and Falkner (2003: 38) stated that they had not any (topo)typical material to compare the specimens to them available and thus any taxonomical decision is postponed.

Although many nominal species were described in the 19th century, the radiation of Oxychilus in Corsica was rediscovered only recently by Falkner et al. (2002), who revalidated nominal species and inferred the presence of five new species (one of them has been described since) within three different lineages (subgenera Oxychilus, Ortizius and "Subg.?", still unnamed).

The rarity of the native Oxychilus species in Corsica, and the fact that most species are conchologically very close and can only be differentiated by anatomy, explain how hard it is to gather valuable data on distribution, and that further prospections are required to provide data on taxonomy, distribution, and ecology of these proposed species.

The re-descripcion of Gigantomilax majoricensis Heynemann, 1863 made by Wiktor et al. (2007) corresponds to Gigantomilax benjaminus Borredà & Martínez-Ortí, 2008 (Borredà and Martínez-Ortí 2008, 2010).

Some localities from Minorca and Majorca given by Wiktor et al. (2007) for Gigantomilax majoricensis require confirmation.

Although many nominal species were described in the 19th century, the radiation of Oxychilus in Corsica was rediscovered only recently by Falkner et al. (2002), who revalidated nominal species and inferred the presence of five new species (one of them has been described since) within three different lineages (subgenera Oxychilus, Ortizius and "Subg.?", still unnamed). The rarity of the native Oxychilus species in Corsica, and the fact that most species are conchologically very close and can only be differentiated by anatomy, explain how hard it is to gather valuable data on distribution, and that further prospections are required to provide data on taxonomy, distribution and ecology of these proposed species.
Charpentiera nobilis episoma Brandt, 1961 is now considered a junior synonym of the nominal subspecies by Nordsieck (2004) and Bank (2013).

Falkner et al. (2002; see also Falkner et al. 1999, Falkner and Falkner 2002) and Nitz et al. (2010) started to revise the Limax complex from Corsica, with redefinitions of previously valid species and recognition of at least three new species still to be described. The species here assessed does not correspond to Limax corsicus s.st. but to the corsicus-complex as defined by Nitz et al. (2010).
Nordsieck (2016) considers this species to be a subspecies of I. bicristata (Rossmässler, 1839).

Welter-Schultes (2012) doubts whether H. aradasiana from Sicily represents a separate species: "Giusti (1973) analysed genitalia and radula of specimens from northern Italy and Lipari Island (northern Sicily) and found almost no differences except for a smaller fungiform papilla and a shorter pedunculus of the male part of genitalia [Guisti] argued that two species H. aradasiana and H. hohenwartiana were found in Sicily, but did not explain how to distinguish them and did not report the diagnostic features for the shells".

Muticaria syracusana is the first Muticaria species described from mainland Sicily (Locus Typicus: Siracusa). Since Colomba et al. (2010) published their contribution, the species was thought to occupy a wide area comprehensive of the entire Iblean limestone platform (SW Sicily). Recent molecular and morphological studies (Colomba et al. 2010, Colomba et al. 2012) proved that M. syracusana has a more restricted areal, limited to the coast areas of the province of Siracusa, approximately from Brucoli in the north to Avola-Lido di Noto in the south. They did not provide unfortunately any locality list or map. The inland territories of the Iblean Peninsula seem to be inhabited by a different species, M. neuteboomi, which was previously thought to be a very restricted taxon.

The taxonomic identity of O. amblyopus, which was never illustrated, is a mystery (Falkner et al. 2002). Mabille described Zonites amblyopus from Corsica (without further precision) in 1869 and Locard, based on a sample label and manuscript by Bourguignat, described Hyalina amblyopa from Brest in 1894. Both species seem to have been described based on the same specimen (Falkner et al. 2002). Later Germain (1931), considered H. amblyopa Locard, a junior synonym of O. allarius, and Z. amblyopus Mabille a synonym of O. blauneri. Finally, a sample of Oxychilus sp., composed of six specimens and collected by Réal and Réal-Testud (1988) in Aleria (Corsica) was assigned to O. amblyopus by Falkner et al. (2012).

Although many nominal species were described in the 19th century, the radiation of Oxychilusin Corsica was rediscovered only recently by Falkner et al. (2002), who revalidated nominal species and inferred the presence of five new species (one of them has been described since) within three different lineages (subgenera Oxychilus, Ortizius and "Subg.?", still unnamed). The rarity of the native Oxychilus species in Corsica, and the fact that most species are conchologically very close and can only be differentiated by anatomy, explain how hard it is to gather valuable data on distribution, and that further prospections are required to provide data on taxonomy, distribution and ecology of these proposed species.

Charpentieria (Siciliaria) crassicostata belongs to the group 1 nobilis-calcarae sensu Nordsieck (2002) and, in particular to group 1a, characterized by the palatal edge of the clausilium plate not upbent. This grouping has been accepted also by Beckmann (2004).

Based mainly on their small shell size, originally several non-related Montenegrina taxa were described as subspecies of M. janinensis. These include M. soosi Erőss and Szekeres, 2006, and some subspecies currently classified with M. attemsi, M. dofleini, M. grammica, M, hiltrudae, M. sporadica, and M. tomorosi.

According to B. Rowson (pers. comm. 2016) this species is very difficult to distinguish from the closely related A. subfuscus (Draparnaud, 1805); A. fuscus (O.F. Muller, 1774); A. irati Garrido, Castillejo and Iglesias, 1995; and A. molinae Garrido, Castillejo and Iglesias, 1995. Even behavioral observations and dissections may be insufficient. More research on the three Garrido et al. (1995) species is required to clarify their distinctness, and their Red List statuses should arguably be considered provisional until then.

The species is clearly distinguishable from other Tandonia species by virtue of its extremely long spermatheca and some peculiar detail of the genital morphology. Tandonia bosnensis does not present any taxonomical issue.

According to Fauna Europaea (Bank 2013) accepted subspecies are:

Delima (Delima) amoena amoena (L. Pfeiffer, 1848)
Delima (Delima) amoena smokvicensis (A.J. Wagner, 1915)
Delima (Delima) amoena substricta (Charpentier, 1852)

The re-description of Limax majoricensis Heynemann, 1863 made by Wiktor et al. (2007) corresponds to Gigantomilax benjaminus Borredà & Martínez-Ortí, 2008 (Borredà and Martínez-Ortí 2008, 2010). Some localities from Menorca and Mallorca given by Wiktor et al. (2007) for Gigantomilax majoricensis should be confirmed. Recently Cadevall and Orozco (2016) indicated that G. benjaminus is a junior synonym of G. majoricensis, and suggested that G. benjaminus could correspond to juveniles of G. majoricensis, however they dont provide any evidence about that. Thes specimen studied by Borredà and Martínez-Ortí (2008) were adults, with well developed genitalia. These specimens can be consulted in the Museu Valencià d'Història Natural (Alginet, Spain).

authority: A. Reischütz, P.L. Reischütz & W. Fischer, 2008

taxonomicNotes: Although many nominal species were described in the 19th century, the radiation of Oxychilusin Corsica was rediscovered only recently by Falkner et al. (2002), who revalidated nominal species and inferred the presence of five new species (one of them has been described since) within three different lineages (subgenera Oxychilus, Ortizius and "Subg.?", still unnamed). The rarity of the native Oxychilus species in Corsica, and the fact that most species are conchologically very close and can only be differentiated by anatomy, explain how hard it is to gather valuable data on distribution, and that further prospections are required to provide data on taxonomy, distribution and ecology of these proposed species.

At present there are five species of this genus recognized from the Canary Islands. There are no species recognized from Fuerteventura, La Gomera, El Hierro, however on each island at least one undescribed species exists.

With the exception of P. raricostata, which is easily recognizable, the described species are very similar, and by contrast the shells of the undescribed species are quite distinct. In addition on each island the animal has a different colour.

The taxonomy for these species is confused and the group is in urgent need of a major revision, however, the ability to undertake such a revision is severely limited by a lack of living material. A further problem is that the shell is thick and is able to withstand erosion, hence dead shells may represent a long time period, even centuries under certain conditions.
The type locality is 26°20'N, 19°21'W, Eastern Atlantic just south of the Canary Islands.  The taxonomic status of this species, which is only known from four specimens, is not clear.

This species is considered a subspecies of Acer cappadocicum (as Acer cappadocicum subsp. lobelii (Ten.) A.E.Murray.) by The Plant List (2017), but is considered here as a species based on Pavari (1950).

Classified by Di Pietro et al. (2012) as a species endemic to Italy. This agrees with the WCSP (2016) diagnosis. Others consider the species to be more widespread across central and southern Europe such as Euro+Med (2016). Here, only the Italian populations are treated.

López González (2001) doubted the origin and validity of the species and suggested that it may be of hybrid origin. The species is considered as a synonym of Quercus pyrenaica by do Amaral Franco (1993).
Considered a valid species (S. lavandulifolia Vahl.) by Castroviejo et al. 2010, G. Blanca pers. comm. 2014).
The isolated population in Gudár differs morphologically and genetically from the southern populations (Castroviejo et al. 2010).

Roselló et al. (2021) have proposed subsuming this species into S. tragoriganum as Sideritis tragoriganum subsp. reverchonii (Willk.) R. Roselló, P.P. Ferrer, J. Gómez, E. Laguna & J.B. Peris, comb. & stat. nov.
Formerly included in S. araneus, but now recognised as a distinct species (Hutterer in Wilson and Reeder 2005).

Acomys minous is a poorly defined species. Likely to be part of Acomys cahirinus but currently recognized as valid (see Barome et al. 2001, and Musser and Carleton 2005 for discussion). Studies by Frynta et al. (2010) and Giagia-Athanasopoulou et al. (2011) also support that this is a subspecies of A. cahirinus.

The correct spelling of the epithet has been the subject of discussion, with both 'mirmulans' (Mabberley 2002) and 'mirmulano' used. The species is treated here as a Madeiran endemic under the name S. mirmulans (Lobin et al. 2005).

The species present in the Canary Islands is now considered Sideroxylon canariense, and that from Cape Verde Islands S. marginata.
In some Central European Flora’s Larix decidua var. carpatica is included with L. decidua var. polonica.

It has been argued, on the basis of mandibular measurements, that Crocidura canariensis should be treated as a subspecies of C. sicula (Sarà 1996). However, other morphological, ecological, palaeontological and molecular evidence supports specific status (Michaux et al. 1991, Hutterer et al. 1992). Genetic distances suggest that C. canariensis and C. sicula diverged approximately five million years ago (Vogel et al. 2003), and both share karyotype with C. tarfayaensis (Vogel et al. 2006).
This species was moved from genus Cremnophyton to Atriplex following Kadereit et al. (2010).
The species is closely related to Euphorbia squamigera found in eastern Spain, southern France and Majorca.
Haase (1995) considered this species to be a 'problematic taxa' known from few specimens all taken from a 'poorly defined locality'.
This species was originally viewed as a subspecies of Iglica gratulabunda (Gloer 2002).  The shell form is variable, as shown by Gloer (2002, p. 142)
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands have been treated by Valido et al. (1999).
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands was treated by Valido et al. (1999).
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands was treated by Valido et al. (1999).

Some sources consider the congener K. goerneri to be a synonym of K. milleri. Other populations of unidentified Knipowitschia species from the Ionian basin are genetically and morphologically similar to K. milleri, and this has led to many being placed in an unofficial K. cf. milleri species grouping, and the Lake Trichonida and Zakynthos Island populations are also closely related (Geiger et al. 2014, Barbieri et al. 2015).
Occasionally placed in the genus Squalius, a phylogenetic position not being acceted by following studies.

This genus originally contained two species, one from the Canary Islands, the other from Madeira. These taxa were characterised by large orthostyle shells. Further research on the Canarian taxa L. cuticula, has shown this to be a member of the family Vitrinidae (Alonso et al. 2000, Bank et al. 2002). Hence, Lampadia is now a monotypic genus, with one species restricted to Porto Santo (Seddon 2008).

This species was originally listed as a subspecies of L. sphinctostoma, but Waldén (1986, pers. comm) believed that the taxa merited specific status. Bank et al. (2002) treat this as a separate species in their checklist and Seddon (2008) also treated it as a distinct species.
The range of this species across the Azores is uncertain due to taxonomic concerns. The Lauriidae of the Azores are currently under revision.
The identity of this species has been challenged by Backhuys (1975), considering the possibility that it is a variation of L. rugulosa. The Lauriidae of the Azores are currently under revision.

Bank et al. (2002) placed the species in the genus Caseolus, but did not give any grounds for this revision. Seddon (2008) noted that this species is apparently allied to Caseolus calva rather than to Lemniscia michaudi. Wollaston (1878) and Pilsbry (1893) also commented on the lack of similarity to the type species from Porto Santo. We follow MolluscaBase (2022) in placing the species in genus Caseolus.

Seddon (2008) reported that Wollaston (1878) and Walden (1983) noted that var. subdubia is apparently intermediate between L. wollastoni and L. nivosa; both authors nonetheless treated wollastoni as a distinct species. The intermediate is only found on a very small area on Pico do Concelho, whereas in most parts of their ranges the two species are clearly and distinctly separable. The subfossil shells from the Quaternary deposits below Pico do Concelho are larger than the living shells.

Two different subspecies are recognised by some authors: Leptaxis wollastoni forensis (Wollaston, 1878).
Mandahl-Barth(1950) treated  the population of this islet (Islet of Ilheu de Fora off its eastern coast) as a distinct subspecies.

Morelet and Drouët’s (1857) original description does not mention type locality, so “The Azores” is currently accepted. Morelet (1860) only found it in Caldeira das Sete Cidades, São Miguel, thus restricting the type locality.

The taxonomic identity of this species is considered 'uncertain' by MolluscaBase (2022).

Morelet (1860:158) acknowledged that he confused the shells of L. terceirana with those of L. caldeirarum, which he had described earlier (Morelet and Drouët 1857), and that his 1860 species was erected upon specimens removed from the L. caldeirarum type series.

The taxonomic status of the species is considered 'uncertain' (MolluscaBase 2022).
According to the World Spider Catalog Macrothele should be placed in its own family the Macrothelidae.

Successful hybridization between endemic Macrovipera schweizerii from Milos and adjacent islands reported in Kamelin et al. (1997) and results of a recent comprehensive mitochondrial phylogeny of European vipers (Freitas et al. 2020) support suggestions that this species is conspecific with M. lebetinus. These results are however preliminary and no formal taxonomic change has yet been proposed (Speybroeck et al. 2020; W. Wüster pers. comm. 2022).
We treat S. scharffi and S. trevelyani as synonyms.
The deep water charr reported from Lake Attersee is most likely not conspecific with S. evasus.
Long recorded only from Shetland Islands. This or a similar species has recently been recorded from northern Scotland. Above diagnosis based largely on latter population.

Long known only from the original description, based on material from Orkney Islands. This or a similar species has recently been recorded from Loch Meallt. Above diagnosis largely based on latter population.
Long formally recorded only from Loch Killin. This or similar species have recently been recorded from several other lakes of Scotland. Above diagnosis largely based on latter populations.

Long known only from the original description, based on material from Loch Scourie. This or a similar species has recently been recorded from lakes of northern Scotland. Above diagnosis largely based on latter populations.

Spring and autumn spawning charrs occur sympatrically in Windermere; they do not interbreed in the wild (but can be crossed under laboratory conditions) and are reportedly not distinguishable morphologically except by gill raker counts (which broadly overlap) and more brilliant coloration for the spring spawner. Another morphological study concluded that they differ, but did not explicitly state how they differ. There are indications that they are genetically isolated, for which reason they are here treated as distinct species. Autumn and spring spawners occur in other Cumbrian lakes but they co-occur only in Windermere. No information is available on spawning period of charrs in other Cumbrian lakes (Goat's Water, Wast Water, Lowes Water). The Ennerdale population is said to be phenotypically distinct, but the differences have never been described; its status cannot therefore be evaluated. Differences between S. willoughbii and S. maxillaris are slight and they are possibly conspecific. In the past, numerous populations in intermediate areas have been referred to S. willoughbii, but more data are needed to decide their identity.

Long recorded only from the original description, based on material from Loch Eck. Above diagnosis based on Loch Eck population. This or similar species have recently been recorded from several lakes of western and central Scotland; they differ in having a somewhat smaller eye (4.0-4.5 times in HL), darker body, and small pale spots, often indistinct. Loch Doon population is reporded to have a "substantially lower" number of branchiostegal rays [actual numbers not stated], which, if confirmed, suggests it could be a distinct species.
This species continues to be referred to as Coregonus lavaretus in some of the published literature.

Regional authorities and scientists question the hypothesis that multiple species of Coregonus formerly existed in the Bavarian Danube drainage. While the diversity of coregonids in the area had been well-described by early 20th century authors, only a single species might exist today due to decades of commercial translocations. There are indications that a smaller species formerly existed in Chiemsee, which has obviously also vanished.

Ancient literature records the presence of deepwater trout in several subalpine lakes of Austria, Germany and Switzerland. Some records are ambiguous and probably refer to lacustrine ecotypes of S. trutta. Others are more detailed and indicate that different stocks existed. There is no indication whether and which of these populations survive; some may still be extant, but they do not seem to have received attention. Here, Kottelat and Freyhoff (2007) tentatively use the name S. schiefermuelleri. As originally described, S. schiefermuelleri was a heterogeneous assemblage of several species and Kottelat and Freyhoff (2007) restricted it to the 'mayforelle' of the Austrian lakes (mayforelle is apparently still used locally, but not for the original stock). The 'schwebforelle' of Lake Vierwaldstätter (Switzerland) has a somewhat similar appearance but is unlikely to belong to the same lineage as S. schiefermuelleri as they occur in different drainages. Other populations known from some Alpine lakes, exhibit distinctive phenotypes and it is still unclear whether or not they are reproductively isolated. One such case is the Engadine trout (Lakes St. Moritz and Silsersee, Switzerland, Danube drainage), which has a distinctive morphology and colour pattern.

This species potentially also occurs in Mondsee. But native whitefish in Mondsee spawn one month earlier than in Attersee. Mondsee population was introduced to Attersee in the early 20th century. After introduction, early spawning individuals were recorded also from Attersee but such individuals seem not to have established. Further studies are needed to demonstrate that the Mondsee population really belongs to the present species. Today, about half of the Coregonus harvested in Mondsee result from stocking.

In both Lakes Thun and Brienz, there are forms (?) of this species spawning as deep as 70 m, some with a deeper body. They were formerly more distinct and had clearly-separated spawning seasons, according to reports. Hybridisation with introduced species might have reduced these patterns of behaviour.
This species is restricted to the Dordogne River catchment in France due tu new, unpublished taxonomic studies.

The above diagnosis is based on Lake Vierwaldstätter population. Populations from the smaller lakes apparently exhibit a greater variability and their identity requires confirmation. There have been a number of introductions and there are indications that several lakes are now inhabited by hybrid populations and that the original populations or species are extinct. This is probably the case of the original population of Lake Sempach; descriptions of material collected in the 19th century suggest that in fact it might have been a distinct species. Populations from small lakes have also been impacted by eutrophication.

This species has regularly been referred to as a subspecies of the Twaite Shad (Alosa fallax). However, research has demonstrated that its ecological, molecular and morphological traits are sufficiently distinct for it to be regarded as a distinct taxon.
This species' taxonomic status is unclear, and it may be a synonym of the congener G. aculeatus.

The populations of Cumbria and Scotland differ somewhat in morphology and might be distinct species. On the other hand, available data do not allow to distinguish C. vandesius from the assemblage of all populations referred to C. albula and C. sardinella.

Available data do not allow to distinguish C. albula as a whole from C. sardinella and C. vandesius. A very high variability is reported for all morphological characters between the many populations referred to C. albula, suggesting that several species might be involved. Further studies are needed to resolve their identity. However, C. vandesius is clearly distinct from C. albula populations from eastern Baltic basin, but it is similar to some populations from the western Baltic.

This species' taxonomic status is questionable and under review at time of writing. Cottus subpopulations in southern France, including those inhabiting tributaries of the lower Rhône, plus the Hérault, Aude and a number of short coastal river systems, possess distinct genetic profiles. Together, they are also clearly separated from subpopulations found in the upper Rhône and elsewhere in Europe. Until this situation is resolved the taxon cannot be assessed using Red List criteria.

This species is regarded as a synonym of the congener Knipowitschia panizzae (Verga 1841) by some authorities based on a molecular study by Thacker et al. (2018). However, the authors in fact do not explicitly synonymise the two species, therefore they are retained separately here.
This species' taxonomic validity is in question since genetic studies have failed to separate it from the widespread congener G. aculeatus.

Regional authorities and scientists question the hypothesis that multiple species of Coregonus formerly existed in the Bavarian Danube drainage. While the diversity of coregonids in the area had been well-described by early 20th century authors, only a single species might exist today due to decades of commercial translocations.
This species continues to be referred to as Coregonus lavaretus in some of the published literature.
This species has been intensively studied during the last years and no study could confirm this as an own species. It is therefore treated as a synonym of L. burdigalensis.

Records from the upper Strymon, Loudias and Filiouris drainages had been  considered to be P. strymonicus but their identification remain  unresolved and molecular data suggest hybridistion with or the occurence  of other Phoxinus species. The assessment is therefore restricted to  the Aggitis and Marmaras Rivers.
This species has never been found alive, but is considered as a valid species by everyone.
Moitessieria locardi is considered as a valid species by every author.

This doubtful taxon, described by Bernasconi, has never been found again despite more recent searches at the type locality in Corsica (see Bertrand 2004).

Initially described as Moitessieria corsica, Falkner et al. 2002 placed the species in the genus Spiralix. Then, Boeters and Falkner (2009) restudied the type specimen and proposed to place the species within a new genus, the genus Corseria. This latter placement has been followed by MolluscaBase (2022).

The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (2003) ruled that the name Bos primigenius for this wild species is not invalid by virtue of being antedated by the name based on the domestic form. Therefore, IUCN considers the wild species of Aurochs under the name Bos primigenius, while the domestic forms of cattle are considered under Bos taurus (see Gentry et al. 2004). Grubb (2005) lists B. primigenius as a subspecies of B. taurus, contrary to most authors, but we do not follow that arrangement here.
The genus Obelus was revised by Ibáñez et al. (2003).

Type locality: west of Torremolinos (Málaga). Species described by De Winter & Ripken (1991) only from the type locality employing shell characters and a few generic reproductive system features. Later, Puente (1994, 1996)  provided a more accurate anatomic description of one speciemen she classified with some doubts as O. ortizi. Arrébola (1995, 1998) integrated both authors' data and provided several new sites that appreciably extended the range of the species. This author emphasized the shell differences existing between some of the specimens collected in the southernmost part of the province of Cadiz. Arrébola, Ruiz & Cárcaba (in press) explain that possible episodes of hybridism could happen between O. granesae and  O. ortizi, the later displacing the former. In fact, both species were found together in the same locality. Genetic taxonomy techniques are currently employed to elucidate the status of both and other related species.
Radoman (1985) considered this species to be distinct from the other five taxa in genus Ohridohauffenia and its distribution is different based on the distributional data given in Radoman (1985).

This is a polytypic species with taxonomic problems associated with the subspecies. The currently accepted subspecies are: Orcula austriaca austriaca, O. austriaca faueri Klemm, 1967, O. austriaca goelleri Gittenberger, 1978 and O. austriaca pseudofuchsi Klemm, 1967.
There are two subspecies: Renea moutonii moutonii (Dupuy, 1849) and R. moutonii singularis (Pollonera, 1905).

The type locality for this species is unknown, so it is uncertain what the original distribution could be and Prie (pers. comm., 2009) suggests that there maybe more than one species with the range currently mapped for this species.
Plagigeyeria deformata is considered as a valid species, but has never been collected alive, so the genus name is uncertain.
This taxon was originally assessed under the name Hemicycla adansoni for the Red List, however the nomenclature has changed and it is now renamed as Hemicycla pouchet (see: Ibanez and Alonso 2007)

This species was previously assessed under the name Leiostyla laevigata. Bank et al. (2002) proposed Leiostyla falknerorum nom. nov as a new name for Pupa laevigata Lowe, 1852 as they considered it to be preoccupied by Pupa laevigata von Gallenstein, 1848. This name was known to Pilsbry (1922-26) and Waldén (1983) who both considered it a forgotten name.
The taxonomic status of this species is considered 'uncertain' by MolluscaBase (2022).

This species belongs to an aggregate, with many populations over a wide range of countries.  However there are various other species that could be viewed as part of the species group, B. robiciana and B. opaca (sensu lato), as the species group is under review for their molecular systematics. The species have been assessed based on their current described status, in order to assess their conservation status. Molecular data supports its relationship with some Bosnian B. opaca populations (Z. Feher pers. comm. 2010).

This species was considered by Kabat (1993) following Radoman (1983), to be placed in the genus Anagastina Radoman (1978) which was a replacement name for Anagasta Radoman, 1973, non Heinrich, 1956.

[Need to add Kabat (1993) reference]
This species should be considered as Data Deficient given the taxonomic doubt. See Bichain et al. (2007) and Benke et al. (2009) for a review.
The attribution to the genus Graziana is provisional based on shell characters and requires confirmation (Reischutz and Reischutz, 2009).
Generic placement follows MolluscaBase (2022), however, the generic position of this species is uncertain and its placement under Hauffenia questionable (Georgiev and Hubenov 2013).

Considered by Radoman (1983) to be in a separate genus, Dalmatinella, with  D. fluviatilis being the type species of the genus. Placed by Bank et al. (2006), as a subgenus Dalmatinella in the genus Vindolia.
