  • In the west of Ibiza, in the islands of Ses Bledes live X. e. scopulicola (Na Gorra, Bleda Na Bosc y Bleda Plana), X. e. conjugens (Escull Vermell), X. e. calasaladae en S’Illeta, in front of Cala Saladaand X. e. margaritae in Ses Margalides, island in front of Santa Agnès
  • The northern islands of Ibiza are home to X. e. muradae (Illa Murada), X. e. calderensis (Illa d’en Calders)and X. e. mesquidae (Illot de Sa Mesquida).

Recently Beckmann (2007) has segregated X. cisternasi from X. ebusitana of Ibiza, assigning to the first the current subspecies (14) and the four fossil subspecies (Sacchi 1954, Paul 1984) to the second.
This species has been treated as a variation of Canariella hispidula by Ibanez et al. (1995). However, currently this form is considered as a separate species (Bank et al. 2002).
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands have been treated by Valido et al. (1999). The species now placed in genus Canarivitrina Valido & M.R. Alonso, 2000 by MolluscaBase (2022).
The taxonomic identity of this species is considered 'uncertain' by MolluscaBase (2022).

Napaeus subsimplex (Wollaston, 1878) from El Hierro has usually been considered as a synonym of Napaeus bertheloti. However, in the latest version of Fauna Europaea, it was listed as a separate species without any published reasoning.

A. Hallgass (pers. com. 2011)has recently detected Helix pantanellii De Stefani, 1879 at its type locality Monte Fionchi (less than 20 km distant from the Monti Reatini) and found it similar to Monacha ruffoi in anatomical characters, but different in color and form of aperture. This opens the possibility that M. ruffoi might be a local summit form of M. pantanellii.
According to Falkner (1995), all populations cited as Trochoidea murcica have to be summarised under the older name Xerocrassa subrogata (L. Pfeiffer 1853).
Napaeus tremulans has sometimes been synonymised with N. pruninus but Backhuys (1975) has shown that the two species differ anatomically.
Originally described as Helix (Helicodon) arridens R.T. Lowe, 1831.
The genus is in need of an extensive revision.
Although several literature sources use 'coerulans' the original spelling of the specific epithet is 'caerulans' and e.g. MolluscaBase (2022) or Welter-Schultes (2012) name this species accordingly.
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands was treated by Valido et al. (1999).

Morelet and Drouët’s (1857) original description does not mention type locality, so “The Azores” is currently accepted. However, Morelet (1860) states that this species is found on Terceira and Faial, and possibly on São Miguel; the provenance of the type material confirms it, thus enabling a possible restriction of the type locality to the latter island.

Wollaston (1878) considered the two forms described by Lowe (1860) as synonyms of the widespread species C. mucronatum, as he felt the forms overlapped with this species. He did note that the subfossil forms from Porto Santo were smaller and possibly were the form neritoides. Recently, the taxa were reviewed by Anton de Winter (pers. comm. 2005) who considered C. neritoides to be a separate species.

Prieto (1986) and Puente (1994) considered this a synonym of Helicella itala (Linnaeus 1758). Nevertheless, Gittenberger and Carr (2002) after the finding of a second population consider that H. valdeona is a valid species, differring from H. itala by conchological and anatomical characters.
A taxonomic review of the genus Trochulus spp. is underway by Gerhard Falkner and Ted von Proschwitz.

Seddon (2008) and Cameron et al. (2006) considered that Helicomela punctulata and Helicomela solidus (now listed as Helicomela setulosa) were probably just ecologically different subpopulations of the same species. However, Bank et al. (2002) listed them as separate species, a view maintained by MolluscaBase (2022).

Two subspecies are recognised (MolluscaBase 2022);
  • Helicomela punctulata ssp. avellana (R.T. Lowe, 1855).
  • Helicomela punctulata ssp. punctulata (G. B. Sowerby I, 1924).

Gasull (1964) and other authors considered X. cardonae as a junior synonym of X. nyeli. However, Quintana and Vilella (2001) consider it is a valid species. Molecular studies are necessary to confirm this taxonomic situation.
This species is considered a taxon separate from Acicula lallemanti (Bourguignat, 1864) (Boeters et al. 1989).
Molecular studies are needed to compare the different subpopulations (on the separate islands) and to ensure that these are all the same species.

Seddon (2008) noted that these animals were originally listed as Vitrina when they were described by Lowe and Gould, Waldén (1983) placed the species as Phenacolimax Stabile, 1864, but the main revision by Groh and Hemmen (1986) established the new subgenus Madeirovitrina for the Madeiran species. Work by Alonso et al. (2000) established the genus Plutonia for all the species of Vitrinidae in the Atlantic islands, including subgenera: Guerrina, Madeirovitrina, Insulivitrina and Canarivitrina.

In contrast, Schileyko (2003) elevated Guerrina and Madeirovitrina to full genera leaving only Canarivitrina in Plutonia. Mordan and Martins (2001) reviewed the species from Azores and noted that all the Atlantic island species could be considered a monophyletic group based on the position of the penial retractor muscle.

This species has been placed in various genera: Groh and Hemmen (1986) tentatively allocated this species to the genus Eucobresia rather than with the other Madeirovitrina species. Seddon (2008) and Bank et al. (2002) placed with other Madeirovitrina species, which is now followed by MolluscaBase (2022), and we follow that approach here.
According to Parmakelis et al. (2005) the populations of M. hemmeni are paraphyletic and further studies are required for resolving the taxonomical position of the species.

This is a polytypic species: Hemicycla b. bidentalis, and Hemicycla b. inaccessibilis Groh, 1988. The nominal subspecies is highly polymorphic, the morphs inhabit very differing habitats types. It is a task for the future to assess whether these morphs will be separated into species in their own rights. However, this assessment follows the current view as published by Ibanez et al. (1988).
This species was recorded as the "lancerottensis" form from La Gomera by authors (Groh, pers. comm., 2011).
The specific distinctness has recently been corroborated by molecular genetics studies (Giusti et al. 2011).

Bank et al. (2002) listed this species as Helix innominata Gray, 1825, Ann. Phil., 15 [= NS., 9] (6): 412, on the basis that this name has priority over Caseolus compactus (Lowe, 1831). Gray refers to G.B. Sowerby I, 1824, Zool. J., 1 (1): 58, pl. 3 fig. 8 "Another minute species which we have represented at f. 8 is common at Porto Santo". Seddon (2008) invoked articles 23.9.1.1 and 23.1.9.2 of ICZN to preserve the established usage of Caseolus compactus (Lowe, 1831) since 1848, suggesting that all papers citing Caselous compactus and its subspecies use this name, and none have used Helix innominata.

Mandahl-Barth (1943) listed three subspecies whereas Waldén (1983) listed five, with additional taxa from Porto Santo. Cameron et al. (2006) showed some are conspecific within the subfossil deposits on Porto Santo. Further research may show that the geographically separate subspecies should be treated as a separate species.

MolluscaBase (2022) currently maintains two subspecies;
- Caseolus innominatus ssp. compactus (R.T. Lowe, 1831), and
- Caseolus innominatus ssp. innominatus (Gray, 1825).
Gittenberger (1978) separated Orcula spoliata and O. austriaca as two distinct species.

According to Sattmann & Reischütz (1994), there are several differences between Monacha haussknechti and M. emigrata. For this reason, M. haussknechti is treated as a separate species, and further investigation is urgently required to clarify its taxonomic status.
Seven subspecies have been described to date (MolluscaBase 2020).
The correct year of publication is1832 (see Sherborn 1924, Index Animalium, Sect. 2, Part 5: p. 1110).
Until recently, this taxon has been considered to be a subspecies or even a synonym of Helix ligata. For this reason, this taxon was not target to any specific research.
Authorship of this species was previously assigned to Deshayes (1839), however Deshayes (1840) is now considered the Author (MolluscaBase 2020).
F. Welter-Schultes question the validity of this species.

Manganelli et al. (1995) considered the species to be of uncertain taxonomic status.

The taxonomic authority of this species is frequently given, incorrectly, as A. Villa & J.B. Villa (R. Bank pers. comm. March 2022).
This species has been treated as a variation of Canariella hispidula by Ibanez et al. (1995). However, currently this form is considered as a separate species (Bank et al. 2002).
This species was described in the genus Renea, but was recently correctly replaced in the genus Acicula (Gittenberger 2004). The correct name is thus Acicula douctouyrensis.
There are two sub-species: Hemicycla psathyra psathyra and H. psathyra bituminosa (J. Mabille, 1883).

Fauna Europea (Bank 2011) gives the year of publication as 1830, but the correct date is 1832 (see Sherborn 1930, Index Animalium, Sect. 2, Part 23: p. 5771). This is a polytypical species; in addition to the nominotypical subspecies, further 13 subspecies are listed as valid in Fauna Europaea (Bank 2011):
M. s. scabriuscula (Deshayes, 1832)
M. s. buelowi (Maltzan, 1886) [bulowi is an error]
M. s. delpretei (Monterosato, 1892)
M. s. demissa (Benoit, 1859) [demissae is an error; the year of publication should be corrected to 1859]
M. s. eulasia (Westerlund, 1889)
M. s. explanata (Benoit, 1859) [the year of publication should be corrected to 1859]
M. s. latebrosa (Monterosato, 1892)
M. s. nadorrica (Westerlund, 1889)
M. s. paciniana (Philippi, 1836)
M. s. paulucciana (Monterosato, 1892)
M. s. segestana (Philippi, 1836)
M. s. selinuntina (Philippi, 1836)
M. s. tayae (Monterosato, 1892)
M. s. vieta (Rossmässler, 1836)
The Sicilian representatives of Marmorana are traditionally attributed to the subgenus Murella L. Pfeiffer, 1877. Recently, after a molecular genetic study, Fiorentino et al. (2008) pleaded for the elevation of Murella to the rank of a full genus.

As it has been indicated for Allognathus hispanicus, it is necessary to conduct a revision of the entire complex Iberellus Hesse, 1908, considered as a subgenus of Allognathus by several authors (Vilella et al. 2003, Beckmann (2007) or as an independent genus by some others (Jaeckel 1952, Gasull 1963, Puente 1994, Quintana 2007). Some authors consider that Iberellus contains only one species with or without subspecies within it, while some others consider several species (see Puente 1994 and Beckman 2007 for a review).
Closely related to M. hemmeni in molecular analyses (Parmakelis et al. 2005).

This species was considered as a synonym of M. gregaria by Giusti (1973). In the Italian checklist (Manganelli et al. 1995), the species is again recognised as valid, but with the remark that it needs urgently a systematic study.

The monotypic subgenus Polloneriella (Alzona & Alzona Bisacchi, 1940) was elevated to the rank of a full genus by Giusti and Manganelli (1998), however Polloneriella was later reduced to a subgenus of Xerosecta by Razkin (2015).

The species was originally erroneously placed in genus Polloneria (rather than Polloneriella) when first assessed.
This is a polytypic species, only the nominotypical subspecies, O. t. templorum, occurs in Europe.

Seddon (2008) noted that these animals were originally placed as Vitrina when they were described by Lowe and Gould, Waldén (1983) placed the species as Phenacolimax Stabile, 1864, but the main revision by Groh and Hemmen (1986) established the new subgenus Madeirovitrina for the Madeiran species. Work by Alonso et al. (2000) established the genus Plutonia for all the species of Vitrinidae in the Atlantic islands, including subgenera: Guerrina, Madeirovitrina, Insulivitrina and Canarivitrina. Mordan and Martins (2001) reviewed the species from the Azores and noted that all the Atlantic island species could be considered a monophyletic group based on the position of the penial retractor muscle.

In contrast, Schileyko (2003) elevated Guerrina and Madeirovitrina to full genera leaving only Canarivitrina in Plutonia. This treatment has been adopted by MolluscaBase (2022), which we follow here.

Xerocrassa amphiconus and X. siderensis populate the same region in eastern Crete, but are usually not syntopic. The two species are quite similar in both their genitalia and shell characteristics (Hausdorf & Sauer 2009).
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands was treated by Valido et al. (1999).

Morelet (1860) extended the range of L. azorica to Santa Maria as variety γ minor, which Backhuys (1975) elevated to subspecific level. Van Riel et al. (2005), using molecular data, found evidence for specific separation of the populations from Santa Maria. Backhuys (1975) states the type locality as “Azores, Santa Maria, Ribeira Almagreira”; however, just after that statement, the author mentions the two specimens from Pico Alto as “paratypes”. Ribeiro, Almagreira is at the footsteps of Pico Alto; for that reason, although confusing, this locality imprecision is not worth correcting.

The taxonomic identity of this species, as Leptaxis (Leptaxis) minor Backhuys, 1975, is considered 'uncertain' by MolluscaBase (2022).
This genus is in need of an extensive revision.

This species was described by Arrébola and Gómez (1998) as belonging to the genus Chondrina using shell and anatomic features. Morphological and genetic studies confirm that this species belongs to this genus (Kokshoorn and Gittenberger 2010) and not to the genus Rupestrella as indicated by other authors.

Fauna Europaea lists this taxon as a separate species. According to Fiorentino et al. (2010), it is a junger synonym of T. villicus. Earlier K. L. Pfeiffer (1946) proposed that T. sardonius should be treated as a subspecies of T. villicus. According to the assessors of this species, this view should be retained. However, as the taxon is listed as a species in its own rights in Fauna Europea, it is here assessed as such.
According to Subai (1996) there two subspecies of Chilostoma amorgia; C. a. amorgia and C.a. furia.

This is a polytypical species; in addition to the nominotypical subspecies, further eitght subspecies are listed as valid in Fauna Europaea: carsoliana (A. Férussac, 1821), contaminata (Paulucci, 1878), persianii (Tiberi, 1878), strigata (A. Férussac, 1821), tetrazona (De Cristofori & Jan, 1832), tiburtina (E. von Martens, 1899), uniarmata (Paulucci, 1881), uzielliana (Paulucci, 1881). Forcart (1965) considered M. fuscolabiata as a younger synonym of M. signata and used the name for the southern formgroup. The molecular genetic analysis of Fiorentino et al. (2010) has proven the coherence of the Rassenkreis, but the classification of subspecies has been judged as insufficient by Nordsieck (2011) who proposed a grouping which is quite similar to that of Fauna Europaea. The preoccupied name strigata should be replaced by its valid junior synonym umbrica (J. Mabille, 1868).

This is a polytypic species with two subspecies: T. romagnolii romagnolii (Dutailly, 1867), and T. r. deschampsiana (Hagenmüller, 1888).
T. romagnolii romagnolii: Hélice de Corte
T. romagnolii deschampsiana: Hélice de la Tartagine [note: the subspecies does not occur in the Tartagine valley as could be presumed from the common name].
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands have been treated by Valido et al. (1999).

This species has been treated as a variation of Canariella hispidula by Ibanez et al. (1995). However, currently this form is considered as a separate species (Bank et al. 2002). This species is polytypic and comprises the nominal subspecies and C. fortunata beata Wollaston, 1878.
The taxonomic identity of this species requires confirmation, it is listed as 'uncertain' by MolluscaBase (2022).
The species has partly been misidentified by several  authors. Further anatomical examination is needed for the verification of the species' presence to various areas (Hausdorf 2003).
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands have been treated by Valido et al. (1999).
The species was described by Morelet in 1864 under the name Helix paivana and later renamed by Mabille in 1882.
Some authors consider that this species should be included in the Hellicella instead of Xerotricha genus (Puente 1994).

This is a  polytypic species with two subspecies besides the nominotypical subspecies: T. acropachia pollonerae (Caziot, 1903) and T. acropachia garciai (Hagenmüller, 1888).
According to recent research (Falkner ined.) the populations in the north-west of the total distribution area adjacent to the Monte Cardo, which have been described as Helix (Campylaea) venacensis Caziot, 1903, form a well characterised distinct species which has wrongly been treated as a synonym of T. a. acropachia.
This species has been revalidated by Falkner et al. (2002). Its taxonomic validity needs to be fully investigated, especially at the molecular level.

Moreletina horripila was treated by Backhuys (1975) as an Actinella, a Madeiran genus, on account of its anatomy. Cunha et al. (2005) listed it in its present combination, following the work of Martins (2002).

Grossu (1987) mentioned M. alpicola as a valid species and listed anatomical differences. According to www. animalbase.org: "Smaller than typical Mastus venerabilis, but obviously no other differences. "Mastus alpicola" (correct spelling) is possibly a species complex and needs further taxonomic investigation.

As Helix metabola is based on juvenile specimens which belong to Theba pisana (as already remarked by Kobelt), the appropriate name for the endemic Cernuella of Lampedusa is C. lampedusae (Kobelt, 1890). The taxonomic position and specific validity are questioned (Cianfanelli 2002). In the Italian checklist this species is not mentioned, not even as a synonym.

This is a polytypical species; in addition to the nominotypical subspecies, a further 27 subspecies are listed as valid in Fauna Europaea (Bank 2011):

M. fuscolabiata apula (Kobelt, 1897), M. f. aspidensis (Tagliani, 1942), M. f. brunellae (Sacchi, 1956), M. f. cassinensis (Tagliani, 1942), M. f. castelluccensis (Kobelt, 1906), M. f. circeja (Kobelt, 1903), M. f. consigliana (Kobelt, 1904), M. f. gauri (Kobelt, 1903), M. f. irpina (Kobelt, 1903), M. f. lauriensis (Kobelt, 1905), M. f. mariannae (Kobelt, 1879), M. f. mingardii (Kobelt, 1904), M. f. picentina (Kobelt, 1903), M. f. pollinensis (Bacci, 1951), M. f. posidoniensis (Kobelt, 1877), M. f. potentiae (Kobelt, 1903), M. f. prausi (Bacci, 1951), M. f. saprensis (Kobelt, 1904), M. f. serpentinarum (Degner, 1936), M. f. sirinensis (Kobelt, 1904), M. f. sybaritica (Kobelt, 1906), M. f. tegianica (Degner, 1936), M. f. tenetensis (Kobelt, 1904), M. f. tiriolensis (Adami, 1873), M. f. vallicola (Kobelt, 1903), M. f. wullei (Kobelt, 1903). Forcart (1965) considered M. fuscolabiata as a synonym of M. signata.

The Marmorana forms south of the Napoli-Benevento depression have traditionally been united in a multifarious Rassenkreis with 10 to about 30 subspecies (Kobelt 1906, Degner 1936, Forcart 1965, Fauna Europaea (Bank 2011)). This concept has completely lost its base with the molecular genetic analysis of Fiorentino et al. (2010). Forms which have been formerly attributed to M. fuscolabiata are positioned in very different clades of the phylogenetic tree. Especially the typical form from the peninsula of Sorrento turned out to be closely related to the Tuscan saxetana. This means that even if a part of the former Rassenkreis can be maintained in Calabria, this cannot be named M. fuscolabiata.

Following Nordsieck (2011) this species complex needs to be separated, the taxon M. saxetana sensu auctores will become a synonym of M. fuscolabiata.
Wollaston (1878) described two varieties; one variety lentiginosa and var. stellaris and  Bank et al. (2002) retain both subspecies in their Madeiran list.

Morelet (1860) extended the range of L. azorica to Santa Maria as variety γ minor, which Backhuys (1975) elevated to subspecific level; the latter author extended the range of the species to Flores Island.

van Riel et al. (2005), using molecular data, found evidence for specific separation of the populations from Santa Maria (L. minor Backhuys1975) and Flores (undescribed), as well as for splitting the eastern population of São Miguel from the western population, the latter being L. azorica. The subgeneric status of the Azorean Leptaxis is in need of revision (Bank et al. 2002).
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands was treated by Valido et al. (1999).

Waldén (1983) recognized a varietal name used by Wollaston, Caseolus commixtus var. pusilla, as meriting specific status, giving it the name baixoensis. Seddon (2008) reports difficulty separating Caseolus baixoensis Waldén, 1983 and Caseolus compactus vigiae Waldén, 1983, and in the absence of type material of the latter considered that these may be conspecific.

According to P. Subai (pers. comm. 2010) the genus Wladislawia could be placed as a separate genus. Damjanov and Likharev (1975) considered the species to have one subspecies (W. polinskii pirinensis (A. Wagner 1927) in addition to the nominate subspecies.
Theba impugnata was previously named Helix impugnata.

There are as many as five subspecies considered. X. caroli caroli (Dohrn & Heinemann 1862), X. caroli formenterensis F. Schröder 1984, X. caroli jaeckeli (Altimira 1965), X. caroli spartariensis F. Schröder 1984, and X. caroli alegriae F. Schröder 1984.

The taxonomy of the genus Ponentina has been elucidated after the revision of this genus published by Holyoak and Holyoak (2012). This study placed Ponentina martigena (Férussac, 1832) into this genus, previously considered as Trichia (=Trochulus) martigena by several authors.
According to Fauna Europaea this is a valid species. E. Neubert (pers. comm. 2010) also considers it a valid species. This species can be confused with Helix cincta.
According to Kokshoorn and Gittenberger (2010) for a long time, S. juliana has been considered only a synonym of S. similis.
The authorship is cited as: (Fra' Piero [Arbanasich, P.], 1897) by Manganelli and Giusti (2005) and as ([Arbanasich, P.], 1897) by Giusti et al. (2011).

Nomenclatural comments: Bank et al. (2002) recognised that Helix nivosa var. planata (Lowe, 1855) is preoccupied by Helix planata Maton & Rackett, 1807, and hence gave it a new name.

Mandahl-Barth (1950) recognised three subspecies from different islands. As these forms are distinct as well as geographically isolated all three are discussed here:
Leptaxis nivosa nivosa (Sowerby, 1824)
Leptaxis nivosa calensis (Bank et al., 2002)
Leptaxis nivosa craticulata (Lowe, 1852)

Manganelli et al. (1995) and Fauna Europeae recognised five valid subspecies, whilst MolluscaBase (2022) accepts four;
  • Campylaea planospira planospira (Lamarck, 1822)
  • Campylaea planospira benedicta Kobelt, 1872
  • Campylaea planospira occultata (Paulucci, 1886)
  • Campylaea planospira setulosa (Briganti, 1825).
The genus is in need of an extensive revision.
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands was treated by Valido et al. (1999).

This is a polytypical species; in addition to the nominotypical subspecies, seven further subspecies are listed as valid in Fauna Europaea (Bank 2011):
M. p. platychela (Menke, 1830)
M. p. connexa (Westerlund, 1889)
M. p. excelsa (K.L. Pfeiffer, 1931)
M. p. florioi (Monterosato, 1892)
M. p. iparia (Benoit, 1857) [ragusae Kobelt 1883]
M. p. rosaliae (Benoit, 1857)
M. p. sicana (A. Férussac, 1832)
M. p. spuria (Westerlund, 1876); the description as "forma" is based on one specimen from Parreyss without an indication of a type locality; Westerlund treated it later as an infrasubspecific entity within the typical platychela.

Candidula claudia (Sacchi, 1954) is a synonym to this species. The form C. scissa (Paulucci, 1881), originally described as a variety of C. cavannae, is considered to belong to the form group of C. grovesiana.

Sacchi has described C. claudia from Capri and the peninsula Sorrent, but this species is anatomically and conchologically identical with C. cavannae, and thus has to be regarded as a younger synonym.
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands have been treated by Valido et al. (1999).
This is most probably a species complex, which urgently needs scientific research (Greve et al. 2010). The complex is known from almost all islands within the Canary Island group.

Soós (1943) believes that Helicopsis talmacensis is not synonymous to this species, but that it is a subspecies of H. instabilis. In this assessment however, H. talmacensis records are also considered.

Seddon (2008) and Cameron et al. (2006) considered that Helicomela punctulata and Caseolus solidus (now listed as Helicomela setulosa) to probably be just ecologically different subpopulations of the same species, however Bank et al. (2002) listed them as separate species, a position maintained by MolluscsBase (2022).
De Mattia and Mascia (2014) placed X. hillyeriana as a synonym of X. dorhni.
The taxon has been defined by a Lectotype designation by Giannuzzi-Savelli et al. (1986).
Locus Typicus: L'ile Majorque à Palma (Mallorca).
According to Fauna Europaea, this species comprises two sub-species: Napaeopsis ossicus ossicus (O. Boettger 1885); Napaeopsis ossicus discolor (O. Boettger 1885).

Morelet and Drouët’s (1857) original description does not mention type locality, so “The Azores” is currently accepted. Morelet (1860:187-188) states that this species is spread through most of the islands, mentioning that it is most abundant in São Miguel and Faial. However, preliminary anatomical work has revealed that most records from islands other than São Miguel are most probably N. delibutus (A. Martins pers. comm. 2010). It is, then, advisable to restrict the type locality to São Miguel, where the type material comes from.
Theba grasseti was previously named Helix grasseti.

The shells of X. siderensis are very variable especially between populations. Some populations, especially east of Agia Fotia and west of Zakros, are characterized by a distinct edge at the periphery ofthe body whorl and ribs. In the population from Agia Fotia, 1.7 km towards Palekastro, an extreme specimen with a distinct keel and a very narrow umbilicus was found. This specimen approaches the charactersof X. amphiconus. However, the specimens from adjacent populations of X. amphiconus have a more protruding keel and are more depressed. The intermediate specimen might be evidence for an introgressionbetween X. siderensis and X. amphiconus. Nevertheless, we classify X. siderensis and X. amphiconus as distinct species, because such specimens are very rare, and even these can be referred to one of the two taxa without doubts (see remarks by X. amphiconus) (Hausdorf & Sauer 2009).
Odhner (1932) supposed it to be a synonym of H. guarmatemes, but nowadays it is believed to be a species on it’s own.
A synonym of this species is N. tarnerianus (Grasset, 1856).
The genus is in need of an extensive revision.
The genus Obelus was revised by Ibáñez et al. (2003).
Ena elongata (Kobelt 1877) has been attributed to the genus Ena based on shell characters (Bank & Menkhorst 1992, Hausdorf 2001).

Moreletina vespertina was treated by Backhuys (1975:218) as an Actinella, a Madeiran genus, on account of its anatomy. Cunha et al. (2005) listed it in its present combination, on account of the work of Martins (2002) for Moreletina obruta.

The genus is in need of an extensive revision.

Two subspecies are currently accepted by MolluscaBase (2022):
- Metafruticicola coartata ssp. coartata Fuchs & Käufel, 1936
- Metafruticicola coartata ssp. gemina Fuchs & Käufel, 1936

According to Kokshoorn and Gittenberger (2010) there is one subspecies described: Rupestrella occulta gibilfunnensis (De Gregorio, 1895) (the type locality is the Gibilforni mountain, near Palermo, in Sicily, Italy). According to www.animalbase.org the species needs to be revised.
This is a polytypic species currently subdivided into three taxa: Ena m. monticola, Ena monticola dryops (E. von Martens, 1889, and Ena monticola klissurica Bank & Menkhorst, 1992.
The taxonomic identity of this species is considered 'uncertain' by MolluscaBase (2022).
Closely related with M. abundans in molecular analyses (Parmakelis et al. 2005)

This species was formerly included within Podarcis erhardii. The assignment of a number of subspecies of Podarcis erhardii to P. cretensis by Lymberakis et al. (2008) was made "without much justification" (Uetz et al. 2022), although this arrangement is presently accepted and as such P. erhardii is not considered to occur on Crete (Speybroeck et al. 2016).
This species was formerly included within Iberolacerta monticola, but recognized to be distinct by Arribas, Carranza and Odierna (2006).

authority: Lymberakis, Poulakakis, Kaliontzopoulou, Valakos and Mylonas, 2008

taxonomicNotes: Ampedus gallicus has been described as 'new to science' from France but has not been reported elsewhere. It seems unlikely that there really is an endemic French Ampedus and so this species is probably going to be synonymised with another Ampedus species at some stage in the future. Until such a review takes place, A. gallicus must remain as a separate species and be assessed for the Red List separately. It is within the A. nemoralis group.

The taxonomic status of the species needs to be confirmed. Wollaston (died 1878) tells in the original description: 'the only specimen which I have yet seen of this insect was captured by myself (beneath the bark of a felled Spanish chestnut-tree) at the Agua Mansa, in Tenerife. Possibly it may be but a geographical state of the European P. depressus; but further material would be necessary, for comparison, before such could be ascertained'.
The taxonomic status is uncertain and is considered doubtful by several Elateridae experts. It is likely to be very close to other Ampedus species (A. pomoni).
This species is taxonomically uncertain and its status is questionable (B. Büche pers. comm. 2009).
This species was described on the basis of a single larva from the type locality in Sweden and the validity of this species is in question.
Leipaspis lauricola has two subspecies: L. l. lauricola Wollaston, 1862 and L. l. gomerensis Wollaston, 1862 (Plata-Negrache and Prendes-Ayala 1981).

Flora Iberica (Castroviejo et al. 2001) treat Jasione lusitanica either as a synonym of Jasione maritima or of Jasione montana var. montana. However, the plant is treated as a Portuguese endemic in this assessment.
This species is within the genus Vella according to recent genetic research (Crespo et al. 2005).

Brassica glabrescens Poldini is a wild relative of a number of crops in the brassica group; including broccoli, B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck, Brussels sprout, B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker, cabbage, B. oleracea var. capitata L., cauliflower, B. oleracea var. botrytis L., kale, B. oleracea var. viridis L., swede, B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb., turnip, B. rapa L. ssp. rapa, and oilseed rape, B. napus L. var. napus.

The taxon is only recognized at subspecific level as B. repanda ssp. glabrescens (Poldini) Gómez Campo in some taxonomic treatments.
Valid taxonomy should be Aconitum napellus L. ssp. corsicum (Gayer) Seitz (Jeanmonod and Gamisans 2007).
Euro+Med Plantbase (2006-2011) treats this species as Minuartia verna ssp. verna in which case the distribution would be more widespread.

Colchicum corsicum Baker has been split in two taxa: C. corsicum Baker occupying the eastern part of the distribution area, and C. arenasii Fridl. occurring in the western part (Figari is the limit between the two) (Friedlander 1999).

The species was recorded in the past from Sardinia but that is a mistake as those reports refer to C. verlaqueae Fridl.

Crambe laevigata DC. ex Christ is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R.E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).
According to Caujapé-Castells et al. (2008), this species includes two subspecies: Atractylis arbuscula subsp. arbuscula and Atractylis arbuscula subsp. (or sometimes var.) schizogynophylla.
Two subspecies considered: Coincya rupestris ssp. leptocarpa (Gonz.-Albo) Leadlay and Coincya rupestris Porta & Rigo ex Rouy ssp. rupestris.
Flora Europea writes it as Jonopsidium acaule.

Lactuca watsoniana Trel. is a tertiary wild relative of lettuce, L. sativa L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010). However, according to H. Schaefer (pers. comm. 2010), its position in the genus Lactuca is not confirmed and it might turn out to belong to another Asteraceae genus as its morphology is quite different from all other Lactuca species.

The taxonomy of this species might be under review. The Plant List (2011) lists it as a synonym of Festuca subverticillata (Pers.) E.B.Alexeev. However, according to Grassbase (Clayton et al. 2006 onwards), this species does not occur in Europe. Grassbase does not list Poa riphaea in its list of accepted species. The World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010) treats Poa riphaea as a heterotypic synonym of Poa laxa and the latter as a European endemic. But Grassbase states that Poa laxa is also found outside Europe. Due to this confusion, Poa riphaea is treated here as a valid name at the moment and as endemic to the Czech Republic.

Crambe arborea Webb ex Christ is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R.E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.). Two varieties are native to Europe: C. arborea var. arborea and C. arborea var. indivisa Svent. (Euro+Med PlantBase 2006).
This species has taxonomic problems and its validity is questionable. It is difficult to detect as it is very similar to Myosotis welwitschii Boiss. & Reuter (ICN 2006).

Beta patula Aiton is a primary wild relative of cultivated beets, B. vulgaris L. ssp. vulgaris (leaf, garden, fodder and sugar beet groups) (classified in Beta section Beta). B. patula was given specific rank in a reclassification of the genus by Letschert (1993) and later Lange et al. (1999) based on its distinctive morphology and the fact that it is confined to two small islets off Madeira (Pinheiro de Carvalho 2010). Ford-Lloyd (2005) gives a detailed review of the taxonomy of the genus Beta. Although further changes have been made to the classification of the Beta gene pool since this publication, this has not changed the specific status of B. patula in Section Beta.
Current accepted name of the species is Gonospermum ptarmiciflorum (Webb) Febles, according to Acebes et al. (2010).

This taxon is representative of the taxonomical problem with the genus Ophrys. The WCSP (2015) and Kew are following the recent (but controversial) synthesis of Pedersen and Faurholdt (2007) + Faurholdt and Pedersen (2009).
Thus, two extremes can be followed:

- Consider that there is one species, Ophrys argolica, with several geographical and/or ecological subspecies (+ hybrid swarms), or;
- That there are several species in the complex, each one with a narrow geographical distribution, plus several hybridogenous species narrowly distributed.

In order to take more easily in consideration historical confusions and also field uncertainty even for part of recent data, we chosen here to consider a species sensu lato approach for the whole group, and to detail each of the most individualised taxa as a subspecies above the same binomial.
Because Ophrys argolica sensu lato does not represent the biological reality on the ground and is evidently Least Concern, we follow here the approach that acknowledges that each subspecies component represents an evolutionary entity with its own threats and conservation problems.
N.B. : the 2010 assessment was based on O. argolica sensu stricto (i.e. subsp. argolica).
There is taxonomic research about this and other endemic species in Austria and Germany. This is a not well studied group with lots of endemics.

Contrary to Plants of the World online, Dactylorhiza kalopissii E. Nelson, 1976, Dactylorhiza macedonica Hölzinger & Künkele, 1988 and Dactylorhiza pythagorae Gölz & H.R.Reinhard, 1992 are considered three distinct species (Hedrén et al. 2007, Tsiftsis and Antonopoulos 2017).

Brassica macrocarpa Guss. is a wild relative of a number of crops in the brassica group; including broccoli, B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck, Brussels sprout, B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker, cabbage, B. oleracea var. capitata L., cauliflower, B. oleracea var. botrytis L., kale, B. oleracea var. viridis L., swede, B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb., turnip, B. rapa L. ssp. rapa, and oilseed rape, B. napus L. var. napus. It is most closely related to and interfertile with B. oleracea (Branca et al. 2008, 2010; Qiu et al. 2008).
A. lemanniana has close affinities with A. vulneraria of which it is probably only a subspecies (Buord and Lesouëf 2006).
The accepted name in Italy is Galatella sorrentinoi Tod.

Accepted as a valid species by Euro+Med Plantbase (Valdés 2011), Echium gentianoides is considered a synonym of Echium thyrsiflorum Masson ex Link by POWo (Board of Trustees, RBG Kew 2018). Echium thyrsiflorum is considered a synonym of Echium decaisnei Webb & Berthel. by Valdés (2011).
Due to morphological similarities and proximity observed in phylogenetic research based on molecular characters, this species has been proposed as synonym to Petrocoptis pardoi Pau.
There are several synonyms for this species such as Hormatophylla pyrenaica (Lapeyr.) Dudley and Cullen or Ptilotrichum pyrenaicum (Lapeyr.) Boiss. and Alyssum pyrenaicum might not be the valid name.
The new name for Rosmarinus tomentosus Hub.-Mor. & Maire, Salvia granatensis B.T.Drew, was proposed by Drew et al. (2017) because Salvia tomentosa Mill. is already in use.

Omphalodes kuzinskyanae is confused with Omphalodes littoralis ssp. gallaecica. Omphalodes kuzinskyanae only occurs in Portugal, while Omphalodes littoralis ssp. gallaecica is present in Spain (Galicia) (I. Fernandez in Flora Iberica in prep.).
The name Vicia bifoliolata is accepted by Flora Iberica (Castroviejo et al. 2000), although Euro+Med Plantbase (2006-2011) and ILDIS (2010) treat it as a synonym of Vicia filicaulis Webb & Berthel..
Symphytum cycladense Pawl. is treated under the name Symphytum davisii Wickens ssp. cycladense (Pawl.) Stearn. in the Greek Red Data Book (Snogerup and Snogerup in: Phitos et al. 2009).
It is difficult to distinguish between Verbascum litigiosum and  Verbascum thapsus L. and therefore the range of the species may not be well known (ICNB 2007).

Elatine gussonei has been confused with E. macropoda Guss. and to a less extent with E. hydropiper L. in the past but the distinction is clarified by Mifsud (2006), where the most important distinctive character lies in the morphology of the seeds.
This species is a stenoendemic of Mt. Olympos, Greece, and belongs to the monotypic genus Jankaea of the tropical family Gesneriaceae (Commission of the European Communities 2009).

Where Pulsatilla subslavica occurs with other related species, hybridization takes place: in the southern part of the range with P. grandis, in the northern part with P. slavica. This backcrossing results in transient individuals, even whole populations, which are difficult to identify (Mereďa and Hodálová 2011).
The genus Sinapidendron is endemic to Madeira and is part of the brassica complex.

Crambe sventenii Pettersson ex Bramwell & Sunding is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R.E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).
According to Flora Ibérica, this taxon is invalid, as it is an annual form of Anthyllis vulneraria subspecies gandogeri (Sagorski) W.Becker ex Maire (Benedi 2006).

The taxonomic identity and nomenclature of this species requires confirmation.

Recent Italian literature refers to this species as Linum mulleri (e.g. Pignatti et al. 2017, Bartolucci et al. 2018).

The species was described by Moris (1829). The species is placed by some references (e.g. Raab-Straube 2018, WCVP 2021) as a synonym of Linum maritimum L. (1753). Arrigoni (1984) claimed the validity of the taxon as a species.

Diplotaxis vicentina (Cout.) Rothm. is a wild relative of brassica crops as well as being related to cultivated perennial wall rocket, D. tenuifolia (L.) DC.

Some taxonomists consider D. vicentina to have only subspecific status as D. siifolia ssp. vicentina (Samp.) Mart.-Laborde. The taxon was recorded as 'preliminary accepted' in Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) which currently forms the taxonomic core of the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean (Kell et al. 2005) for the Brassicaceae family. However, in a recent update of Euro+Med PlantBase, Marhold (2011) reduced the taxon to subspecific level. This assessment therefore relates to the subspecies, D. siifolia ssp. vicentina but since the taxon is recognized at species level in the EU Habitats Directive, the assessment is valid for publication in the European Red List.
Diplotaxis ibicensis (Pau) Gómez-Campo is a wild relative of brassica crops as well as being related to cultivated perennial wall rocket, D. tenuifolia (L.) DC.
The Plant List (2010) treat it as a synonym of Centaurium chloodes ssp. somedanum (Laínz) Romero.

Allium grosii Font Quer is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Gentianella anglica is considered one of the few endemic plants of Great Britain. However, the taxonomic status of this species is still uncertain. It is not clear whether G. anglica is a species or whether it is part of the Gentianella amarella aggregate (Wilson 2009). Taxonomic research is currently underway.
The World Checklist of Selected Plant Families treats this taxon as a synonym of Clinopodium taygeteum (P.H.Davis) Bräuchler (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010).
Dianthus cintranus ssp. cintranus may have been confused with Dianthus gaditanus, in Spain (Cadiz) (Castroviejo et al. 1990).
It might be a synonym of Centaurea herminii Rouy (Franco and Afonso 1984).

Traditionally, the species was considered most closely related to Carex distans and C. punctata, placed in section Spirostachyae. Recent molecular-systematic work by Escudero et al. (2008) however showed that C. cretica does not belong in that group and has other phylogenetic affinities.

This assessment refers to Veronica repens sensu stricto.
Populations in Spain (Sierra Nevada) previously assigned to V. repens nevadensis are now considered as a separate species V. nevadensis.
Populations in Morocco previously assigned to V. repens serpyllifolia are now considered as a separate species V. serpyllifolia, but this taxon is not aquatic.
This taxon may be the result of an introgression between Juncus articulatus and J. alpino-articulatus ex. alpinus.
Its conspecificity with Hauffenia sp. (Steffek and Grego 2008) is conceivable, therefore the Hauffenia group in the Carpathian region needs further study.
This species has been placed in the subgenus Raphica.

This newly described species will require further studies to confirm relationships with other species from this complex genus, as currently it is only known from shells and although fresh shells were collected, no living specimens have been.  M.seminiana, described by Boeters (2003) on the basis of specimens from interstitial waters from Majones river at Villareal de la Canal (Huesca, Spain), is the species that most closely resembles M.barrinae. Alba et al. (2007) suggest that the less stout and less conical appearance, with less convex whorls, and a smaller size (shorter length and lesser number of whorls), permit to clearly distinguish M.barrinae from M.servaini. The species that most closely resemble M.barrinae by the small size and moderately stout appearance are M.cocheti Boeters & Falkner, 2003, M.heideae Boeters & Falkner, 2003, and M.seminiana Boeters, 2003. Regarding the two French species (M.cocheti and M.heideae), besides ornamentation, M.barrinae can be distinguished from them by its longer length and greater number of whorls, the lesser convexity of whorls, and the greater number of lines above the aperture.

This newly described species will require further studies to confirm relationships with other species from this complex genus, as currently it is only known from shells and although fresh shells were collected, no living specimens have been.
This species was recently described in 2004.
The taxonomic status of this species is considered 'uncertain' by MolluscaBase (2022).

authority: Corbella, Alba, Tarruella Ruestes, Prate & Guillen Mestre, 2006
taxonomicNotes: This newly described species will require further studies to confirm relationships with other species from this complex genus, as currently it is only known from shells and although fresh shells were collected, no living specimens have been.

Galanthus ikariae is frequently confused with other green-leafed snowdrops, and particularly G. woronowii, which are often considered as constituting one species. While it is true that these species can often appear to be very alike, there should be no real reason for confusion. The inner perianth mark of G. ikariae is very large and bold, as stated above, and even when the mark is a similar shape to that of G. woronowii (see below) it still usually covers a larger area of the segment. Galanthus ikariae also has leaves that are dark matt-green, and not bright green like those of G. woronowii. A further means of telling these species apart is by looking at transverse sections of the leaves, as the leaf anatomy of each species is quite different.

When a leaf of G. ikariae is sectioned and examined under a microscope, large air-spaces are evident and the mesophyll cells (the cells making up the bulk of the leaf tissue) are loosely arranged with large spaces between them. The air-spaces can be clearly seen with either the naked eye or a x10 hand lens, when the leaf is cut in half with a knife or pair of scissors. The leaves of G. woronowii, and all other broad-, green-leafed snowdrops, do not display this feature, but instead the leaf-blade has very small air-spaces which are either invisible or barely discernible to the naked eye. As a rule-of-thumb test, it is possible to fit a dress-maker’s pin into the air-spaces of G. ikariae, with little or no difficulty. Molecular studies (Lledo et al. 2004) demonstrate that G. ikariae and G. woronowii are separate species.

Since its discovery on the island of Ikaria, G. ikariae has been collected from at least three other Aegean islands, including Andros, Naxos, and Skyros; further collections have also been made on Ikaria (Davis 1999, 2001; Lledo et al. 2004).

The Osmoderma species complex is here treated as five separate species (barnabita, eremita, cristinae, italica and lassallei), following Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). Distribution limits of these different forms remain poorly resolved, but for the purpose of these assessments we follow the approximate distribution limits outlined in Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). There is ongoing debate as to whether or not these forms constitute valid species, but for the purpose of this assessment we are assessing each form separately.

This species is often treated under the synonym Ononis hackelii, for example in the Annexes of the Habitats Directive or in Portugal (ICN 2006). But the accepted name is Ononis maweana Ball. according to ILDIS (2010).
According to Boyce (2008) Biarum davisii and B. marmarisense (= B. davisiii ssp. marmarisense) are separate species.

This taxon included two subspecies: Cheirolophus satarataënsis (Svent.) Holub ssp. satarataënsis and Cheirolophus satarataënsis (Svent.) Holub ssp. dariasi (Svent.) Kunk. The latter has been recognized as the different species Cheirolophus dariasi.

Cicer canariense A.Santos & G.P.Lewis (Santos Guerra and Lewis 1985) was sufficiently distinct to warrant the erection of the monospecific subgenus Stenophylloma A.Santos & G.P.Lewis, although van der Maesen et al. (2007) consider it a member of section Polycicer and as such it is a tertiary wild relative of cultivated chickpea.
Bromus interruptus (interrupted brome) almost certainly arose in the 19th century as a new species through a major and sudden genetic change (UK Biodiversity Group 1998).

Fritillaria rixii was described from altitudes 700-800 m from the mountains Kantili, Xiro and Pyxaria in northern Evvoia Island (Zaharof 1986). According to Zaharof (1986) and Zaharof-Pourpoutidi (19871987), Fritillaria rixii is clearly distinguished from Fritillaria euboeica by its taller habit, fewer and narrower leaves, shorter tepals and nectaries, shorter, less divided, and papillose style. On the other hand, Kamari (1996) argues that these characters fall within the range of variation of Fritillaria euboeica. Kamari (in Strid and Tan 1991) notes that there appears to be a continuous variation of these characters and Fritillaria rixii can be regarded as a poorly defined lower altitude ecotype of Fritillaria euboeica. This view is strengthened by the fact that plants with intermediate characters between the two species have been found at Pyxaria (Kamari, in Strid and Tan 1991, Kamari and Kalogeropoulos in Phitos et al. 2009). The plants found at low altitudes at Politika (Kalogeropoulos and Delipetrou 2009) have the characters of Fritillaria rixii.

Currently, the EURO+MED database and the WCSP accept Fritillaria rixii as a valid taxon, however until further further work is undertaken to confirm the identity of Fritillaria rixii, we include it within Fritillaria euboeica.

Crambe scoparia Svent. is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R.E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).
Records of this species from other regions of Spain (Balearic Islands, Murcia and Valencia) are considered to be potentially different species.

Sands et al. (2020) found specimens resembling T. valentinus (collected from near the type locality) to group with T. baeticus in molecular analyses. Earlier, and in contrast, Ramos (2014) found some degree of molecular differentiation between these species based on museum type material.

Until more material is studied through more extensive methods, the status of T. valentinus remains uncertain.
Plutonia atlantica was redescribed by Wiktor and Backeljau (1995).

Beta nana Boiss. & Heldr. is a secondary wild relative of cultivated beets, B. vulgaris L. ssp. vulgaris (leaf, garden, fodder and sugar beet groups) (classified in section Nanae Ulbrich) (Frese 2004).

Kadereit et al. (2006) analysed a representative sample of Beta species with 29 nuclear ribosomal ITS1 sequences, as well as four representatives of Hablitzieae as an outgroup and found B. nana to be closely related to species in Beta section Corollinae. They suggested merging Beta section Nanae into section Corollinae.

Brassica balearica Pers. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the brassica group; including broccoli, B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck, Brussels sprout, B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker, cabbage, B. oleracea var. capitata L., cauliflower, B. oleracea var. botrytis L., kale, B. oleracea var. viridis L., swede, B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb., turnip, B. rapa L. ssp. rapa, and oilseed rape, B. napus L. var. napus.

Brassica cadmea O.E. Schulz is a wild relative of a number of crops in the brassica group; including broccoli, B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck, Brussels sprout, B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker, cabbage, B. oleracea var. capitata L., cauliflower, B. oleracea var. botrytis L., kale, B. oleracea var. viridis L., swede, B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb., turnip, B. rapa L. ssp. rapa, and oilseed rape, B. napus L. var. napus.

Brassica rupestris Raf. is a wild relative of a number of crops in the brassica group; including broccoli, B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck, Brussels sprout, B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker, cabbage, B. oleracea var. capitata L., cauliflower, B. oleracea var. botrytis L., kale, B. oleracea var. viridis L., swede, B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb., turnip, B. rapa L. ssp. rapa, and oilseed rape, B. napus L. var. napus.

This assessment refers to B. rupestris sensu lato.

Brassica villosa Biv. is a wild relative of a number of crops in the brassica group; including broccoli, B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck, Brussels sprout, B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker, cabbage, B. oleracea var. capitata L., cauliflower, B. oleracea var. botrytis L., kale, B. oleracea var. viridis L., swede, B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb., turnip, B. rapa L. ssp. rapa, and oilseed rape, B. napus L. var. napus.

Latest revision was done by Schütt (1977). Schütt distinguishes C. achaicum achaicum and C. achaicum diplestes (Westerlund 1894) as distinct subspecies. According to MolluscaBase (2022), diplestes is possibly a distinct species and treats just coerulea A.J. Wagner 1897 and maxima A.J. Wagner 1897 as synonyms. Schütt's concept is based on shell morphology only, a modern revision, with genital morphology and molecular data is necessary. This assessment was made according to the MolluscaBase concept.
The latest revision of Cochlostoma was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this subgeneric division it belongs to the subgenus Turritus.

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Turritus.
According to Fauna Europaea, Cochlostoma eupleurum Westerlund, 1885 is its junior synonym.
The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Auritus Westerlund, 1883.

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Turritus.
In addition to the nominate form, MolluscaBase (2022) includes another subspecies in this species: C. braueri latestriatum (A.J. Wagner 1897). However, in the view of Soós (1913) latestriatum might be just an abnormally built C. elegans, and an ongoing revision of the subgenus Turritus has found the same (E. Zallot, unpublished). In this assessment, this concept was followed and only the C. braueri in the strict sense was assessed.

Alzona (1971) treats C. pinianum and C. agriotes as subspecies of C. gualfinense and C. crosseanum as the synonym of C. gualfinense pinianum. According to Fauna Europaea, Cochlostoma agriotes Westerlund 1879, C. gualfinensis De Stefani 1879 and C. pinianus De Stefani 1879 are synonyms of this species. MolluscaBase (2022) treats agriotes as the subspecies of crosseanum.
According to an ongoing revision of the subgenus Turritus, it seems reasonable to treat C. agriotes (syn. gualfinense) and C. crosseanum (possibly pinianum is a synonym) as two distinct species (Enrico Zallot, pers comm). Accordingly, the present assessment was performed for C. crosseanum sensu stricto.

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Turritus.
MolluscaBase (2022) lists seven valid subspecies for this species: C. e. imoschiense (A. J. Wagner, 1906); C. e. irregulare (A. J. Wagner, 1897); C. e. oostoma (Westerlund, 1883); C. e. simile (A. J. Wagner, 1897); C. e. spectabile (A. J. Wagner, 1897); C. e. tumidum (A. J. Wagner, 1897).
Although MolluscaBase (2022) includes latestriatum (A.J. Wagner 1897) under C. braueri, in the view of Soós (1913) it might be just an abnormally built C. elegans. An ongoing revision of the subgenus Turritus (E. Zallot, unpublished) has found that C. elegans is a morphologically variable species, and it is more reasonable to treat latestriatum and all the above mentioned subspecies as the synonyms of that. This assessment follows this concept.
Zallot et al. (2015) placed this taxon into subgenus Lovcenia (see also Zallot et al. 2018).
The latest revision was done by Schütt (1977). Its system is based on shell morphology only so a modern revision, based on genital morphology and molecular data is necessary.
The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Auritus Westerlund, 1883.

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Auritus Westerlund, 1883. According to Schütt (1977) and MolluscaBase (2022) it involves two subspecies, namely C. h. hellenicum Saint-Simon, 1869 and C. h. athenarum Saint-Simon, 1869. This concept is based on shell morphology only, and therefore a modern revision, based on genital morphology and molecular data is strongly needed.

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Auritus Westerlund, 1883.
In addition to the nominate form, Fehér (2004) and the MolluscaBase (2022) lists two further subspecies: C. hoyeri csikii Fehér, 2004 and C. hoyeri lillae Fehér, 2004. An ongoing study based on genital morphology and DNA markers, has revealed that hanswagneri Fehér, 2004 also belongs to this species, rather that to C. pinteri, where it was originally assigned (E. Zallot & Z. Fehér, unpublished). In this assessment, C. hoyeri was assessed in the way that it includes also hanswagneri.

MolluscaBase (2022) lists this as a taxon inquirendum (uncertain). According to Alzona (1971), this is synonym of C. septemspirale agardhi  (Pini, 1884) [which is in fact synonym of C. septemspirale] and the current expert opinion also supports this view (E. Zallot, personal communication). So until conclusive evidence is presented that this is a distinct species, it makes no sense to make a separate assessment in addition to the one for C. septemspirale.
The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Turritus.

The previous assessment was made under the assumption that cassiniacum (Saint Simon, 1878); sospes Westerlund, 1879, and also elongatum Paulucci 1879 are conspecific with montanum. In MolluscaBase (2022) cassiniacum is treated as the subspecies of montanum; sospes is treated as an uncertain species (taxon inquirendum) and elongatum is treated as a distinct species. According to an ongoing revision of the subgenus Turritus, it seems reasonable to treat all these four taxa as distinct species (Enrico Zallot, pers comm.). Accordingly, the present assessment was performed for C. montanum sensu stricto.
The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Turritus.

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Turritus. According to an ongoing revision of the subgenus Turritus, it seems very likely that subaiorum Schütt, 1977 is a synonym of pageti (E. Zallot, unpublished) and therefore, this assessment already followed this concvept.
The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Auritus Westerlund, 1883

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Eupomatias Wagner, 1897. According to MolluscaBase (2022) the positions of pachystoma and decipiens are uncertain (taxa inquirenda)

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Dalfreddia. According to MolluscaBase (2022) this species is comprised of three valid subspecies: Cochlostoma porroi porroi, C. porroi gredleri (Westerlund, 1879) and C. porroi stabilei (Pini, 1884). An ongoing genus revision, based on genital morphology and DNA markers, however, appears to support the idea that the latter two taxa should be considered as separate species (E. Zallot, personal communication, not yet published). Accordingly, in this assessment, only porroi in the narrower sense was addressed.

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Turritus. FaunaEuropaea listed apostata Westerlund, 1890; maltzani Westerlund, 1890 and perdix Westerlund, 1890 as synonyms of this species. In MolluscaBase (2022) all these three are listed as uncertain species (taxa inquirenda).
The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Turritus.

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Auritus Westerlund, 1883. According to MolluscaBase (2022) this species involves three subspecies: C. westerlundi westerlundi (Paulucci, 1879), C. westerlundi yapigium (Westerlund, 1885) and C. westerlundi dionysi (Paulucci, 1879). In contrast, Alzona (1971) distinguishes C. dionysyi and C. yapigium as separate species. An ongoing study based on genital morphology and DNA markers seems to support this latter view (E. Zallot, personal communication), therefore, in this assessment yapigium and dionysii were not taken into account only westerlundi in the strict sense.
The Lauriidae of the Azores are currently under revision.

Wollaston (1878) considered macilenta as a separate species, although he noted that it could be a variety of Leiostyla recta. Pilsbry (1922–6) and Waldén (1983) listed the taxa as a subspecies. Cameron and Cook (1999) treat this as a species rather than a subspecies. Seddon (2008) noted the there are differences in shell form and size, and given that the two taxa are present on different islands it seems to be grounds to maintain these two forms as different taxa.

Wollaston (1878) recognised two forms ‘rupestris’ and ‘arborea’, which are now separated as different species; L. sphinctostoma and L. arborea. Pilsbry (1922–6) noted that sphinctostoma as recorded was very variable, and he felt that there were sufficient differences to separate two further subspecies heterodon and simulator. Bank et al. (2002) and Seddon (2008) treated both as a separate species in their publications.
The Lauriidae of the Azores are currently under revision.
A synonym used for this species is Pupa pythiella Mousson 1872 (see the records for this taxon in Wollaston 1878).
The Lauriidae of the Azores are currently under revision.
The taxonomy of the Azores-graylings is still under debate. At this moment only H. miguelensis is considered a separate species.

Originally placed by Rolán (1993), as part of Alzoniella pyrenaica. The species has similar conchological characters, but differs anatomically in characters of the bursa copulatrix and the receptaculum (Arconada et al. 2007).

Falniowski et al. 2009 suggest a wider distribution but their specimens were collected from Rhodopes Mts and at much lower altitude in Stara Planina Mts. Authors found very close genetic relationships between these Bythinella populations studied, but most importantly they did not compare their materials with specimens from the type locality. So belonging to the B. hansboetersi of these materials is doubtful. Also, they obviously have differences in their anatomy.

This species has not been redefined since originally collected by Clessin, until recent work by Gloer and Beran (2009) confirmed that the taxon differs from Bithynia tentaculata and Bithynia mostarensis.
This species is recently described and separated from the widespread species, B. tentaculata. There may be more records for this species once older records of B. tentaculata are examined.

Schutt (1988) suggested that it was not a valid species, but a synonym of B. tentaculata (Gloer & Maassen, 2009). Schutt (1988) designated a lectotype: 4.5 whorls, shell height 4.6 mm, shell width 3.1 mm, and identified this species as a juvenile of Bithynia tentaculata.

According to Gloer and Maassen (2009), Beriozkina et al. (1995: 36, Fig. 5a) illustrated Bithynia majewskyi from the Rostov Region with measurements: shell height 6.6 mm, width 4.6 mm, while Anistratenko and Stadnichenko (1995: 150) illustrated quite a different looking species with the measurements: shell height 5.3 mm and width 4.2 mm, whereas in their description they gave the measurements: shell height 4–4.5 mm, width 3–3.5 mm. Gloer and Maassen (2009) commented that the identity of the species used for their description of Bithynia majewskyi is questionable, as is their range description “Sicily, Balkan peninsula, shores of northern part of the Black and Azov seas and Caspian Sea”. In addition, Beriozkina et al. (1995: 35) mentioned Bythinia hellenica Kobelt, 1892 as a younger synonym of B. majewskyi, but the syntypes of B. hellenica, studied by Gloer (cited in Gloer and Maasse 2009), look distinct from B. majewskyi. If Schutt (1988) and Gloer and Maassen (2009) are correct, in their views that  B. majewskyi is a younger synonym of B. tentaculata, then Gloer and Maassen (2009) comment that the genus Paraelona has no type species and is not a valid genus name.  However at present it is still listed as a valid species pending further taxonomic research in the region.
The previous assessment was still based on the assumption that B. montenegrina and B. radomani are separate species.
The species has been recently described by Gittenberger (2008), based on 15 individuals.

According to AnimalBase Project Group (2010), Bodon and Cianfanelli (2008) published a very accurate study, but unfortunately missed to analyse the degree of variation in the thickness of the cervical callus in the south of Italy and Dalmatia. It seems that some Croatian specimens of P. elisabethae have a broader cervical callus, like the Italian population.

According to the pictures and description, this species appears to be very similar to H. modesta. However, this species is described from a locality far away, but also on the island of Tenerife. This case requires additional investigation.

This species has been recently described by Ruiz et al. (2009). According to these authors, the main feature characterizing the shell of O. mariae is the relation between the umbilicus and the shell diameter (1/8), the smallest in the Oestophora Iberian group in common with O. granesae (Arrébola 1998). Considering this, even the presence of the palatal tooth and the slight enlargement of the basal edge, are not comparable with the teeth of O. barbula (nor with the tooth of O. barbella), the only Iberian Oestopohora species with this kind of modifications on the aperture. Small morphological differences (including the relation umbilicus/shell diameter aforementioned) and biogeographical issues also distinguish this species from other North African's Oestophora. However, further studies (molecular, anatomical, etc.) must confirm the identity of all of them.

The specimens of this species living in the Insel Pobre (Cabrera Archipelago) have been classified as a different subspecies (Xerocrassa ferreri pobrensis Gasull 1964). The other subpopulations belong to the nominal subspecies.
See Triantis et al. (2004).

This species has been described by Ruiz, Arrébola y Puente (2009). According to these authors, O. calpeana, O. dorotheae and O. prietoi, the three Oestophora species with keeled shells cited in the Iberian Peninsula, can be differentiated as follow: 
- The shell periphery has a pronounced, acute/sharp and upward-reflected keel with a sinus inside. The 6 1/2 to 7 whorls are convex except the last two that are flatted. The diameter is 13 to 17 mm (data according to Ortiz de Zárate, 1962)........................................................... O. dorotheae

- The shell periphery has a pronounced, acute/sharp (not reflected) keel and lacks an internal sinus. The 6 3/4 to 7 whorls are convex except the last two that are practically flatted. The aperture is clearly wider than tall. The diameter is 10.4 to 11.4 mm...........................................O. calpeana

- The shell periphery has a clear and more or less blunt keel with neither reflection nor sinus inside. All the 5 1/2 - 6 1/4 whorls are convex. The aperture is semilunar shaped and a little wider than tall. The diameter is 9.5 to 13 mm.....……........................................…..…….. O. prietoi

Allium aethusanum Garbari is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).
It is a recently described species.
Lactuca palmensis Bolle is a wild relative of lettuce, L. sativa L.

Allium hymettium Boiss. & Heldr. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

This species was described by Arrébola et al. (2006) as Hatumia pseudogasulli. Martinez-Ortí et al. (2008) concluded that Helix zapateri Hidalgo, 1970 must be considered as a valid species and affiliated to Hatumia with H. pseudogasulli being a junior synonym of H. zapateri.

Allium pilosum Sibth. & Sm. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium bornmuelleri Hayek is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the Allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh Onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium corsicum Jauzein, J.-M. Tison, Deschåtres & H.Coudec is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.). This species was described in 2002 (Jauzein et al. 2002).
Avena canariensis Baum & al. is a tertiary wild relative of oats, Avena sativa L. and A. byzantina K. Koch. (Maxted et al. in prep.).

Allium tardans Greuter & Zahar. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium favosum Zahar. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).
Lactuca alpestris (Gand.) Rech. f. is a tertiary wild relative of lettuce, L. sativa L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).
Lactuca longidentata Moris ex DC. is a tertiary wild relative of lettuce, L. sativa L. (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).
Malus crescimannoi Raimondo is a wild relative of apple, Malus domestica Borkh. It is a preliminary accepted species in Euro+Med PlantBase (Kurtto 2009).

Allium circinnatum Sieber is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.). According to Turland et al. (1993), there are two subspecies: A. circinnatum ssp. circinnatum Sieber (endemic to Crete) and A. circinnatum ssp. peloponnesiacum Tzanoud. which occurs in southern Greece—with a suspected population near the coast of southwestern Turkey (Fielding and Turland 2005). However, as Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) does not recognize ssp. peloponnesiacum, this assessment  is only for the Cretan population, ssp. circinnatum.

Allium macedonicum Zahar. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium obtusiflorum DC. is a tertiary wild relative of and potential gene donor to a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium heldreichii Boiss. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium melananthum Coincy is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium parnassicum (Boiss.) Halácsy is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium lojaconoi Brullo, Lanfr. & Pavone is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).
Daucus halophilus Brot. is considered in some taxonomic treatments as a subspecies of D. carota (D. carota ssp. halophilus (Brot) A. Pujadas). The taxon is closely related to carrot, D. carota L.
L. singularis Wilmott. is a wild relative of lettuce, L. sativa L.

The nomenclatural status of the species should be reconsidered (see Brullo et al. 2010) who commented that the characters of this species are well within the bounds of A. permixtum, and proposed to include both A. phthioticum and A. breviradium as synonyms of A. permixtum). For this assessment, the Annotated Checklist of Greek Flora (Dimopoulous et al. 2013) is followed.

WCSP (2018) considers Allium breviradium (Halácsy) Stearn (and Allium neapolitanum var. breviradiatum Halácsy to be synonyms of this species.

Allium kermesinum Rchb. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium insubricum Boiss. & Reut. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium integerrimum is a doubtful taxon and may belong to Allium sphaerocephalon subsp. sphaerocephalon (P. Delipetrou and I. Bazos pers. comm. 2015).

Allium integerrimum Zahar. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the Allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

The considered 'unplaced' by WCSP (2015) and not found in Euro+Med (2014).

Allium incensiodorum Radić is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium lopadusanum Bartolo, Brullo & Pavone is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.). It shows some relationships with A. lojaconoi from the Maltese Islands and belongs to Allium sect. Brevispatha (Bartolo et al. 1986).

Allium chrysonemum Stearn is included as an accepted taxon in Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) and is recognized by Govaerts et al. (2005–2007). However, according to Spanish experts present at a European CWR Red List workshop held in April 2010, the species is a synonym of A. rouyi. The taxonomic status of this species therefore requires clarification. The species is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium luteolum Halácsy is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium lehmannii (Lojac.) Gillett is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium horvatii was described as a local endemic of exposed saline maritime rocks (elev. 3-350 m asl) of Krk Island, Croatia. Seregin et al. (2015) failed to find any consistent characters to separate A. horvatii from A. saxatile ssp. tergestinum, which is known to occur all around the Adriatic coast and no genetic variation was detected within the Adriatic entity from central Italy to Montenegro. They therefore recognized the westernmost entity of the A. saxatile group as a single species, with A. horvatii is its oldest valid name.

Patellifolia webbiana (Moq.) A.J. Scott, Ford-Lloyd & J.T. Williams is a tertiary wild relative of cultivated beets, B. vulgaris L. ssp. vulgaris (leaf, garden, fodder and sugar beet groups). The species was previously classified in Beta section Procumbentes Ulbrich as Beta webbiana Moq., but was later re-classified. Wagner et al. (1989) and Jung et al. (1993) suggested that P. procumbens and P. webbiana might not be different species, while more recently, Thulin et al. (2010) have proposed that all members of the Patellifolia clade are treated as a single variable species, P. procumbens.

Allium palentinum Losa & P. Monts. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).

Allium pyrenaicum Costa & Vayr. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.).
Pyrus vallis-demonis is a wild relative of pear, P. communis L. subsp. communis. It is a preliminary accepted species in Euro+Med PlantBase (Kurtto 2009).
