The Canary Brimstone used to be considered a subspecies of the Cleopatra (G. cleopatra).
Euchloe grancanariensis was formerly considered a subspecies of the Green-striped White (E. belemia).
Thymelicus christi was formerly considered a subspecies of the Lulworth Skipper (T. acteon).

Euchloe eversi was considered a subspecies of the Green-striped White (E. belemia). Based on studies in molecular biology, it has been separated from the nominate species (Back et al. 2008) , but recent studies put this conclusion again under discussion (Suarez et al. 2009).
This butterfly used to be considered a subspecies of the Furry Blue (P. dolus), but there is a clear difference in the number of chromosomes of each species.
Was in the IUCN Red List from 1996 to 2006 incorrectly spelt as Platyla maaseni.
This species was previously described as Acicula (Platyla) orthostoma.
Davis (1978) considered that this species is only a local variant of L. aquatica. This approach is followed by The Flora of Greece Web (Dimopoulos et al. 2021).

Prelli (2001) presents detailed and informative argument for the inclusion of Isoetes brochonii within I. lacustris, although Prada and Rolleri (2005) claim to have demonstrated that it is a good species.

The main taxonomic issue is whether Motelay’s type is dodecaploid – that is can the cytologically distinct allopolyploid Pyrenean plant recorded by Taylor and Hickey (1992) and subsequently morphologically studied by Prada and Rolleri (2003) be identified with Motelay’s plant.

Rorippa valdes-bermejoi (Castrov.) Mart.-Laborde & Castrov. is a wild relative of watercress, Nasturtium officinale W.T. Aiton and N. microphyllum Boenn. ex Rchb.

It is possible that this species is conspecific with R. africana Maire, but but there are differences in the leaves and fruits between the species. Further research is needed to clarify this.
This newly described species was discovered in 2005. It is the single representative of the family Symphytognathidae in Europe with its closest relatives occurring in Cote D’Ivoire.
Lepidium cardamines L. is a wild relative of brassica crops and garden cress, L. sativum L.
Asparagus plocamoides Svent. is a wild relative of asparagus, A. officinalis L.

Crambe gomerae H. Christ is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R. E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).

According to the last revision of the genus (Prina and Martinez-Laborde 2008), two subspecies have been recognized: ssp. gomerae and ssp. hirsuta Prina.

Lepidium ramburei Boiss. is included as an accepted taxon in Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) which forms the taxonomic core of the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean (Kell et al. 2005) for the Brassicaceae family.  However, Euro+Med PlantBase has recently been updated for the Brassicaceae family and the taxon is now considered to be a synonym of L. villarsii ssp. anticarium (Valdés Berm. & G. López) Hern.-Berm. (Marhold 2011) (although the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean has not yet been updated in line with this change). The Plant List (2010) (based on data derived from the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families in review) also records the taxon as a synonym of Lepidium villarsii ssp. anticarium and according to Spanish experts present at a European CWR Red List workshop held in April 2010, the taxon is a synonym of L. villarsii.

Tutin et al. (1964) included it as an accepted species but within the L. villarsii Gren & Godron taxon concept, noting that "plants up to 22 cm, with leaves glabrous or almost so, pedicels 5–6 mm in fruit and silicula about 7x6 mm, from S.E. Spain, are probably L. ramburei Boiss, Voy. Bot. Midi Esp. 2: 52 (1839) and may represent a third subspecies".

The taxon is a wild relative of brassica crops and garden cress, L. sativum L.
Asparagus fallax Svent. is a wild relative of asparagus, A. officinalis L.

Strid (1986) wrote that the status of Barbarea conferta Boiss. & Heldr. is uncertain. It was described from Mt. Killini and "differs from B. vulgaris in the raceme scarcely elongating in fruit, and pedicels 2–4 mm" (Strid 1986).

If a valid taxon, it is a wild relative of the cultivated Barbarea species, B. verna (Mill.) Asch. (land cress), and B. vulgaris R. Br. (winter cress).

Isatis vermia Papan. is a wild relative of brassica crops and of dyer's woad, I. tinctoria L. Strid (1986) notes that I. vermia is related to the widespread and variable species, I. tinctoria, but differs in the flowering period and a combination of morphological characters. This is reflected by Euro+Med PlantBase (2006), who note that this is a doubtful species, close to I. tinctoria, and is therefore a preliminary accepted species.

Crambe microcarpa A. Santos is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R. E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).

Crambe strigosa L'Her. is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R. E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).

Elymus alopex B. Salomon is a tertiary wild relative of bread wheat, Triticum aestivum L. ssp. aestivum, durum wheat, T. turgidum ssp. durum (Desf.) Husn., and a number of other cultivated wheats; including emmer wheat, T. turgidum ssp. dicoccon (Schrank) Thell., einkorn wheat, T. monococcum L. ssp. monococcum, spelt, T. aestivum ssp. spelta (L.) Thell., and sanduri wheat, T. timopheevii (Zhuk.) Zhuk. ssp. timopheevii.

E. alopex was previously regarded as E. caninus, but according to Salomon (2005) the Icelandic population should be regarded as a separate species.
Medicago strasseri Greuter et al. belongs to section Dendrotelis, and is a tertiary wild relative of cultivated alfalfa, M. sativa L. subsp. sativa (GRIN 2010).

Barbarea bosniaca Murb. is a wild relative of the cultivated Barbarea species, B. verna (Mill.) Asch. (land cress), and B. vulgaris R. Br. (winter cress). It is closely related to Barbarea sicula C. Presl. and B. intermedia Boreau.

There is some uncertainty about the validity of Barbarea macrophylla (Halácsy) Halácsy. It was described in 1899 from Pilion in eastern Greece but according to Tutin et al. (1964) and Strid (1986) is probably only a variant of B. vulgaris.

If a valid taxon, it is a wild relative of the cultivated Barbarea species, B. verna (Mill.) Asch. (land cress), and B. vulgaris R. Br. (winter cress).

Lepidium carrerasii J.J. Rodr. is a preliminary accepted species in Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) which forms the taxonomic core of the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean (Kell et al. 2005) for the Brassicaceae family. However, Euro+Med PlantBase has recently been updated for the Brassicaceae family and the taxon is now considered to be a synonym of L. spinosum Ard. (Marhold 2011) (although the CWR Catalogue for Europe and the Mediterranean has not yet been updated in line with this change). Tutin et al. (1964) and The Plant List (2010) (based on data from the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families in review) also record the taxon as a synonym of L. spinosum.

The taxon is a wild relative of brassica crops and of garden cress, L. sativum L.
Asparagus arborescens Schult. & Schult. f. is a wild relative of asparagus, A. officinalis L.
Diplotaxis gomez-campoi Mart.-Laborde is a wild relative of brassica crops as well as being related to cultivated perennial wall rocket, D. tenuifolia (L.) DC.

Crambe scaberrima Bramwell is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R. E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).

Medicago bondevii Kouharov belongs to the section Spirocarpos, and the subsection Pachyspireae and is a secondary wild relative of the cultivated barrel medic (M. truncatula), and a tertiary wild relative of alfalfa (M. sativa) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).
Diplotaxis ilorcitana (Sennen) Aedo, Mart.-Laborde & Muñoz Garm. is a wild relative of brassica crops as well as being related to cultivated perennial wall rocket, D. tenuifolia (L.) DC.

Crambe pritzelii Bolle is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R. E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).

Cicer graecum Orph. belongs to the family Fabaceae, subfamily Faboideae, and section Polycicer. It is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated chick pea, C. arietinum (van der Maesen et al. 2007, USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).
Medicago heyniana Greuter belongs to the section Heynianae, and is a tertiary wild relative of cultivated alfalfa, M. sativa L. subsp. sativa (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2010).

Medicago heterocarpa Spach is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated crop alfalfa, M. sativa ssp. sativa. Association Tela Botanica (2000) and Al-Atawneh et al. (2009) consider this as a synonym of M. murex which has a wider distribution and which is also an accepted species in Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) and in our list for assessment.

Dianthus moriasianus belongs to the complex of D. sylvestris Wulfen and shows similarities with D. sardous, from which it is differentiated by the ecology and some morphological characters (Bacchetta et al. 2010). Dianthus morisianus was considered as subspecies of  D. siculus (Arrigoni 2005), but is now accepted as a separate species (Bacchetta et al. 2010).

"At least 25" subspecies have been described (Speybroeck et al. 2016), but the only morphological and genetic study of diversity across the species' entire range concluded that variation is incongruent with traditional subspecific divisions (Pérez-Cembranos et al. 2020). These authors elected not to revise the subspecific taxonomy of this species, but propose recognizing every isolated population as an Evolutionarily Significant Unit.

Individual islet subpopulations are likely to represent Evolutionarily Significant Units (despite shallow genetic divergence; Rodriguez et al. 2013), and as many as 28 morphological subspecies have been proposed (Salvador et al. 2015, Rodriguez et al. 2013).

[Rodriguez et al. 2013 reference not attached]

Vicia capreolata Lowe is a tertiary wild relative of bitter vetch (V. ervilia (L.) Willd.) and Winter vetch (V. villosa Roth.) and more remotely a number of other cultivated vetches faba bean (V. faba L.), narbon bean (V. narbonensis L.), Hungarian vetch (V. pannonica Crantz and common vetch (V. sativa L.).

Vicia costae A. Hansen is a tertiary wild relative of bitter vetch (V. ervilia (L.) Willd.) and winter vetch (V. villosa Roth.) and more remotely a number of other cultivated vetches: faba bean (V. faba L.), narbon bean (V. narbonensis L.), Hungarian vetch (V. pannonica Crantz) and common vetch (V. sativa L.).

Vicia ferreirensis Goyder is a tertiary wild relative of bitter vetch (V. ervilia (L.) Willd.) and Winter vetch (V. villosa Roth.) and more remotely a number of other cultivated vetches faba bean (V. faba L.), narbon bean (V. narbonensis L.), Hungarian vetch (V. pannonica Crantz and common vetch (V. sativa L.).
The genus Sinapidendron is endemic to Madeira and is part of the brassica complex.

The genus Sinapidendron is endemic to Madeira and is part of the brassica complex. Two subspecies of S. frutescens (Sol) Lowe are recognized: S. frutescens ssp. frutescens and S. frutescens ssp. succulentum (Lowe) Rustan.

Crambe feuillei A. Santos is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R. E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).

The species was previously classified as C. strigosa but was re-classified in a revision of the genus published in 2008 (Prina and Martinez-Laborde 2008).

Crambe wildpretii Prina & Bramwell is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R. E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).

The species was recently described and it is possible that earlier records of C. gomerae relate to C. wildpretii.

Crambe tamadabensis Prina & Marrero Rodr. is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R.E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).

The species was previously classified as C. pritzelii but was re-classified by Prina and Marrero (2001).

Crambe gigantea Bramwell is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R.E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).

This species was originally classified as C. strigosa var. gigantea. This variety was later published as C. gigantea but the name was not valid because it was a homonym of another taxon. The taxon was therefore renamed by Bramwell as C. santosii (A. Santos Guerra pers. comm. 2010).
The specific name was incorrectly spelt in Red Lists prior to 2008 as parvani. Should possibly be recognized at specific level.

This species  lies within one of the groups of subterranean snails that need researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic status and the species limits. A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology pending the results for full analysis for the group. However, given the characteristic shell, this is undoubtedly a valid species.

This species is regarded as a synonym of the congener Knipowitschia panizzae (Verga 1841) by some authorities based on a molecular study by Thacker et al. (2018). However, the authors in fact do not explicitly synonymise the two species, therefore they are retained separately here.
Previously this species was included within Squalius pyrenaicus (Günther, 1868), but it is now recognised as a separate species (Doadrio et al. 2007).
This species was included in the genus Aphanius prior to 2020.
May have been transferred to the genus Typhlocypris.
May have been transferred to the genus Typhlocypris.
May have been transferred to the genus Typhlocypris.

Iberus is an Iberian Peninsula endemic genus, that comprised 20 morphospecies of uncertain validity (traditional classifications conflicted with each other mostly in the number of species), some of them occupying a very restricted geographical area. They were characterized mostly on the basis of the shell morphology because the reproductive system shows no diagnostic features at the specific level (Puente 1994, Arrébola 1995). Recently, Elejalde, Madeira, Arrébola et al. (2008) have studied partial DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes (COI and 16S rRNA) from different specimens of Iberus, to test the validity of the described morphospecies of the genus. The analysis have revealed 11 main phylogroups, being genetically unique lineages that are allopatrically distributed and considered to have full species status. One of them is I. gualtieranus, composed by three subspecies:  I.g. gualtieranus, I.g. mariae and I.g. ornatissimus. The first has a keeled and flattened shell with marked ornamentation of spiral and radial costulae (synapomorphy), while the other two show rounded and globose shells with soft ornamentation. I.g. mariae and I.g. ornatissimus have distinct and very restricted range and their shells clearly differ one from another. Both taxa were phylogenetically very closely related to I. g. gualtieranus, in contrast with the opinion of other authors who considered them to be more closely related to I. alonensis s.l., on the basis of shell morphology (Alonso and Ibáñez 1981).

Iberus is an Iberian Peninsula endemic genus, that comprises 20 species-level taxa of uncertain validity (traditional classifications are in conflict with each other mostly in the number of species), some of them occupying a very restricted geographical area. These species were characterized mostly on the basis of the shell morphology because the reproductive system showed no diagnostic features at the specific level (Puente 1994, Arrébola 1995).

Recently, Elejalde et al. (2008), using mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) data (COI and 16S rRNA), were able to validate the observed phylogenetic taxa within the complex by means of the analysis of specimens of the different species, together with the study of topotypes (i.e. specimen taken from the type locality of that species). The analysis have revealed 11 main phylogroups, being genetically unique lineages that are allopatrically distributed and considered to have full species status. One of them, I. alonensis s. str., comprises all the Iberus living in the half eastern Iberian Peninsula except in Andalusia and in the southern part of the Murcia provinces, where I. carthaginiensis and two additional un-nominated and not described yet taxa of the alonensis form were identified. This designation was in agreement with Martínez-Ortí et al. (2005).

Iberus is an Iberian Peninsula endemic genus, that comprised 20 morphospecies of uncertain validity (traditional classifications conflicted with each other mostly in the number of species), some of them occupying a very restricted geographical area. They were characterized mostly on the basis of the shell morphology because the reproductive system shows no diagnostic features at the specific level (Puente 1994, Arrébola 1995). Recently, Elejalde et al. (2008) have studied partial DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes (COI and 16S rRNA) from different specimens of Iberus, to test the validity of the described morphospecies of the genus. The analysis have revealed 11 main phylogroups, being genetically unique lineages that are allopatrically distributed and considered to have full species status. One of them is I. campesinus.

Iberus is an Iberian Peninsula endemic genus, that comprised 20 morphospecies of uncertain validity (traditional classifications conflicted with each other mostly in the number of species), some of them occupying a very restricted geographical area. They were characterized mostly on the basis of the shell morphology because the reproductive system shows no diagnostic features at the specific level (Puente 1994, Arrébola 1995). Recently, Elejalde, Madeira, Arrébola, Muñoz & Gomez-Moliner (2008) have studied partial DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes (COI and 16S rRNA) from different specimens of Iberus, to test the validity of the described morphospecies of the genus. The analysis have revealed 11 main phylogroups, being genetically unique lineages that are allopatrically distributed and considered to have full species status. One of them is I. carthaginiensis.

Iberus is an Iberian Peninsula endemic genus, that comprised 20 morphospecies of uncertain validity (traditional classifications conflicted with each other mostly in the number of species), some of them occupying a very restricted geographical area. They were characterized mostly on the basis of the shell morphology because the reproductive system shows no diagnostic features at the specific level (Puente 1994, Arrébola 1995). Recently, Elejalde, Madeira, Arrébola, Muñoz and Gomez-Moliner (2008) have studied partial DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes (COI and 16S rRNA) from different specimens of Iberus, to test the validity of the described morphospecies of the genus. The analysis have revealed 11 main phylogroups, being genetically unique lineages that are allopatrically distributed and considered to have full species status. One of them is I. guiraoanus, mainly characterized by its medium-sized umbilicated shells although the mentioned authors do not reject the possibility two cryptic species could exist in the guiraoanus clade.

Iberus is an Iberian Peninsula endemic genus, that comprised 20 morphospecies of uncertain validity (traditional classifications conflicted with each other mostly in the number of species), some of them occupying a very restricted geographical area. They were characterized mostly on the basis of the shell morphology because the reproductive system shows no diagnostic features at the specific level (Puente, 1994; Arrébola, 1995). Recently, Elejalde, Madeira, Arrébola, Muñoz & Gomez-Moliner (2008) have studied partial DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes (COI and 16S rRNA) from different specimens of Iberus, to test the validity of the described morphospecies of the genus. The analysis have revealed 11 main phylogroups, being genetically unique lineages that are allopatrically distributed and considered to have full species status. One of them is I. angustatus, characterized by the presence of a narrow umbilicus in the shell.

Iberus is an Iberian Peninsula endemic genus, that comprised 20 morphospecies of uncertain validity (traditional classifications conflicted with each other mostly in the number of species), some of them occupying a very restricted geographical area. They were characterized mostly on the basis of the shell morphology because the reproductive system shows no diagnostic features at the specific level (Puente 1994, Arrébola 1995). Recently, Elejalde, Madeira, Arrébola, Muñoz and Gomez-Moliner (2008) have studied partial DNA sequences of two mitochondrial genes (COI and 16S rRNA) from different specimens of Iberus, to test the validity of the described morphospecies of the genus. The analysis have revealed 11 main phylogroups, being genetically unique lineages that are allopatrically distributed and considered to have full species status. One of them is I. ortizi. Previously, I. ortizi had been considered a minor form of  I. alcarazanus (Ortiz de Zárate in García San Nicolás 1957) although García San Nicolás (1957) assigned it a subspecific status: I. alcarazanus ortizi. However, the data provided by a recent taxonomic revision (Martínez-Ortí et al. 2004) indicate that I. alcarazanus should be considered as a synonym of I. alonensis. Consequently, I. ortizi is a valid name (Elejalde et al. 2008).
Previously in genus Chondrula, the species was then placed in genus Mastus, and subsequently placed in genus Eubrephulus A.J. Wagner, 1928 (MolluscaBase 2022).

The original type locality cited by Ortiz de Zárate (1962) is an error (Corbellá and Guillén 2002).

Corbellá and Guillén (2002) considered the species to belong to the genus Gasullia while Arrébola et al. (2006) included it in the new genus Hatumia as Hatumia cobosi (with H. zapateri and H. riffensis).

Following current placement in MolluscaBase (2022), the species is placed in genus Gasullia.
Gymnocephalus ambriaelacus is closely related to Gymnoceohalus baloni and it might be even a synonym of this species.

The taxonomic status of this species, and hence it's range, is uncertain. Vinarski (2003) describes how Lymnaea vulnerata was once regarded as a distinct variety within the polymorphic species Lymnaea palustris (Müller 1774). Research on this group is showing that there are cryptic species lying within the Lymnaeidae, and hence the species group requires further research.

Various authors, such as Kruglov and Starobogatov (1986)  have added confusion, through incorrectly synonymising the species with Catascopia terebra (previously known as G. occulta) and Beran (2002) referring to L. vulnerata as Stagnicola fuscus. Jackiewicz  (1998) examined material from the type locality in Croatia, and gave data on the anatomy, noting that the species should not be synonymised with Stagnicola fuscus. Later Vinarski and Gloer (2008) noted that the anatomy was certainly different to Catascopia terebra and hence the species could not be listed as a synonym of this species.

In the opinion of Vinarski (2003), the taxonomic position of L. vulnerata has to be investigated further.

DNA phylogenetic studies show that P. daanidentata is a monophyletic lineage, very closely related to P. cantabrica. Its specific or subspecific status requires further research  (Elejalde et al. 2009).
3D geometric morphometric studies undoubtedly supports the validity of P. daanidentata as a separated species (Caro et al. (2019).

Prieto (1991) considered two subspecies: P. navasi navasi and P. navasi sylvatica with the latter living within forests and characterized by its greater size. Nevertheless, DNA sequenciation studies (Elejalde et al. 2009) showed that both morphs are only ecotypes, and subspecific categories should not be considered.
The status of this species has been confirmed by phylogenetic studies based on DNA sequences (Elejalde et al. 2009).

DNA sequences indicate that Pyrenaearia velascoi is closely related to P. carascalensis, but it constitutes a proper genetic lineage restricted to the Basque Country mountains. Although Altonaga et al. (1994) indicated that P. velascoi could be subdivided into two or three subspecies, molecular studies do not support subspecific taxa.

Bythinella bicarinata was described as a species endemic to its type locality. Despite its conspicuous bicarinate shell (which gives the species its name), it is considered conspecific with B. lalindei that lives nearby, as well as B. pujolensis and B. moulinsi (Bichain 2007, based on molecular data). Oddly enough, the species also clusters with Bythinella dunkeri from northern France.

This species is believed to be a good species, based on both shell morphology and genetics (Bichain et al. 2007, Benke et al 2009). Prie concluded that B. lancelevei can be synonymised with B. viridis based on the molecular analyses performed by Benke et al. (2009) and morphological evidence (Prie pers. comm. 2009).

According to Fauna Europaea this species is a synonym of Mastus grandis grandis (Mousson 1859). Nevertheless, according to Parmakelis (2003) and Parmakelis et al. (2005) this is a well separated species and thus here is treated as a separate species.

According to Fauna Europaea the taxon is a subspecies of Mastus grandis, i.e. M. g. giuricus (Westerlund 1901). However M. giuricus is a well-seperated species (see Parmakelis et al. 2005), and thus is treated as a separate species.

According to Fauna Europaea, the taxon is a subspecies of Mastus emarginatus, i.e. M. e. turgidus (Kobelt 1877). Nevertheless, according to Parmakelis et al. (2005) it  is a well-defined species of Mastus distributed in Karpathos and Kasos and most probably in Rhodes as well. Thus, it is treated as a separate species.
Xerocrassa grabusana is most similar to X. subvariegata (Hausdorf & Sauer 2009).

According to Fauna Europaea (Bank 2009) the species belongs to the genus Candidula Kobelt 1871, when previously it was assigned to genus Trochoidea. According to the Hausdorf and Sauer (2009) it should be included in Xerocrassa, i.e. Xerocrassa siphnica (Kobelt, 1883). The latter placement is adopted here, following MolluscaBase (2022).

This species was originally described by Alonso (1974) as a subspecies of Chondrina farinesii. Arrébola and Gómez (1998) consider that the shell features of Chondrina granatensis are different enough to justify its consideration as a separate species from the Chondrina farinesii complex. Kokshoorn and Gittenberger (2010) agree with the last authors.

Abida ateni was considered to be a subspecies of Abida secale by Fauna Europeae (Bank et al. 2006). However, here, we follow Kokshoorn and Gittenberger (2010) who consider them to be distinct species.

This species was never found back since its description. It had been considered a synonym of Monilearia caementitia (see Bank et al. 2002), but after check of the type specimens it has been raised to a species in its own rights (Fauna Europaea version 2010, http://www.faunaeur.org).

Until recently, the taxonomic status of this species had been unclear, and its provenance has been unclear (Bank et al. 2002). However, new investigations suggest that this taxon in fact is a member of the genus Monilearia (unpublished data, Ibanez, Alonso and Groh pers. comm. 2011).
This species was treated as a probable synonym of N. bertheloti (Bank et al. 2002), but recently raised to specific rank in Fauna Europaea.
Euphorbia lambii Svent. was considered endemic to the island of La Gomera, Spain. Its synonymy with Euphorbia bourgeauana has been confirmed.

See Bichain et al. (2007) and Benke et al. (2009) for a review of the current state of taxonomy in this group. Research is ongoing on the species relationships, as species limits based on  shell characters are insufficient to identify species in this group.

According to Gargominy and Ripken (2006), this is a distinct species and MolluscaBase (2022) follows this view. By contrast, Falkner et al. (2002) treats this as the synonym of Cochlostoma simrothi, which seems to be supported by az ongoing study of the subgenus Turritus (E. Zallot, pers. comm.). So until conclusive evidence is presented that this is a distinct species, it makes no sense to make a separate assessment in addition to the one for C. simrothi.

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Auritus Westerlund, 1883.
In the Fuchs collection, there were specimens from the type locality, labelled as "Auritus bischoffi", but this name has never been published.

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Auritus Westerlund, 1883. Originally, it was described with two further subspecies C. pinteri erossi Fehér, 2004 and C. pinteri hanswagneri Fehér, 2004. This view is followed by MolluscaBase (2022) too. However, recent molecular studies have revealed that hanswagneri belongs to C. hoyeri and not to C. pinteri (E. Zallot & Z. Fehér in preparation, yet unpublished). Therefore, in this assessment only the nominate form and C. pinteri erossi are considered.
Alzoniella (A.) somiedoensis differs from A. (A.) rolani (Boeters, 1986), known from Galicia and Portugal, by a rough, scaly surface of the protooconch (Rolan et al. 2009).
Synonym: Belgrandia gibba Draparnaud, 1805 [partim]. in Nobre (1930: 206). The species Belgrandia gibba refers to both Belgrandia silviae and Belgrandia lusitanica; see Rolan and Oliviera (2009).

authority: Arconada, B., Rolán, E. & Boeters, H.D. 2007
taxonomicNotes: Originally placed by Rolán (1993) as part of Alzoniella elliptica. The species has similar conchological (shell) characters, but differs anatomically in characters of the seminal receptacules (Arconada et al. 2007).

Belgrandia alcoaensis was considered as a subspecies by Haase (2000: 185) based on an examination of one shell (a paratype). Rolan and Oliveira (2009) have examined many specimens and consider it very different from the other Portuguese species due to the almost flat whorls, especially the last one, the prominent spiral cord and lack of any axial thickening.
This species was originally described as Suboestophora. Ruiz et al. (2009) studied the anatomy of reproductive system and conclude S. ebria belongs to Oestophora.
Often considered as a synonym of Squalius squalus.
This is a recently described species (Subai 2011).
This is a recently described species (Subai 2011).
This is a recently described species (Subai 2011).
This is a recently described species (Subai 2011).

The accepted name in Italy is Petagnea gussonii. Petagnaea saniculifolia is not listed in Euro+Med Plantbase (2006-2010), the International Plant Names Index (2010), or the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2011).
This species was listed as subspecies of I. gloubularis in Fauna Europea (Bank et al. 2006). but raised to a species by Arconada and Ramos (2006) after comparison work was done.
This new species is not listed in Fauna Europea (Bank et al. 2006).
This new species is not listed in Fauna Europea (Bank et al. 2006). Two subspecies were described I. henrici henrici (Córdoba populations) and I. henrici giennensis (Jaen populations).

The name of this species has been changed from Belgrandiella to Belgrandia by Boeters (2009).  The old name was Belgrandia dunalina, and it was assessed as Near Threatened. However, it was forming a different species concept (with a much wider distribution) - but there are still doubts on the taxonomy for this species.

Originally described as a "Valvata", named Arganiella exilis in the French list of protected species, the name has been changed to Heraultia by Bodon et al. (2001) and then to Heraultiella by Bodon et al. (2002).

This species was originally described as Oestophora (Suboestophora) tarraconensis altamirai, dedicated to Carlos Altimira. Martínez-Ortí (1999) proposed to correct this mistake by naming this species as S. altimirai.

Suboestophora altimirai was considered a subspecies of S. tarraconensis. Based on anatomical studies of the reproductive system, the taxon has been raised to the species level (Martínez-Ortí 1995).

The name has until recently been used for all Corsican species of Tacheocampylaea (for which 27 names have been published). Thus, literature has to be carefully monitored, to understand which species is actually meant.
A polytypic species.  Some variations may represent distinct species or subspecies.
A taxonomic review of the genus Trochulus spp. is underway by Gerhard Falkner and Ted von Proschwitz.

There are two subspecies: Trochulus oreinos oreinos, and T. oreinos scheerpeltzi Mikula, 1957. The latest molecular genetic studies have shown that they could perhaps be regarded as two separate species (Duda et al. 2011). For the time being, both subspüecies are assessed as a single species.

Although it is often possible to differentiate this species from X. zaharensis only using shell characteristics, a positive identification can only be determined by studying the reproductive system (Puente and Arrébola 1996).
Puente (1994) considers X. montserratensis and X. betulonensis two different species. Martínez-Ortí and Bros are working to clarify the taxonomic status.

Although it is often possible to differentiate this species from X. jimenensis using only shell characteristics, the identification requires the study of the reproductive system (Puente and Arrébola 1996).
The taxonomic validity of this species needs to be fully investigated, especially at the molecular level.

According to Gittenberger (1993), the similar Xerosecta species living in the southern half of the Iberian Peninsula (X. cespitum, X. promissa, X. reboudiana and X. adolfi) can be identified by some shell features. Puente (1994) and Arrébola (1995) indicated that sometimes reproductive system studies are required for an unambiguous identification.

There are is evidence that Barbus tyberinus might have a smaller range than previously considered. In the southern part of its the range, two groups of populations have been identified as potentially undescribed species previously included within B. tyberinus (Zaccara et al. 2019a, 2019b).

This species is one of many small spring-snails that can be most easily be identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system. Further data is required to determine distribution and status of populations, and the relationship between the populations of Alzoniella pyrenaica  and Alzoniella iberopyrenaica.

This species is one of many small spring-snails that can be most easily identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system. Originally, this species was found to be living with another spring snail Graziana lacheineri (Gloer 2002).

This species is one of many small spring-snails that can be most easily identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system. Shell characters are similar to those of Belgrandiella fuschi Boeters, 1970, B. wawrai  Haase, 1996 and B. mimula Haase, 1996, so distribution records based on shells alone are questionable (Gloer 2002, p. 109), although B. wawrai  Haase, 1996 and B. pelerei  Haase, 1994 are not found in thermal spring sites.
This is one of many small spring-snail species that can be most easily be identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system.
This species is one of many small spring-snails that can be most easily be identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system.
This species is one of many small spring-snails that can be most easily be identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system.

This is one of many small spring-snail species that can be most easily identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system. It is close in shell characters to Belgrandiella parreysi, the distribution records based on shells alone are therefore questionable (Gloer 2002).

One of many small spring-snail species that can be most easily be identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system.  It has been confused with Belgrandiella fuschi Boeters, 1970, so distribution records based on shells alone are questionable.

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to Rhabdotakra A. J. Wagner, 1897, which was raised to genus level. According to Alzona (1971), Cochlostoma insubricum Pini, 1877 and C. canestrinianum (Adami, 1886) are synonyms of this species.
This assessment only relates to the populations of Abies pinsapo var. pinsapo in southeastern Spain. Populations in Morocco are assessed under the name Abies pinsapo var. maroccana.

Prunus ramburii Boiss. is a wild relative of almond, P. dulcis (Mill.) D.A.Webb, peach and nectarine, P. persica (L.) Batsch, plum, P. domestica L., sloe, P. spinosa L. and sweet cherry, P. avium (L.) L.
Considered as a valid species following molecular analyses by Benke et al. (2009).
This is a valid species, confirmed by molecular analysis (Bichain et al. 2007).

This species is one of many small Hydrobids that can be most easily be identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system, however these species are in urgent need of a review incorporating conchological, anatomical and molecular characters in order to understand the relationships with other taxa (Haase et al. 2007).

This species  lies within one of the groups of subterranean snails that need researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic status and the species limits.  Bernasconi described B. bressanum diaphanoides, a taxon that exhibits an anatomy similar to B. bressanum, but has a shell similar to B. diaphanum. Falkner et al. (2002) raised B. b. diaphanoides to the species level.  

A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology pending the results for full analysis for the group.

This species is one of many small hydrobids that can be most easily be identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system, however these species are in urgent need of a review incorporating conchological characters, anatomical characters and molecular characters in order to understand the relationships with other taxa. According to Bichain et al. (2007), these populations in the north-eastern specimens listed as Bythinella compressa should now be classified with Bythinella reynesii, and as such is part of a species that is more widespread, however in Germany, at present it is still considered a valid species.

Several subspecies have been described in the south of France by Girardi (2002, 2003, 2009a,b; Girardi and Bertrand 2009). However, Bertrand (2004) considered that, in the state-of-the-art, B. diaphanum (sensu stricto) is limited to the southern parts of the Jura in eastern France. The genus Bythiospeum requires a global taxonomic revision.

Three of the eight former (Prié 2010) subspecies are retained within B. diaphanum (MolluscaBase 2022);
  • B. diaphanum luberonense Girardi, 2009 (Bythiospée du Luberon; Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur)
  • B. diaphanum meyrarguense Girardi, 2009 (Bythiospée de Meyrargues; Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur)
  • B. diaphanum regalonense Girardi, 2009 (Bythiospée du Régalon; Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur).

Whilst five former subspecies (Prié 2010) are now returned to their original species rank (MolluscaBase 2022);
  • B. diaphanum alpillense Girardi, 2009 accepted as Bythiospeum alpillense Girardi, 2009
  • B. diaphanum fernetense Girardi, 2009 accepted as Bythiospeum fernetense Girardi, 2009
  • B. diaphanum michaellensis  Girardi, 2002 accepted as Bythiospeum michaellense Girardi, 2002
  • B. diaphanum montbrunense Girardi, 2009 accepted as Bythiospeum montbrunense Girardi & Bertrand, 2009
  • B. diaphanum sarriansense Girardi, 2009 accepted as Bythiospeum sarriansense Girardi, 2009

Only the nominate subspecies Bythiospeum diaphanum diaphanum is being considered in this assessment, as the other subspecies are taxonomically doubtful and might not belong to this species.
This species is one of many small spring-snails that can most easily be identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system.

This species  lies within one of the groups of subterranean snails that need researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic status and the species limits. A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology pending the results for full analysis for the group.

This species lies within one of the groups of Hydrobids that is currently being researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic status and the species limits are doubted by some researchers. A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology, pending the results of the full analysis of group. This species has been placed in the genus Paladilhiopsis and Paladilhia.

This species is close to Bythiospeum heldii and may require anatomical data to be certain of the identity (Glöer 2002).

This species  lies within one of the groups of spring-snails that is currently being researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic status and the species limits are doubted by some researchers (Benke et al. 2009). A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology pending the results for full analysis for the group.

This species lies within one of the groups of spring-snails that is currently being researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic status and the species limits are doubted by some researchers (Benke et al. 2009). A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology, pending the results of the full analysis for the group.

This species lies within one of the groups of spring-snails that is currently being researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic status. The species limits are doubted by some researchers (Benke et al. 2009). A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology pending the results for the full analysis for the group.

Most of the synonyms of Bythiospeum sandbergeri, have now been segregated as distinct species since 2005, and as such, the nature of this species for a conservation assessment requires a further review. It is still listed by Fauna Europaea, so presumed to be a valid species, after the other taxa have been removed from the species concept.

This species lies within one of the groups of Hydrobid snails that is currently being researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic status and the species limits are doubted by some researchers (Benke et al. 2009). A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology, pending the results of the full analysis for the group.

This species lies within one of the groups of freshwater snails that is currently being researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic status and the species limits are doubted by some researchers (Benke et al. 2009). A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology, pending the results of the full analysis for the group.

This species lies within one of the groups of spring-snails that is currently being researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic status and the species limits are doubted by some researchers (Benke et al. 2009). A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology, pending the results of the full analysis for the group.

There are currently 4 subspecies listed for this species; quenstedti (Wiedersheim 1873), ara (Geyer, 1905), turbinella (Geyer, 1905) and weinlandi (Geyer, 1904).

Glöer and Zettler (2005) noted that in Germany nearly 70 different "species" were originally described, which were reduced by Bolling (1965) to 3 species, so for some periods there was little recording. In this problematic genus, they continued to list those species and subspecies on CLECOM (Check List of European Continental Mollusca), but noting that as long as we adhere solely to the shells there will be no progress. A revision of this genus is urgently needed and in Stuttgart, research with DNA analysis is ongoing for this problem.

A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology pending the results for full analysis for the group using Falkner and Niederhöfer (2008), however unless there is indicated active specific species survey data, some species listed as or Extinct or Possibly Extinct have been placed into threatened categories.

This species lies within one of the groups of spring-snails that is currently being researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic  status and the species limits are doubted by some researchers (Benke et al. 2009). A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology, pending the results of the full analysis for the group.

This species lies within one of the groups of spring-snails that is currently being researched using molecular systematics to determine the taxonomic status and the species limits are doubted by some researchers (Benke et al. 2009). A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology, pending the results of the full analysis for the group.

Gittenberger (1985) after anatomical examination of two specimens of Xeroplexa setubalensis (type species of Xeroplexa, Monterosato1892) from the locus typicus noted that it corresponded to Candidula (Kobelt 1871), so Xeroplexa must be considered a junior synonymn of Candidula.

authority: (Peinado, G. Moreno & Velasco) G. Moreno & Peinado

taxonomicNotes: This species is considered as a subspecies of Pieris brassicae by some authors.
Synonym = Caseolus sphaerula Lowe.

Neiber et al. (2020) undertook a genetic assessment of the remaining known subpopulations of the species and found a differentiation into a western, a central and an eastern group of subpopulations, which is largely consistent with a pattern of isolation-by-distance.
The species is cited as Xerosecta sp. in the Italian check-list.
This species has also been known under the name Drepanostoma camerani (Lessona, 1880).

Personal observations by Falkner and Beckmann suggest that the populations are isolated and often exhibit marked morphological differences. These might indicate that the species is polytypic, or even contains cryptic species.
This species is also known as Ochthephila spirulina not Disculella (amendation by Walden 1983).

Molecular studies strongly suggest, that R. meidingeri is very closely related or conspecific with R. frisii. As the morphological characters distinguishing both species have not been reviewed to test the hypothesis, R. meidingeri is continued to be treated as a valid species.
Note correction to spelling of the generic name from Siluris to Silurus.
The generic name was incorrectly spelt in the 1996 Red List as Pyrenaeania.

Molecular studies place this species as nested within the congener Cobitis vardarensis, suggesting that both species are closely related or identical. Indeed, individuals showing the diagnostic colour pattern of C. stephanidisi occur in populations of C. vardarensis in the Pinios River drainage (Perdices et al., 2018). Until this phenomenon has been studied in detail the conservation status of C. stephanidisi cannot be assessed.

Molecular evidence suggests this species is very closely-related to, or even conspecific with, the congener Cobitis arachtosensis (Perdices et al. 2018). Their taxonomy may therefore be reviewed in the future.
Cobitis romanica transferred to Sabanejewia following Kottlelat (1997).
This species cannot currently be assessed due to taxonomic issues.

Telestes pleurobipunctatus is structured in a number of distinct molecular groups which are all treated as one species here. In future, it might be tested if they might represent different species or only divergent molecular lineages within T. pleurobipunctatus.
Transferred from genus Pseudophoxinus to Telestes.
Recent change of genus from Leuciscus to Squalius (Zardoya and Doadrio 1999, Sanjur et al. 2003).
There has been a recent change from genus Leuciscus to Squalius (Zardoya and Doadrio 1999, Sanjur et al. 2003).
Molecular studies suggest that this species is very closely related to the congener Cobitis hellenica (Perdices et al. 2018). Their taxonomy may therefore be reviewed in the future.

This species was found to be distinct in a molecular study by Ketmaier et al. (2004) but this was not supported by Geiger et al. (2014). Further research is required to ascertain its taxonomic position.
This species was included in the genus Aphanius prior to 2020.

Recent molecular studies have demonstrated that all shads endemic to the Aegean, Black and Caspian Sea basins, including Alosa vistonica, share close phylogenetic relationships. Their taxonomy may therefore be revised in the future.
This is one of the few Bythiospeum species, whose validity is not questioned.
Recent change from genus Leuciscus to Squalius (Zardoya and Doadrio 1999, Sanjur et al. 2003).

The results of phylogenetic studies (Vecchioni et al. 2018, 2022) suggest that the genus Salaria might prove paraphyletic, and that the freshwater species may require generic reassignment. A conservative taxonomic approach pending conclusive evidence is adopted for this assessment, however.
Taxonomic status is unclear.

A lineage from the northeast of Gran Canaria has been described as the distinct species Chalcides bistriatus on morphological grounds (Pasteur et al. 1988). While this arrangement has a genetic basis the same lines of evidence indicate that the divergence between the two is both shallow and incomplete, suggesting both a young divergence and a lack of reproductive isolation (Speybroeck et al. 2020). On this basis Speybroeck et al. (2020) concur with Mayer and Tiedemann (1991) that C. bistriatus is best considered conspecific with C. sexlineatus.

Chalcides simonyi used to be considered a subspecies of Chalcides polylepis (as C. p. occidentalis), but it was elevated to specific status by Pasteur et al. (1988). The International Commission of Zoological Nomenclature ruled that the valid name of this taxon is C. simonyi, and not C. occidentalis (López Jurado 1998).
This taxon will probably be separated into several different species (J. Mateo pers comm.).
Following the ruling of the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature, the name of this species is Gallotia bravoana, not Gallotia gomerana.
This species was described by Hernández et al. (2000), but the name first appeared in Barbadillo et al. (1999) and this is therefore the correct authority.

This taxon is considered to be a full species based on evidence from Arribas (1996), Carranza et al. (2004), Crochet et al. (2004), Mayer and Arribas (1996, 2003) and Odierna et al. (1996). It was formerly treated as a subspecies of Iberolacerta monticola. The specific status of this taxon is supported by morphology (Arribas 1996), allozymes (Mayer and Arribas 1996) and mitochondrial DNA (Mayer and Arribas 2003; Carranza et al. 2004a; Crochet et al. 2004).

This species was formerly treated as a subspecies of Iberolacerta monticola, but genetic and morphological data support a full specific rank (Mayer and Arribas 2003, Arribas and Carranza 2004, Crochet et al. 2004).

This species is not closely related to Lacerta sensu stricto, nor to Archaeolacerta bedriagae (Arribas 1999, Harris et al. 1998, Mayer and Arribas 2003, Carranza et al. 2004). Its relationships remain uncertain (Crochet and Dubois 2004).

This species has been accepted as being validly distinct from Zamenis longissimus, with which it was previously confused, since Lenk and Wuster (1999). Nevertheless, the lack of standard procedures for distinguishing between the two species has resulted in a lack of clarity regarding their relative range limits, complicated by the discovery of intermediate forms. Salvi et al. (2017) investigated the distributions of the taxa in Italy and found that that of Z. lineatus was smaller than previously recognized, and that at least some morphologically intermediate specimens were referrable to Z. longissimus, with none that could be unambiguously assigned to Z. lineatus.
Some people treat S. nigra subsp. palmensis as S. palmensis and further investigation is required to determine whether it should be elevated from subspecies to species level.

Allium rouyi Gaut. is a tertiary wild relative of a number of crops in the Allium group, including onion (A. cepa L.), Welsh onion (A. fistulosum L.), leek (A. porrum L.), garlic (A. sativum L.) and chives (A. schoenoprasum L.). Spanish experts present at a European Crop Wild Relative Red List workshop convened in April 2010 considered A. chrysonemum to be a synonym of A. rouyi. However, both species are recognized and accepted by Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) and Govaerts et al. (2005-2007).

Although A. chrysonemum and A. rouyi are recognized and accepted by Cabezudo et al. (2004), Euro+Med PlantBase (2006) and Govaerts et al. (2005-2007), recent research has proved that A. chrysonemum Stearn and A. reconditum Pastor, Valdés & Muñoz are synonyms with A. rouyi, and therefore, distribution of this species extends throughout the south of the Iberian Peninsula (Pastor 2009; Aedo 2013).

Spilani et al. (2019) found that there are two genetically strongly differentiated 'east' and 'west' lineages within Podarcis peloponnesciacus. Speybroeck et al. (2020) recommended refraining from taxonomic changes prior to the results of a morphological study, This work, reported by Kiourtsoglou et al. (2021), confirmed the existence of these genetic lineages, with estimated divergence dates in the Pleistocene and no evidence of genetic admixture. They proposed treating the eastern lineage as a full species, for which the name Podarcis thais (Buchholz, 1960) is available. Despite investigating morphological traits these authors were however unable to identify any unambiguous morphological differences, and consequently this assessment follows Speybroeck et al. (2020) and Uetz (2022) in refraining from making taxonomic changes.

Recent literature has adopted the spelling Podarcis raffeonae for this species following a proposed emendation by Michaels and Bauer (2003). Speybroeck et al. (2020) concluded that this emendation was unjustified and this assessment consequently retains the spelling raffonei.
The taxonomic status of the subspecies Podarcis waglerianus marettimensis from Marettimo Island needs to be clarified.
Two subspecies have been described; subsp. duvigneaudii, and subsp. occultata L.Sáez, Rita, Bibiloni, Roquet & López-Alvarado.
The Global Compositae Checklist (Flann 2013) treats this as a synonym of Centaurea cineraria L.
Diplotaxis siettiana Maire is a wild relative of brassica crops as well as being related to cultivated perennial wall rocket, D. tenuifolia (L.) DC.

authority: A.Galán de Mera, J.E.Cortés, J.A.Vicente Orellana & R.Morales Alonso

taxonomicNotes: The Sardinian taxon has been renamed C. amazonum Fridl. & A. Raynal.

Although Medicago citrina has in the past been treated in the past as a subspecies or variety of M. arborea, several caryological and genetic studies found that M. citrina is an hexaploid species (2n=48), well separated from the eastern Mediterranean tetraploids M. arborea and M. strasseri (both 2n=32).

Waldén (1983) notes that this name is not preoccupied by Helix erubescens (Solander) Lightfoot 1786, as he argues that description appears to be unidentifiable. Bank et al. (2002) use the name L. simia, on the basis that the name is preoccupied. Seddon (2008) noted that given the use of erubescens (Lowe, 1831) in numerous papers over the last 120 years, it would appear that Bank et al. (2002) could have argued to keep the name on the basis of stability, and used article 29.2 to set aside Helix erubescens (Solander) Lightfoot, 1786 as a nomen oblitum.

Mandahl- Barth (1950) treats Madeiran forms as four distinct subspecies:

Leptaxis simia advenoides (Paiva, 1867) – Distribution: Madeiran Islands (Portugal)
Leptaxis simia hyaena (R.T. Lowe, 1852) – Distribution: Madeiran Islands (Portugal)
Leptaxis  simia portosancti (Wollaston, 1878) – Distribution: Madeiran Islands (Portugal)
Leptaxis simia simia (A. Férussac, 1832) – Distribution: Azores (Portugal), Madeiran Islands (Portugal).

The original generic name Tyrrheniella Giusti & Manganelli, 1989 is preoccupied and was replaced by Tyrrheniellina Giusti & Manganelli, 1992. Thyrreniellina was an alternative spelling erroneously used in Fauna Europaea.

There are two subspecies: Hystricella bicarinata bicarinata and Hystricella bicarinata aucta (Wollaston, 1878). Cameron et al. (2006) has recently reviewed the status of this form whilst in consideration of the status of Hystricella oxytropis finding that it is distinctly smaller than Hystricella bicarinata.

Bank reviewed the nomenclature of the species and established bulverii as the original spelling of the species name although most authors in the last 80 years have used the bulweri spelling. 

Seddon (2008) noted that 'there has been debate since the 1860s as to whether D. bulweri and D. albersi are one or two species. Wollaston (1878) maintained two species based on Lowe's descriptions commenting that both were found together. D. albersi was treated as subspecies of D. bulweri by Mandahl-Barth (1950), but as separate species by Walden (1983).  Nobre (1931) and Bank et al. (2002) view albersi as a synonym of bulweri.  Seddon (2008) reviewed  extensive material in Museum collections and suggests that the two forms are not separable on a consistent basis, therefore albersi is placed as a synonym of bulweri.  Wollaston (1878) noted the similarity to D. lyelliana from Deserta Grande.

Waldén (1983) recognised two subspecies of Disculella madeirensis. Wollaston (1878) viewed both as distinct and separable species, although Lowe has obviously considered them to be conspecific. The two subspecies are not known to be found together at a site, but it seems possible that they are distinct species.
This is a valid species, confirmed by molecular analyses (Wilke et al. 2001 ; Prié, unpublished data).

The fossil species Gallotia auaritae was described as a subspecies of Gallotia simonyi by Mateo et al. (2001). It has subsequently been widely accepted as a full species following Alfaro and Mateo (2003), although Cruzado-Caballero et al. (2019) note that no detailed formal justification for this has been provided.
Author name should possibly be in brackets?
The specific name may be better spelt as G. delphinula.

Type locality: "Loulé" (Algarve) (Portugal). G. turriplana has been judged closely related to Oestophora by some authors (Ortiz de Zárate 1962; Schileyko 1971; Prieto et al. 1993; Puente 1996; Steinke et al. 2004). However, Schileyko (1991, 2005) considered the Gittenbergeriinae a proper taxon classifying it as a subfamily within his Helicodontidae. New molecular evidences are in agreement with Schileyko and moreover, following the CLECOM system arrangement (Bank et al. 2001), propose to consider the Gittenbergeriidae Schileyko, 1991 as a separated family monotypic for Gittenbergeria turriplana (unpublished data).
There are two subspecies: Hauffenia kerschneri kerschneri and Hauffenia kerschneri loichiana Haase, 1993
Some authors consider this species must be included in the genus Helicella instead of Xerotricha (Giusti and Manganelli 1989, Arrébola 1995).

Since its description by Gasull (1972), the taxonomic status of the hygromiid Helicella (Xerotricha) mariae has been considered uncertain. It was collected from a single locality in the southeast of the Iberian Peninsula in the province of Almería: “Sierra de Gata, Barranco del Sabinal, Cumbres del Mediodía”. However, the correct name for the locality would be "Sierra del Cabo de Gata" where there is a ravine (barranco) named Sabinar instead of Sabinal (with 5 endemic plants described). Description and generic assignment of this snail were based on conchological (= shell) characteristics only. The reproductive system of three syntypes was studied by E. Gittenberger (in Gasull 1972), but these were found to be sexually immature. Finally, the subgenus Xerotricha was named with some doubts by Gasull (1972). Ruiz et al. (2006) indicated that because it has never again been found in its type locality nor in the rest of the Sierra de Gata, both its presence and its taxonomical validity must be confirmed. Martínez-Ortí and Uribe (2008) also indicate that both the taxonomical validity and the generic placement in the Family Hygromiidae are yet to be confirmed. Martínez-Ortí (2008) studying (conchologically) the type series of the species concludes Helicella mariae must be considered a junior synonym of Xerotricha conspurcata. However, new samplings in the type locality and its surroundings have discovered living specimens of a species distinct from X. conspurcata, although with similar general conchological features. Several specimens were dissected but were also sexually immature. Even so, the genital anatomy resembled those of the Xerocrassa genus (A. Ruiz pers. comm. 2010).

Future samplings will be made during more appropriate seasons in order to find sexually mature specimens. However, we must consider that X. conspurcata is not distributed in the province of Almería (Arrébola 1995), except in its northern part where there is a single record given by Puente (1994).
The generic/subgeneric status of this species must be confirmed. Comparative anatomic and genetic studies including closest species and genera (even North Africans) could be explanatory.
Some authors consider that this species must be included in Helicella instead of Xerotricha genus (Gittenberger and  Manga 1977).

This species, described by Ortiz de Zárate (1950) using a single specimen, was classified by this author in a new subgenus of the genus Helicella. The taxonomic classification of this species needs to be clarified (especially the status of the genus).

Moreletina obruta was described as a fossil. Backhuys (1975:203) attributed it cautiously to the genus Cernuella. Martins et al. (1991) found it alive and placed it under Helicella. Finally Martins (2002) placed it in a separate genus, Moreletina. Two ecomorphs were recognized, their true taxonomic identity awaits molecular analysis.
This taxon was originally assessed under the name Hemicycla pouchet for the Red List, however the nomenclature has changed and it is now renamed as Hemicycla pouchadan (Ibanez and Alonso 2007).
There are two known subspecies for this species, Hemicycla glyceia glyceia is only known as a Quaternary fossil, whereas Hemicycla glyceia silensis is known living.

Wollaston (1878) described two varieties of this species, the nominate race actinophora and var. β descendens. Walden (1983) treated these as subspecies in his list, and Bank et al. (2002) retained these subspecies in their list.

This was listed as Actinella Form II in Waldén (1983), whereas other authors considered the species to be part of Actinella fausta. Bank et al. (2002) listed the taxa suggesting the type locality must be Estreito de Camara de Lobos

Waldén (1983) created Actinella (Plebecula) effugiens nov. nom. for Helix lurida Lowe, 1831 (not C. Pfeiffer, 1828) but overlooked Actinella (Plebecula) littorinella (Mabille, 1883) (Bank et al. 2002).

The species was moved to genus Domunculifex by Brozzo et al. (2020).

Mandahl-Barth (1950) and Bank et al. (2002) treat this as a separate species. Waldén (1983) noted the status as a distinct species from nitidiuscula was uncertain. Seddon (pers. comm. 2010) noted that detailed surveying may allow the recognition of the species limits between A. nitidiuscula and A. giramica.

Seddon (2008) noted that it appeared closely allied to the Quaternary fossil species Actinella (Faustella) promontoriensis, which also has a bisinuosity, which is more strongly developed, and a shell which appears more globose, with a more shouldered whorl (not as acutely keeled).  A. promontoriensis is a common fossil species on the peninsular at the eastern end of the island.
This was listed as Actinella Form III in Waldén (1983), whereas other authors considered the species to be part of Actinella fausta.  Bank et al. (2002) listed it as a valid species.
Synonym = Diacyclops hypogeus Kiefer, 1930.

Recent molecular studies have demonstrated that all shads endemic to the Aegean, Black and Caspian Sea basins, including Alosa macedonica, share close phylogenetic relationships. Their taxonomy may therefore be revised in the future.
This species is one of many small spring-snails that can be most easily be identified using anatomical characters of the reproductive system.
Dasypoda iberica is only from the male. Female of this species is still undescribed.
The genus Eozubovskya has been synonymised by Storozhenko et al. (2015) with Zubovskya and currently the species is assigned to the latter.

Prospero battagliae was described by Speta (2000), based on specimens made from plants cultivated in Linz (Austria) and originally collected in Crete. Valdés (2004) transferred the species to Scilla L.

Turland and Chilton (2008) state that the species is treated under P. autumnale sensu lato until further study of Prospero throughout its distribution results in a more satisfactory taxonomic arrangement. 

Scilla autumnalis (Prospero autumnale sensu lato) is an imperfectly understood polyploid complex. Speta (2000) described a number of taxa, all local or regional endemics and based on very fragmentary evidence; they cannot be keyed out on morphological characters (I. Bazos et al. pers. comm. 2014). The species is sometimes considered a synonym of the very widespread S. autumnale L. (e.g., Böhling et al. 2002, Strid 2016).

Prospero hierapytnense was described by Speta (2000), based on specimens made from plants cultivated in Linz (Austria) and originally collected in Crete. Valdés (2004) transferred the species to Scilla L.

Turland and Chilton (2008) state that the species is treated under P. autumnale sensu lato until further study of Prospero throughout its distribution results in a more satisfactory taxonomic arrangement.

Scilla autumnalis (Prospero autumnalis) sensu lato is an imperfectly understood polyploid complex. Speta described a number of taxa, all local or regional endemics and based on very fragmentary evidence; they cannot be keyed out on morphological characters (P. Delipetrou et al. pers. comm. 2014). The species is sometimes considered a synonym of the very widespread S. autumnale L. (e.g., Böhling et al. 2002, Strid 2016).

Prospero idaeum was described by Speta (2000), based on specimens made from plants cultivated in Linz (Austria) and originally collected in Crete. Turland and Chilton (2008) state that the species is treated under P. autumnale sensu lato until further study of Prospero throughout its distribution results in a more satisfactory taxonomic arrangement. Valdés (2004) transferred the species to Scilla L.

Scilla autumnalis (Prospero autumnalis) sensu lato is an imperfectly understood polyploid complex. Speta described a number of taxa, all local or regional endemics and based on very fragmentary evidence; they cannot be keyed out on morphological characters (Bazos et al. pers. comm.).

Prospero minimum was described by Speta (2000), based on specimens made from plants cultivated in Linz (Austria) and originally collected in Crete. Turland and Chilton (2008) state that the species is treated under P. autumnale sensu lato until further study of Prospero throughout its distribution results in a more satisfactory taxonomic arrangement. Valdés (2004) transferred the species to Scilla L.

Scilla autumnalis (Prospero autumnalis) sensu lato is an imperfectly understood polyploid complex. Speta described a number of taxa, all local or regional endemics and based on very fragmentary evidence; they cannot be keyed out on morphological characters (Bazos et al. pers. comm.).
Prionotropis hystrix subsp. azami Uvarov, 1923 was raised to species level by Massa and Ünal (2015).

authority: (Garbari, Miceli & Raimondo) Brullo, Guglielmo, Pavone & Salmeri
taxonomicNotes: Brullo et al. (2001) raised this to species level from Allium lehmannii subsp. castellanense Garbari, Miceli & Raimondo. In the literature, there is some confusion between the distribution of this species and A. agrigentinum, however Salmeri et al. (2016) consider A. castellanense to be well separated from other endemic Sicilian Allium species.
WCSP (2015) considers the species valid as Festuca calabrica Huter, Porta & Rigo ex Hack.

Bellevalia pelagica shows rather close relationships with some species recently described from Tunisia. They are Bellevalia dolichophylla Brullo & Minissale from Cap Bon and B. galitensis Bocchieri & Mossa, endemic to the island of La Galite. However, a number of vegetative and reproductive characters distinguish the Lampione population from both species (Brullo et al. 2009).


WCSP (2016), following Dobignard and Chatelain (2013) consider the taxon to be a synonym of Bellevalia dubia (Guss.) Schult. & Schult.f.

Further work is required to understand the taxonomic relationships within this genus in relation to the distribution of species and the status of proposed subspecies. In particular, the differences between C. multiflorum (and C. longifolium) and C. neapolitanum, are very unclear.

C. neapolitanum sensu strictu is restricted to southern (and perhaps central) Italy (J.-M. Tison pers. comm. 2015).

Fridlender et al. (2014) proposed the following subspecies;
  • C. neapolitanum (Ten.) Ten. subsp. neapolitanum: uncertain endemic to Southern Italy (Campania and Basilicata).
  • C. neapolitanum (Ten.) Ten. subsp. kochii (Parl.) Fridl.: northeast Italy, Slovenia and Croatia (southern limit in Zadar – Krka area) near the seashore at low altitude (0-200 m, up to 400 m).
  • C. neapolitanum (Ten.) Ten. subsp. visianii (Parl.) Fridl.: Dalmatia, above all at an altitude from 300 to 1400 m (some populations at sea level in Herzegovina and southern Croatia).
  • C. neapolitanum (Ten.) Ten. subsp. haynaldii (Heuffel) Fridl., stat. nov.: Romania.
WCSP (2018) considers this species to be a synonym of Festuca circummediterranea Patzke.

The taxonomy of this species is rather complex. It is considered a valid species and an Iberian endemic by some sources (Franco and Afonso 1994, Tison 2009, The Plant List 2014, WCSP 2014), but the recent review by Flora Iberica (López González 2013) treats this taxon as a synonym of Gagea foliosa subsp. elliptica [ellyptica] A.Terracc and thus occurring in the Iberian Peninsula and Morocco (Anthos 2014). The database Euro+Med (2014) considers it a synonym of Gagea granatellii (Parl.) Parl, which by its turn is considered synonym of G. lacaitae in Flora Iberica.

However, in addition to the study of juvenile and immature stages, the molecular data (Tison et al. 2013) confirm the independence of G. elliptica, G. granatellii, G. lacaitae and G. lusitanica.

Brullo and Giusso Del Galdo (2006) reviewed this species and described three subspecies; subsp. nitida (Abruzzi to Mt. Pollino), subsp. aprutia (central Apennines) and subsp. sicula (northern Sicily). However Bartolucci et al. (2018) maintain just the nominate subspecies and subsp. sicula.

Bartolucci et al. (2018) state": Since this species was only recorded for its locus classicus, where it has never been found again, we can suspect that it just represents a teratological expression of H. mollis (widespread in the same habitat), rather than a truly distinct species."
Records from the Rif Mountains in Morocco refer to Avena marginata according to Romero Zarco (1996).

Prospero rhadamanthi was described by Speta (2000), based on specimens made from plants cultivated in Linz (Austria) and originally collected in Crete. Turland and Chilton (2008) state that the species is treated under P. autumnale sensu lato until further study of Prospero throughout its distribution results in a more satisfactory taxonomic arrangement. Valdés (2004) transferred the species to Scilla L.

Scilla autumnalis (Prospero autumnalis) sensu lato is an imperfectly understood polyploid complex. Speta described a number of taxa all local or regional endemics and based on very fragmentary evidence; they cannot be keyed out on morphological characters (Bazos and Delipetrou pers. comm.).

The genera of tribe Avenae have been delineated quite differently during the past 200 years (Röser et al. 2009). Therefore, they show frequent nomenclatural problems and some difficulties for applying some taxonomical rules. These complications represent one of the major barriers when working in conservation assessment tasks for genus Helictotrichon.

The large genus Helictotrichon sensu Röser (1989) has been divided in to five genera: Helictotrichon sensu stricto (lectotypus H. sempervirens), Avenula sensu stricto (only A. pubescens, the lectotypus of the genus), Helictochloa Romero Zarco (typus Helictochloa bromoides; in 2011 Romero Zarco included in it most of the species formerly in Avenula),  Tricholemma Röser (Röser et al. 2009, typus: T. jahandiezii: including only two very rare species from NW Africa), and Trisetopsis Röser and Wölk (typus: Trisetopsis elongata; in 2013 Röser and Wölk 2013 included in it the tropical to subtropical African, Arabian and Malagasy species).

Euro+Med (2015) accepts Avenula, Helictochloa, Helictotrichon and Tricholemma as separate genera. Romero Zarco (1984) and Röser et al. (2006) included this species in the genus Avenula, however later Romero Zarco (2011) placed this species in the genus Helictochloa. Euro+Med (2015) has followed this last criterion.
WCSP (2018) considers this species to be a synonym of Puccinellia convoluta (Hornem.) Fourr.
Allium makrianum belongs to sectio Codonoprassum and shows close relationships to A. archaeotrichon (Brullo et al. 2010).

According to Kamari (1991), Fritillaria mutabilis may be of hybridogenous origin. It differs from the widely distributed Fritillaria graeca in the colour and shape of its leaves and flowers as well as in the triangular nectaries. Intermediate forms F. mutabilis x F. thessala occur on Tymfristos (Dimitrellos 2005).

Epipactis leptochila subsp. provincialis (Aubenas & Robatsch) J.-M.Tison is considered here a xerophytic variant of Epipactis leptochila (Godfery) Godfery based on Tison et al. (2010) and Board of Trustees, RBG Kew (2018).

Ophrys lepida S.Moingeon & J.M.Moingeon is considered by some authors subspecies of Ophrys subfusca (= Ophrys subfusca (Rchb.f.) Batt. subsp. liveranii Orrù & M.P.Grasso or under the combination Ophrys subfusca subsp. lepida (S.Moingeon & J.M.Moingeon) Kreutz (S. Orsenigo pers. comm. 2018).

Ophrys lepida S.Moingeon & J.-M.Moingeon is considered a synonym of Ophrys sicula Tineo by Board of Trustees, RBG Kew (2018). However, Ophrys lepida is considered here a valid species based on Peruzzi et al. (2015) and Orsenigo and Peruzzi pers. comm. (2016).
This species is presumably of hybridogenic origin between S. lingua and Serapias spp. Vegetative multiplication is active (E. Véla pers. comm. 2018).
Plants from the island of Tinos with yellowish-green flowers have been described as Fritillaria ehrhartii var. prasinantha (Kamari 1991).
Allium agrigentinum is a primary relative and potential gene donor to garlic (A. sativum)

According to Kamari (1991), hybrid Fritillaria davisii x graeca plants occur at the area of the southern foothills of Mt Taygetos (dot map). Zaharof-Pourpoutidi (1987) did not observe any hybrids and states that plants found in the southern foothills of Taygetos (locality Zizali) belong to Fritillaria graeca.

This species was recently described as a fertile hybrid between Narcissus asturiensis and N. nivalis (Fernández Casas 2009), but its taxonomic status is still rather unclear. The same author points out that this species as long been confused with one of its parents, namely N. nivalis. The recent revision of the Genus Narcissus in Flora Iberica does not consider this as a valid species (Aedo 2013). Its acceptance as a valid species in the Plant List (2017) is followed here, but clearly further taxonomic study is required.

The taxonomic status of this plant is still unclear. Whilst it is considered a valid species by some authors (Zonneveld 2008, eMonocot 2014, Euro+Med 2014), others consider this a subspecies of Narcissus triandrus, N. triandrus subsp. lusitanicus (Lázaro 2000), or a synonym of Narcissus triandrus subsp. pallidulus (Aedo 2013).
This taxon has been recognized by Luceño (2008).

Narcissus albicans (Haw) Spreng is a variable species normally included within N. cantabricus DC (Anthos 2014). Both taxa belong to the Bulbocodii Section and are considered to be separated species according Fernández Casas (2009, 2013).

This species is accepted according to the specialist of the genus in the Flora Ibérica (Luceño 2008). The Euro+Med database (2016) does not recognize C. lachenalii Schkuhr from Flora Europaea (Chater 1980) as a synonym of C. furva.

The description of part of the morphological variability of this species as Carex lucennoiberica (Maguilla and Escudero 2016, 2017) has restricted the distribution of C. furva to the Sierra Nevada, in southern Spain.

WCSP (2017, citing Tutin et al. 1980, Davis 1984, Everett 2013, Christenhusz et al. 2013) considers this species to be a synonym of Tulipa orphanidea Boiss. ex Heldr., however Tulipa hageri and T. orphanidea are considered separate species according to Strid and Tan (1991), Zonneveld (2009), Van Raamsdonk and De Vries (1992), Van Raamsdonk et al. (1997), and Dimopoulos et al. 2013). According to Van Raamsdonk and De Vries (1992), T. hageri, T. orphanidea and T. whittallii are separate species occurring exclusively in the Aegean region (including Asia Minor) with T. hageri being the most widespread. According to Zonnenveld (2009) Tulipa orphanidea has three subspecies: subsp. orphanidea, subsp. whittallii (Dykes) Zonn. (= T. whittallii Dykes, endemic to western Turkey), and subsp. doerfleri (= T. doerfleri).

According to Flora Europaea (Tutin et al. 1980) and Flora of Turkey and the East Aegean islands (Davis 1984) Tulipa hageri (Parnitha, Penteli) is included in T. orphanidea with the following distribution: Greece Gr-Cr/Pe, StE, NE, KK, Bulgaria, Turkey; E. Mediterranean element).

Tulipa hageri var. thasia was described from Thasos (Stojanov and Kitannnov), but this taxon is not quoted in any flora.
