For this assessment, T. hageri is considered as a separate valid taxon.

Although Andrena sagittaria has been considered a subspecies of Andrena sinuatta, for the purposes of the assessment the criteria of Gusenleitner and Schwarz (2002) will be followed, regarding it as a species on its own.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
The species was formerly mixed with H. canariensis and H. hohmanni (Dathe 1993).
The species was formerly mixed with H. ater and H. hohmanni (Dathe 1993).
The taxon is a member of the H. nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
The species was formerly confused with H. ater and H. canariensis (Dathe 1993).
The taxon is a member of the Hylaeus nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
The taxon is a member of the Hylaeus nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
This species belongs to a highly diverse taxonomic group, which is not yet fully understood. It is probably a local variant only and is closely related to Hylaeus hyalinatus.

The comparison of patterns of genetic variability in Hippocrepis valentina with those in two closely related taxa, H. balearica and H. grosii, supports the taxonomic consideration of H. valentina as a proper species, independent of H. balearica, in contrast to previous suggestions (Gonzalez-Candelas and Montolío 2000). In sharp contrast to the results obtained by Llorens et al. (1995), a clear separation of continental and insular samples belonging to the H. balearica complex was found, and no intermediates linking H. balearica and H. valentina were detected in the phenetic analyses of the RAPD data (Roselló et al. 2002).
Only the males of this species have been observed and described. Further research needs to conducted to describe the females of this species.
Warncke (1977) considered Dioxys atlanticus as a subspecies of Dioxys cinctus (Jurine, 1807).
The species was described from a single specimen, a male, collected in 1987 (Tkalců 2001).

Pseudoanthidium canariense is a species belonging to the subgenus Pseudoanthidium Friese, 1898 (Warncke 1980, Michener 2007, Ascher and Pickering 2012).


Warncke (1980) stated that Pseudoanthidium canariense should be the subspecies Anthidium lituratum canariense.

The taxonomic status of Ammobatoides okalii is uncertain (J. Straka pers. obs. 2013). This species was described from a single specimen and it was never found again. This problematic species needs to be studied in the future and its validity resolved.
The Sphecodes species from the Canary Islands are very poorly known and their taxonomy is likely to be changed in future studies (P. Bogusch pers. comm. 2013).
Only females have been discovered and described, further surveys are required to catch the male of the species.

This species was originally described as Campsicnemus mirabilis. However, C. mirabilis (Grimshaw, 1902) takes precedence of this name. Dyte (1980), therefore provided an alternative name for this concept, which is C. atlanticus.
The status of this taxon remains unclear.
Westrich (1993) does not provide a subgenus for this species, but indicates that it is close to A. scopippes, a north African species, in the subgenus Pyganthophora.
<span lang="EN-US">The taxonomic status of this species remains confusing. Westrich (1993) did not assign the species to any known subgenus.
The status of this species is unclear. It could be a synonym of either A. affinis or A. mucida.
There are no taxonomic problems known at present.
There are four subspecies: ssp. viride (Brullé, 1839); ssp. cabrerai (Warncke, 1975); ssp. palmae Ebmer, 1993; and ssp. unicolor (Brullé, 1840).

There are three subspecies on the Canary Islands: L. a. glandarium (Warncke, 1975) is found on El Hierro and La Palma; L. a. optatum is found on Gran Canaria (Warncke, 1975); and the nominal subspecies is found on Tenerife.

This assessment includes the Canarian subspecies Andrena chalcogastra gomera Warncke, 1968 (from La Gomera), Andrena chalcogastra palmaensis Warncke, 1968 (from La Palma), Andrena chalcogastra extrema Warncke, 1993 (from Gran Canaria), and Andrena chalcogastra chalcogastra Brullé, 1839 (from Tenerife).
According to Blank and Kraus (1994), the type specimens of Andrena (Chlorandrena) damara are labelled Andrena sagittaria ssp. damara.
The subgeneric attribution of Andrena ebmerella is uncertain.
This species was originally described by Warncke as Andrena abrupta ssp. elata Warncke, 1975.

While A. maderensis fratella Warncke, 1968 was described from Morocco, it seems that A. maderensis is endemic to the main island of Madeira and A. fratella is a distinct species (E. Scheuchl pers. comm. 2014).

The two subspecies Andrena montarca andina Warncke, 1974, and Andrena montarca parva Warncke, 1974 are certainly distinct species (Gusenleitner and Schwarz 2002). A. montarca is an Iberian endemic species, while A. parva and A. andina are north African species.
Also known as Aleurostictus decempunctatus.

The Osmoderma species complex is here treated as five separate species (barnabita, eremita, cristinae, italica and lassallei), following Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). Distribution limits of these different forms remain poorly resolved, but for the purpose of these assessments we follow the approximate distribution limits outlined in Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). There is ongoing debate as to whether or not these forms constitute valid species, but for the purpose of this assessment we are assessing each form separately.
There has been some confusion on whether A. corsicus and A. quercicola are the same species. According to Platia (1994) A. corsicus is a valid species and it is endemic to Corsica.

The species status for this species is doubtful. It seems to be published only in the original description by Pic 1930 and in the old italian fauna of Porta. Is a taxon name valid for Fauna Europaea. However the taxon is not included in any of the recent taxonomic reviews.

The Plant List, The Euro+Med Plantbase and eMonocot treat this species as a synonym of Romulea revelieri Jord. & Fourr. However, Frignani and Iiriti (2011) provide evidence that there are different entities within the revelieri "group" and there are sufficient distinctive features to justify keeping R. insularis as a good species.

Vanneaugobius dollfusi Brownell, 1878 was considered a synonym of Vanneaugobius pruvoti, however Pallaoro and Kovačić (2000) collected additional specimens that are thought to belong to the valid species V. dollfusi.
Cottunculus konstantinovi is not clearly distinguished from C. microps (Parin et al. 2002).
Described in 1993 as one of four species identified within a species complex (with P. budensis, P. caucasicus and other). Delimitation and distributional ranges are not yet clear.
Sphyraena intermedia was only recently described on the basis of 19 specimens collected from the Mediterranean Sea (Pastore 2009).
This species might be a complex of several hitherto undescribed species (P. Fontana, pers. comm. 2015).

Aedo (2013) recognized Leucojum valentinum Pau as the valid name for the species. Nevertheless, we have followed the approach made by Euro+Med Plantbase (2006), in which Acis valentina (Pau) Lledó, A.P.Davis & M.B.Crespo is recognized as the valid name.

Records from Greece are placed within the Acis valentina taxon concept by some authors (Aguillera et al. 1990), but are considered to belong to another taxon, Leucojum ionicum, and have therefore been excluded from this assessment.

Narcissus is a genus of great difficulty from a taxonomic point of view with numerous nomenclatural problems. The accepted number of species varies widely depending on the authority, from 27 species recognized in Flora Europaea (1980) to 87 in the International Daffodil Register.

N. munozii-garmendiae is an accepted species (WCSP 2016), however, in the Monograph of Narcissus of Flora Iberica (Aedo 2013), this species is subordinated to N. pseudonarcissus as a subspecies: Narcissus pseudonarcissus subsp. munozii-garmendiae (Fern.Casas) Fern.Casas.

Narcissus is a genus of great difficulty from a taxonomic point of view with numerous nomenclatural problems. The accepted number of species varies widely depending on the authority, from 27 recognized species in Flora Europaea (1980) to 87 in the International Daffodil Register.

N. nevadensis is an accepted species in the Euro+MED database, the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (WCSP 2013) and Blanchard (1990) Narcissus a Guide to Wild Daffodils. However in the Monograph of Narcissus for Flora Iberica (Aedo, in press), this species is subordinated to N. pseudonarcissus as a subspecies: Narcissus pseudonarcissus subsp. nevadensis (Pugsley) A.Fern.

Usually two species have been considered in N. nevadensis: Narcissus nevadensis subsp. enemeritoi Sánchez-Gómez, Carrillo, A.Hernández, M.Á.Carrión & Güemes and Narcissus nevadensis Pugsley subsp. nevadensis.

According to Gutierrez et al. (2006), Narcissus nevadensis subsp. enemeritoi Sánchez-Gómez, Carrillo, A.Hernández, M.Á. Carrión & Güemes is synonym to the accepted name Narcissus enemeritoi (Sánchez-Gómez & al.) Sánchez-Gómez & al., according to the WCSP, and Narcissus nevadensis occurs in Sierra Nevada, Spain. However, the information provided for the taxon Narcissus nevadensis in Article 17 (Commission of the European Communities 2009) corresponds to Narcissus nevadensis subsp. enemeritoi.

In the last assessment of this species (Gutiérrez Carretero et al. 2011) the authors considered two subspecies: Narcissus nevadensis subsp. enemeritoi Sánchez-Gómez, Carrillo, A.Hernández, M.Á.Carrión & Güemes and Narcissus nevadensis Pugsley subsp. nevadensis.

They indicated that Narcissus nevadensis subsp. enemeritoi is a synonym to the accepted name Narcissus enemeritoi, according to World Checklist of Selected Plant Families, and that Narcissus nevadensis is restricted to the Sierra Nevada, Spain. They also commented that the information provided for the taxon Narcissus nevadensis in Article 17 (Commission of the European Communities 2009) corresponds to Narcissus nevadensis subsp. enemeritoi.

However in the Monograph of Narcissus to Flora Iberica (Aedo 2013), this species is subordinated to N. pseudonarcissus as a subspecies: Narcissus pseudonarcissus subsp. nevadensis (Pugsley) A.Fern.

Usually two subspecies of N. nevadensis have been considered: Narcissus nevadensis subsp. enemeritoi Sánchez-Gómez, Carrillo, A.Hernández, M.Á.Carrión & Güemes and Narcissus nevadensis Pugsley subsp. nevadensis. Both subspecies have been considered as synonyms of Narcissus pseudonarcissus subsp. nevadensis (Pugsley) A.Fern. by Aedo (2013). Aedo (2013) points out that Narcissus pseudonarcissus subsp. nevadensis includes as synonyms to N. alcaracensis Ríos, D.Rivera, Alcaraz & Obón, N. bujei (Fern.Casas) Fern.Casas, N. enemeritoi (Sánchez Gómez & al.) Sánchez Gómez & al., N. longispathus Degen & Hervier ex Pugsley, N. nevadensis Pugsley, Narcissus segurensis S.Ríos, D.Rivera, Alcaraz & Obón, N. yepesii S.Ríos, D.Rivera, Alcaraz & Obón, and several other taxa related.

At present, we retain both subspecies within Narcissus nevadensis: Narcissus nevadensis subsp. nevadensis, endemic to the province of Granada and Narcissus nevadensis subsp. enemeritoi, endemic to the province of Murcia.

authority: Bahillo de la Puebla et al., 2003
taxonomicNotes: There have not been taxonomic changes at least since 2003.

Cucujus tulliae is clearly related to the cinnaberinus–haematodes species group, its distribution seems to be restricted to the mountains of Calabrian peninsula.The closest taxon could be C. haematodes, from which it can easily be distinguished by the less prominent postgenae, the arrow head shaped prosternal apophysis, the smaller and less spiny pronotum, the typical median lobe of the aedeagus and the larval morphology, that is apparently unique because of its slender body and occipital furrows (Bonacci et. al. 2012).
The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain as it might be a synonym of Petaloptila andreinii, which is also present in the same cave.
The taxonomic status of this species requires further investigation.
Formerly considered an endemic species from Sardinia, this taxon is now placed as a subspecies of Calicnemis obesa (Verdugo and Drumont 2015).
Prionotropis hystrix subsp. rhodanica Uvarov, 1923 was raised to species level by Massa and Ünal (2015).
Taxonomic research is needed to clarify the relationship of Tessellana lagrecai and Tessellana tessellata.
It was previously described as a subspecies of S. marginatus but it is thought to be a separate species (Bogusch and Straka in prep.).

This is a polytypic species with two subspecies (siculus siculus and siculus buturensis).

The current edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

In the next edition of the Catalogue to be published in 2015, all the subgenera will be upgraded to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

Recently, Dellacasa and Dellacasa (2008), has elevated Chelotrupes to the genus rank. Moreover they propose Typhaeus matutinalis (first considered as synonymous of hiostius) as a valid species. Given that both proposed taxa occurs in sympatry in the majority of their ranges and that genus Chelotrupes have high morphological variability (Verdú pers. obs.), on a precautionary basis and pending further molecular analysis that verify such status, Typhaeus will be considered as genus and T. matutinalis as a synonym of T. hiostius in this assessment.
The taxonomy of this species is well known (Zunino 1973, 1984; Löbl and Smetana 2006; Ziani et al. 2006)
After Martín-Piera and López-Colón (2000) this species could belong to the genus Jekelius López-Colón, 1989. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status.
After Martín-Piera & López-Colón (2000) this species could belong to Jekelius López-Colón 1989 genus. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status.

This species could belong to the genus Silphotrupes Jekel, 1866. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status. For its correct identification see Verdú and Galante (2000).
After Martín-Piera and López-Colón (2000) this species could belong to the genus Silphotrupes Jekel, 1866. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status.

Falahee and Angus (2010), using a chromosomal approach, considered O. massai as a valid species and not a synonym of O. fracticornis. Pizzo et al. (2011), using a combination of geometric morphometric and genetic approaches, argued that there was not sufficient evidence to vindicate the species status for O. massai, which should more likely be considered a small-sized form of O. fracticornis.
This species is most closely related to Hydrolagus affinis (Moura et al. 2005).

Raja maderensis, or a very similar species, is found in the Azores. The taxonomy and relationship of skates on these islands should be assessed. This species is now thought to be distinct from similar specimens from the Canary Islands and West Africa (Ebert and Stehmann 2013).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. This species is possibly a junior synonym of M. pyrenaica (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimens (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimens (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimen (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimen (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
It is unclear if it is distinct from H. albonotata (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimen (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
This species could be considered as a species of the Genus Actinia by some authors (Verena Haussermann, 2003).
The specific status of the species is considered doubtful, it may be a subspecies of P. pylaon.
The taxon was first described as Agriades coridon race caelestissima by Verity (1921).
This species is is the type species for the genus Vinodolia, and was originally placed in the genus Orientalina (now Radomaniola).

This species may be conspecific with B. hortorum but the taxonomic status is uncertain. No-one has a sufficiently broad analysis of this complex at present to conclude this authoritatively(P. Williams pers. comm. 2015).

Among the other members of the Bulbocodii section N. hedraeanthus is distinguishable for its dwarf size, with a typical small straw yellow-orange (more or less pale) with stamens exerted from corona: only in N. romieuxii Braun Blanquet & Maire stamens are also exerted but the colour is different and this species is growing in Morocco (Hanks 2002, Ríos et al. 2009, Fernández-Casas 2010). Currently two subspecies are accepted: the typical N. hedraeanthus subsp. hedraeanthus and N. hedraeanthus subsp. luteolentus (Barra & G.López) Aedo (= N. blancoi Barra & G.López) with pale yellow corolla and tube much larger than the type.

In the recent revision of genus Narcissus in the Flora Iberica (Aedo 2013), N. eugeniae is treated as a synonym of N. pseudonarcissus subsp. portensis (Pugsley) A.Fern.


However, the current opinion of WCSP (2017) is followed here, recognizing that the placement of the species may change to follow Aedo (2013).

authority: S. Ríos, D. Rivera, Alcaraz & Obón
taxonomicNotes:
Dwarf plant (along with Narcissus asturiensis (Jordan) Pugsley, the smallest trumpet daffodil described in the wild) with a small bulb bearing a scape with a single and bicoloured flower. Relatively big spathe (up to 40 mm) and flower, with erect to erect-patent tepals. Small convex corona (15-17 mm) with toothed or crenate-toothed margin The anthers length is equaling or exceeding the staminal filaments lenght, which constitutes an exceptional feature in the genus Narcissus (Aedo 2013).


It is considered a synonym of Narcissus pseudonarcissus subsp. nevadensis by WCSP (2017) and of Narcissus hispanicus by The Plant List (2017). The designation of Euro+Med Plantbase Project (2017) is followed here.
There are two natural hybrid subpopulations between this species and the closely related N. segurensis.

Further study is required to confirm the correct placement of this species. According to Dimopoulos et al. (2013), Iris falcata Babal. & Papan. is a synonym of Iris attica Boiss. & Heldr (valid name for Iris pumila subsp. attica), whilst Govaerts (2011) consider it an unplaced name.

According to Babalonas and Papanicolaou (1984) Iris falcata is closely related to Iris reichenbachii and Iris suaveolens.

Narcissus alcaracensis S.Ríos, D.Rivera, Alcaraz & Obón is considered a valid species by WCSP (2017), however Fernández Casas (2013) considers it a synonym of Narcissus longispathus Degen & Hervier ex Pugsley. Here, we follow WCSP (2017) and Marques et al. (2017) in considering Narcissus alcaracensis a valid species separate from Narcissus longispathus.

Some records from near to the town of Alcaraz in the Guadalquivir Basin have been historically assigned to this species and are now confirmed to correspond to a different species, Narcissus bujei.

Araneus hortensis has not been found since its description in 1859 (Blackwall 1859). Given the usually easy sampling of similar species, being relatively large orb weavers, and the fact that the single known specimen was captured in a garden, this may be due to either it being a synonym of another, potentially common, species or an species that has been introduced to Madeira.
Not recorded since original description from Madeira with uncertain locality (Kulczyński 1899).

Possible junior synonym of Centromerus sexoculatus Wunderlich, 1992
(Reboleira et al. 2011) which if true could considerably impact the species extinction risk
assessment.

Possible senior synonymy with Centromerus anoculus Wunderlich,
1995 (Reboleira et al. 2011)

Despite intensive searches during the last decade it was not possible to find this species recently described from undetermined locality in the island of Porto Santo (Wunderlich 1992). It probably is a junior synonym of Hogna insularum.

Hogna ingens was described in 1857 by John Blackwall (1857). Despite several taxonomic redescriptions from pioneer arachnologists (Blackwall 1867, Kulczynski 1899, Roewer 1960, Denis 1962 and later Wunderlich 1992), every other aspect of this remarkable species remained unknown until recently (Crespo et al. 2014).
The species is not found since 1962 and needs taxonomic clarification (Denis 1962).
The species belongs in the Theridion sexpunctatum group.
Possible junior synonym of Steatoda paykulliana (Walckenaer, 1806), a widespread palearctic species (Denis 1962).
This species was described based on males only.

Lathyrus odoratus L. is widely cultivated as an ornamental in horticulture (Sarker et al. 2001) but only wild populations are considered in this threat assessment. In its wild form, L. odoratus is a primary wild relative (Gene Pool 1B) of Sweet Pea, the cultivated form of the species, and a tertiary genetic relative (Gene Pool 3) of the cultivated Grass Pea (L. sativus L.) (A. Shehadeh pers. comm. 2018). It is in the section Lathyrus (Shehadeh et al. in prep) and following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 2 of Chickling Vetch (L. cicera L.) (Vincent et al. 2013), and a number of other cultivated Lathyrus species including Broad-leaved Everlasting Pea (L. latifolius L.) and Caley Pea (L. hirsutus L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep). It is also in Taxon Group 4 of Cyprus Vetch (L. ochrus (L.) DC) and other cultivated Lathyrus species including Spanish Vetchling (L. clymenum L.) (Shehadeh et al. in prep).
Many Epizoanthus taxa in the Mediterranean are doubtful. Some studies considers that Epizoanthus tergestinus could be a synonym of E. univittatus (Lorenz, 1860).
Recently the subpopulations in the Sierra de la Sagra (formerly described as Polyommatus sagratrox) have been assigned to this species.
Following Vila et al. (2010), the taxon subbaeticus (from the Sierras de Cazorla y Segura and Sierra de la Sagra) is treated as a subspecies of P. violetae.
The populations in the Pyrenees are by some authors treated as distinct species (E. rondoui).
Considered by some authors as a subspecies of M. occitanica.
Epizoanthus species records in the Mediterranean are doubtful and might correspond to Epizoanthus arenaceus.
Should be Allancastria (see Bollini and Racheli 2012).

There is a lack of taxonomic information on the genus Epizoanthus in the Mediterranean and further taxonomy studies are required, and there is no information to distinguish E. univittatus from the more common species E. arenaceus.
Many Epizoanthus taxa in the Mediterranean are doubtful. Some studies considers that Epizoanthus steueri could be a synonym of E. vatovai (Pax and Lochter, 1935).

The genus name for the Ringed Seal has been moved back and forth between Pusa and Phoca in recent decades. Current usage generally follows Rice’s (1998) classification of Ringed Seals as Pusa hispida with five identified subspecies including the Saimaa Seal, P. h. saimensis (Committee on Taxonomy 2014). Saimaa Seals can be distinguished from their nearest relatives in the Baltic Sea (P. h. botnica) and Lake Ladoga (P. h. ladogensis) based on skull characteristics (Hyvärinen and Nieminen 1990), body sizes (Sipilä and Hyvärinen 1998), and genetics (Palo et al. 2003, Valtonen et al. 2012).

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. It is considered variously as a synonym of Narcissus jonquilla subsp. jonquilloides, of N. jonquilla subsp. willkommii, or Narcissus assoanus. Several morphological characteristics of this plant are rather stable within the known population and represent variability extremes in Narcissus assoanus or Narcissus jonquilla descriptions.

However the taxon is accepted as valid in Portugal (e.g., Carapeto et al. 2017) and we assess the species as valid pending further taxonomic research.

E. Scheuchl and A. Kratochwil (pers. comm. 2014) are working on the clarification of the confused taxonomic and nomenclatural situation in the subgenus Suandrena. While the work is not finished yet, it is already clear that Andrena fratella and Andrena notata are distinct species, rather than subspecies as Warncke regarded them. Andrena fratella does not occur in Europe, while A. notata occurs in Fuerteventura and Lanzarote (Canary Islands, Spain) and A. cyanomicans occurs in Spain, Portugal, Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia.
This and the other two species in the genus Centrolabrus were moved to the genus Symphodus, based on morphological and behavioural evidence (Almada et al. 2002).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimen (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).

The description of Chorthippus smardai lacks clear diagnosis and its distinction from Pseudochorthippus tatrae is problematic. According to its taxonomic affinity, C. smardai should be related to the genus Pseudochorthippus (A. Kristin pers. comm. 2015).
It was previously thought that the taxon authority of this species was (Rungs, 1952). However, Barat (2012) recently indicated that that the correct authority is (Ebner, 1938).
Bolívar (1897-1899) doubted the validity of this species.
There are two subspecies: Ocnerodes brunneri brunneri (Bolívar, 1876) and Ocnerodes brunneri cyanipes Bolívar, 1902.
This species was formerly recorded from Corsica under several different names, including E. magnifica (Costa, 1863), E. schmidti (Fieber, 1961) and E. chabrieri (Charpentier, 1825)
Ramme (1939) described this species as Rhacocleis silvestrii, named after Prof. F. Silvestri-Portici, but it is often cited as Rhacocleis sylvestrii.

The taxonomic status of this species is a matter of debate (Gorochov 2009, 2012). It may be a subspecies of Gryllomorpha dalmatina but this issue has not been definitely settled yet. The taxon was described as Gryllomorpha cretensis by Ramme (1927), however Eades et al. (2014) place the taxon as a subspecies of Gryllomorpha dalmatina Ramme, 1927. Gorochov and Ünal (2012) mentions G. cretensis in the context of G. dalmatina (p.54-55) but the text there states: "The first taxon [i.e. Gryllomorpha cretensis] is insufficiently studied, and its belonging to G. dalmatina is not evident; however, a single female from Crete I., recently studied by us, is similar to Ramme’s description and distinguished from the above-mentioned Turkish specimens as well as from the other Greek and Montenegro specimens by the smaller body size and transversally banded (not spotted) colouration of abdominal dorsum; this is probably a separate subspecies." In addition, the paper itself does not make the new combination. Although future studies may indeed prove this to be a subspecies of G. dalmatina, at present we retain G. cretensis as a species (L. Willemse pers. comm. 2015).
The species was recently moved into the genus Pseudochorthippus by Defaut (2012). It is often referred to as Chorthippus tatrae.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear, as it may possibly be a synonym of Odontopodisma fallax (J. Skejo pers. comm. 2016).

Some records from localities outside Hvar island were thought to belong to B. kaltenbachi, however the females are not distinguishable from B. yersini at the moment and research on their identity is needed. Until then, records outside of Hvar that are based only on females are disregarded here.
This species should be compared with M. hoermanni because according to the analyses performed so far they seem quite similar.
This species is very poorly known from a description based on three specimens. Thus, its systematics and distribution are in need of thorough research.

This species is morphologically different from all other Ramalina species in Macaronesia (Aptroot and Schumm 2008) and elsewhere in the world. See Aptroot and Schumm (2008) for a key to distinguish this species from others.

This is shrubby species growing saxicolous on volcanic rocks. It stands up to 5 cm high, and it adheres to the substrate surface through a holdfast 2-4 mm diam. It is richly branched. Branches are solid, subterete to somewhat complanate, 0-8-1-2(-2) mm wide, often with shortly linear pseudocyphellae, especially near the base, apices with several branching points close together. Soredia absent. Cortex c. 25 um thick, chondroid tissue forming a discontinuous cylinder with a few chondroid strands interconnected across the medulla. Apothecia numerous, lateral, up to 3 mm diam.; spores (few seen) bilocular,
13-14x6 um. Chemistry: Divaricatic acid, triterpenoids, usnic acid. The species belongs to the Ramalina decipiens group (Krog & Osthagen 1980), a group of Macaronesian endemic species.
The species is very morphologically very similar to the also endemic R. jamesii. Main differences are anatomical and chemical. Chondroid tissue is discontinous in R. timdaliana and continuous in R. jamesii filling most of the branches.  Further, different terpenoid patterns are found in both species and salazinic acid is only found in R. jamesii.

The Horrid Ground-weaver (Nothophantes horridus Merrett & Stevens, 1995) is a recently described species of small linyphiid spider (total body length of just 2.5 mm). It is also the only known representative of the genus.

This species was described from the eastern Aegean island of Kos (Baccetti 1992). Baccetti described this species on the basis of the studies of Krimbas (1956a, 1956b, 1960), who found two Gryllotalpa species with different chromosome numbers in Greece. G. krimbasi has 19 chromosomes and Baccetti considered his specimen as typical for this form which was found by Krimbas in many places of the Greek mainland (see map 109a in Willemse 1984). Ingrisch et al. (2006) present further morphological details of krimbasi after material from Fthiotis, Central Greece, with a chromosome number of about 19

Acrometopa cretensis is a species with two subspecies: A. cretensis cretensis and A. cretensis daedali; see also the Orthoptera Species File (orthoptera.speciesfile.org/). This assessment is based on (distribution) data of the species.
This species needs further taxonomic research to identify the differences with M. nonveilleri (the only difference stated so far is its colour).

Zeuner (1941) described Parnassiana tymphrestos from Mt.Timfristos (= Mt. Veluchi, compare Ramme, 1931). Ramme (1951) discussed the possible synonymy of P. tymphrestos and P. coracis but, not being aware that Mt. Korax is close to Mt. Timfristos, and by lack of material of P. tymphrestos, did not solve it, and the matter remains unsolved. For the time being, the material from Mt. Vardhousia recorded under P. tymphrestos in F. Willemse (1980 & 1984) should be transferred to Platycleis (Parnassiana) coracis Ramme, 1920. Likewise a re-evaluation of the population of Mt. Oiti, also arranged under P. tymphrestos in F. Willemse (1973 & 1980) appears necessary.

The identity of Rhacocleis agiostratica is not beyond doubt as the description has been based on juvenile specimens. Adult material is required to compare it with other Rhacocleis species in particular Rhacocleis distinguenda.

Several endemic Corsican grasshoppers were previously described (Omocestus corsicus Chopard, 1924; Omocestus corsicus montanus Chopard, 1924; Omocestus pascuorum Chopard, 1924; Stauroderus incertus Chopard, 1924; Chorthippus chopardi Harz, 1971) and are now considered to belong to Chorthippus corsicus (Defaut 1999), with two subspecies: C. c. corsicus (Chopard, 1924) and C. c. pascuorum (Chopard, 1924). Both taxa overlap in distribution (Braud et al. 2002). In the same way, the morphological distinction is not always easy or possible due to the substantial intra-populational variability.
The identification of Corsican Dolichopoda can be difficult sometimes since some specimens seem to be intermediary between D. bormansi and D. cyrnensis.
The identification of Corsican Dolichopoda can be difficult sometimes as some specimens seem to be intermediary between Dolichopoda bormansi and Dolichopoda cyrnensis.
The taxonomy of this species needs to be studied and compared with other Platycleis species. It is currently not clear whether it represents a synonym or a unique species.
The taxonomy of this species needs to be studied as recent findings suggest that the species is in fact three distinct species (P. Fontana pers. comm 2015).
More research is needed into the taxonomy of this species, since the two  subspecies might represent separate species (P. Fontana pers. comm.  2015).
The two distinct subpopulations of this species are currently considered two subspecies but they may actually be two separate species (P. Fontana pers. comm. 2015).

The taxon was formerly described as a subspecies of Helictochloa pratensis (former name Avenula pratensis) using a single exsiccatum collected by P. Silva et al. in 1966 (Romero-Zarco 1984). The taxon was subsequently studied by Röser (1998), who proved that it is a good isolated species, the westernmost taxon of the Helictochloa pratensis s.l. complex.

It is high polyploid (2n = 126 = 18x), but a misapplied diploid record (2n=14) was published due to confusion with Helictochloa marginata (Castroviejo et al. 2003). In the Sierra de Noguiera both species grow together and can be easily confused (Romero-Zarco 2014).
Zallot et al. (2018) placed this taxon into subgenus Lovcenia (see also Zallot et al. 2015).

Recent molecular evidence (unpublished data, A. Hochkirch pers. comm. 2016) suggests that at least three different genetic lineages exist on the islands of Tenerife, Gran Canaria and La Gomera. Their taxonomic status needs to be studied as they well might represent unique species.
Tartarogryllus sandanski is likely to be a synonym of Tartarogryllus tartarus (Chobanov 2009)
A recent study by López et al. (2013) showed that the former records from North Lanzarote and Montaña Clara belong to a different species, Purpuraria magna.
Recent genetic evidence suggests that unique species may occur on La Gomera and El Hierro (H. López pers. comm. 2015).

The status of this species and its relationship with Canariola willemsei needs to be studied. Both species are flightless, but overlapping ranges have been documented. Canariola willemsei has even been documented from two islands (La Gomera and Tenerife).
This species is sometimes considered a synonym of Eupholidoptera megastyla (Ciplak et al. 2009). However, recent molecular evidence supports the species rank (Allegrucci et al. 2013).

A female record from Troglav Mountain is quite similar to what is regarded as R. buchichii in the literature. However, the true identity is uncertain as far as the subpopulation from Troglav and the subpopulations from islands are not compared morphologically on both sexes and bioacoustically, both on song characters and stridulatory area morphology.
This species shows very similar morphology and song to L. punctatissima, which needs clarification on its taxonomic situation (G. Szovenyi pers. comm. 2016).
This species is probably a synonym of Chorthippus binotatus (Charpentier, 1825) (Presa et al. 2007).
This species is probably a synonym of Chorthippus jacobsi Harz, 1975 (Presa et al. 2007).
There are two subspecies: Podisma carpetana ignatii Morales-Agacino, 1950, and Podisma carpetana carpetana.
There are two subspecies: Eumigus cucullatus almeriensis Bolívar, 1912 and Eumigus cucullatus cucullatus (Bolívar, 1878).
The specific name should be monticola (Llorente del Moral & Presa Asensio, 1997).

There are three subspecies:

  • Eumigus punctatus punctatus (Bolívar, 1902)
  • E. p. calarensis Presa, Llorente del Moral & García, 2000
  • E. p. templadoi Llorente del Moral & Presa, 1986
The species has been moved from the genus Ephippiger Berthold, 1827 by Barat (2012).
There is a subspecies: Canariola emarginata paynei Llucià Pomares & Quiñones, 2013

authority: (Gomez Ladrón de Guevara, Pardo & Llorente del Moral, 1998)
taxonomicNotes: Barat (2012) changed the species from Steropleurus Bolívar, 1878 to the new genus Coracinotus.
This species was changed from Steropleurus Bolívar, 1878 to the new genus Coracinotus by Barat (2012).
This species was changed from the genus Steropleurus Bolívar, 1878 to the new genus Conacinotus by Barat (2012).
Ephippigerida marceti is probably a synonym of E. asella or of E. areolaria (Barat 2012, Olmo 2006, Poniatowski et al. 2010)
This species is probably synonymous with Ephippigerida asella Navás, 1907 or Ephippigerida areolaria (Bolívar, 1877) (Olmo 2006, Poniatowski et al. 2010, Barat 2012).

Taxonomic research is needed in the group of species composed by Lluciapomaresius anapaulae, L. asturiensis and L. nobrei to clearly identify their taxonomic status and the characteristics that distinguish these entities. Lluciapomaredius anapaulae and L. asturiensis are very similar in morphology and bioacustics, while it is not possible to distinguish L. asturiensis from L. nobrei (Pfau and Pfau 2015).

Research is needed to ascertain the validity of this species and its distinction from Lluciapomaresius asturiensis. Available information shows no differentiation between the male songs of both species and a hypothesis for the synonymy of L. asturiensis and L. nobrei exists (Barat, pers. comm. in Pfau and Pfau 2015).
The species was changed from the genus Steropleurus Bolívar, 1878 to the new genus Lluciapomaresius by Barat (2012).
This species was changed from the genus Steropleurus Bolívar, 1878 to the new genus Lluciapomaresius by Barat (2012).
This species was moved from the genus Platycleis Fieber, 1853 to the new genus Montana by Eades et al. (2010).
This species was moved from the genus Callicrania Bolivar, 1898 to Neocallicrania by Barat (2007).
This species was moved from the genus Ephippiger Berthold, 1827 by Barat (2012).

There are two subspecies: Parasteropleurus martorelli martorelli (Bolívar, 1878) and Parasteropleurus martorelli angulatus (Bolívar, 1908). This species was moved from the genus Ephippiger Berthold, 1827 by Barat (2012).
This species was moved from the genus Ephippiger Berthold, 1827 by Barat (2012).
Pycnogaster gurriae Pinedo, 1987 is considered a junior synonym of P. algericensis. Some authors have proposed this species as a subspecies of Pycnogaster finoti (Pinedo and Llorente 1986).
Two subspecies of this species are known: Pycnogaster (Bradygaster) sanchezgomezi sanchezgomezi Bolívar, 1897 and Pycnogaster (Bradygaster) sanchezgomezi constricta Bolívar, 1926.
The species was moved from the genus Ephippigerida Bolívar, 1903 by Barat (2012),
This species was moved from the genus Ephippigerida Bolívar, 1903 by Barat (2012),
There are two subspecies: Steropleurus andalusius andalusius (Rambur, 1838) Steropleurus andalusius levantinus (Bolívar, 1908).
This is probably a misidentification of an exceptionally large specimen of S. brunerii (J.R. Correas pers. comm. 2016).
This species was moved from the genus Callicrania Bolívar, 1898 by Barat (2007).
The validity of Cochlostoma mariannae has been recently confirmed by anatomical and molecular investigations and placed this taxin into the subgenus Turritus (Zallot et al. 2015).

Borredà (2003) indicates that Deroceras roblesi presents morpho-anatomical characteristics that allow to differ it from D. altimirai Altena, 1969, D. levisarcobelum De Winter, 1986 and D. tarracense Altena, 1969, which occurs at the northeast of the Iberian Peninsula. De Winter (1986) proposed the two last taxa as subspecies of D. altimirai and Castillejo, Garrido and Iglesias (1993, 1995) raised these taxa to species, based on anatomical differences. Therefore, it is necessary to perform molecular studies that contribute to clarify the validity or otherwise of the taxa involved.
The validity of the taxon is questioned by Welter-Schultes (2010).
Laciniaria pseudostabilis (Westerlund 1901) is a synonym of L. exalta (see Nordsieck 2008).

Limax strobeli in nor reported by Manganelli et al. (1995), neither by Welter-Schultes (2012), but Bank (2013) includes it in his check list. The species needs a taxonomical revision to assess its validity. Pini (1876) introduced many names for Limax but it is unclear why Bank (2013) considered valid only L. strobeli. Recently the reproductive behavior of specimens named "Limax strobeli" from Bergell (Switzerland, 100 km NE from the locus typicus), has been depicted and described by a group of researchers (Falkenr et al. http://www.schnegel.at/download/pdf/praesentation_badenweiler.pdf) and used it as a taxonomical feature to validate the species.

The species is cliassified in the genus Lindbergia exclusively upon shell features, namely the peculiar microsculpture of the teleoconch and the overall shell shape. The anatomy is unknown. The genus Lindbergia is in need of an overall revision (Gittenberger and Eikenboom 2006).

The Spanish subpopulations of Orculella bulgarica have been assigned by Arrébola et al. (2012) to a separate species O. aragonica Westerlund, 1897, closely allied to O. bulgarica. This separation was based on anatomical (mostly by the particular structure of the penial caecum) and molecular differences, although they are sibling species in shell morphology. Only one subpopulation from Turkey was included in this study. The incorporation of more samples of O. bulgarica from different localities, and particularly DNA sequences of O. bulgarica lamellata, could give more information about the singularities of the Spanish subpopulations.

F. Welter-Schultes argues in AnimalBase (http://www.animalbase.org/ accessed 17.03.2016) that the name Orcula dolium f. aragonica Westerlund, 1897 used by Arrébola et al. (2012) could be unavailable without providing evidence that the name had been used for a species or subspecies before 1985 (Art. 45.6.4.1).

Tandonia bolensis sp. n. is easily distinguishable from other Tandonia species by the dummy-like penial-atrial papilla, and the partially spiral-convoluted, thorny spermatophore. Tandonia bolensis sp.n. is unlikely to be abnormal or mutant by virtue of its peculiar anatomy which shows not a single, but many different peculiar traits (De Mattia and Nardi 2014).

Helix straminea was relegated to a synonym of Helix lucorum Linnaeus, 1758 by Bank (2013), however, due to recent genetic research it is here considered as a species in its own rights (Korábek et al. 2014).

However, there is a taxonomic uncertainty, because there are nominal species of Helix from the Balkans which might turn out to be synonyms of this taxon. Korábek et al. (2014) list for example Helix valdika as a potential younger synonym (listed as a separate species by Neubert (2014)), but postpone a definite decision. If their opinion is correct, this species displays a trans-Adriatic distribution pattern.

Due to this unresolved situation, only the Italian populations of Helix straminea are here assessed.

The shell of Sardopoiretia is similar to that of genus Poiretia but of smaller dimensions, spindle-like with weak radial ribbing on first whorls. Genitalia show a long duct of the bursa copulatrix, a short epiphallus and a long penis without the diverticulum. Sardopoiretia is clearly distinguishable from the closely related Poiretia by virtue of its genital morphology.

Based on the anatomy of the Azorean Ovatella, all records of Ovatella from the Azores are O. vulcani. Hence all former reports of O. aequalis from the Azores must be treated as O. vulcani (A.M. de Frias Martins pers. comm. 2017).

Festuca paucispicula is considered a synonym of Festuca rubra L. by WCSP (2014).

Al-Bermani et al. (1992) include the species in their circumscription of Festuca trichophylla. Recent observations fully confirm this view, and therefore support its dissociation from Festuca rubra L. (S. Pyke pers. comm. 2015).

Unifying these two grasses in one single species would require a new circumscription which we consider unacceptable at present. Genetic studies might help to resolve this question, but their separation on morphological grounds is easy enough for an agrostologist.

The species is dealt with in its strict sense, adhering to the original description and type material. A similar plant is found in the same region which falls outside these morphological boundaries; this second plant has caused some confusion, and is now being treated as a new species, Festuca dertosensis Pyke and Sáez, (S. Pyke pers. comm. 2015, Pyke et al. 2016).

Festuca alfrediana includes three subspecies which are geographically disjunct. These are;

Festuca alfrediana subsp. alfrediana
Festuca alfrediana subsp. durmitorea D.Lakušic & Foggi, and
Festuca alfrediana subsp. ferrariniana Foggi, Parolo & Gr.Rossi.
S. latissima is extremely close to Sorbus andreanszkyana and is possibly a synonym (L. Somlyay and A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016).
Previously referred to as Sorbus bakonyensis Jáv. Here we follow the renaming of this species by Somlyay and Sennikov (2014).
Sorbus buekkensis is a relative of Sorbus haszlinszkyana.
The origin of this species is in need of further research as it is thought to be a hybrid (V. Mikolas pers. comm. 2016).
Kovanda (1996) considered the name to be invalidly published as no holotype was assigned.
This species is sometimes spelt gayerana and that spelling is accepted by The Plant List (2016). Following IPNI (2016) and C. Németh (pers. comm. 2016) we use gayeriana.

The species belongs to the S. graeca sensu lato group (A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016). The species was first described as a forma from the historical region of Transylvania (in present-day Romania) but then raised to species rank and variously interpreted in Hungary, Slovenia and Romania.
This species is considered likely to be a hybrid (S x decipiens). Further research is needed to confirm this (V. Mikolas pers. comm. 2016).
Kovanda (1996) considered the name to be invalidly published as no holotype was assigned.
The distinction between Sorbus lancifolia and Sorbus sognensis need to be established.
Here we refer to Sorbus latifolia sensu stricto, a species endemic to France.
Sorbus latissima is extremely close to Sorbus andreanszkyana and is possibly a synonym (L. Somlyay and A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016).

This assessment refers to the Sorbus pannonica sensu Somlyay and Sennikov (2015) and therefore includes only the Hungarian part of the previous Sorbus pannonica concept. All other records of this species are thought to refer to other species (see Somlyay and Sennikov 2015).

Flow cytometry shows that the type tree is tetraploid, whilst other individuals previously ascribed to S. parviloba are triploid (Pellicer et al. 2012); a reconsideration of its taxonomic status may be required as only one individual is currently known (T. Rich pers. comm. 2016).
There are two forms of this pentaploid species (M. Lepší and T.C.G. Rich pers. comm. 2016)
Named in honour of Prof. Charles Stirton for his work in establishing the National Botanic Garden of Wales.
The European and North African records of this species are now considered to belong to T. gallica (Villar 2017).

The species is an apomictic hybrid. Studies show that S. eminens is a a tetraploid derived from S. aria and S. porrigentiformis.

We follow a more restricted view than originally described by Warburg (1957), as set out in Rich et al. (2010).
The species is apomictic, originating from a cross between S. aria (L.) Crantz and S. rupicola (Syme) Hedl. It is part of the S. porrigentiformis sensu lato group in Britain.
The species is an apomictic product of a cross between S. aucuparia L. and S. rupicola (Syme) Hedl or S. porrigentiformis Warb. sensu lato.
The species is apomictic and a fully fertile hybrid of S. aucuparia L. and S. rupicola (Syme) Hedl.

The species, an apomictic member of the S. latifolia L. complex, is thought to have originated from a hybridisation event between S. pannonica Karpati or S. aria (L.) Crantz and S. torminalis (L.) Crantz.

The species was validly described by Bornmüller in 1918. Düll’s later description from 1961 can be considered superfluous (Meyer 2016).
The parent species are S. arranensis Hedl. and S. aucuparia L. For further details see Robertson et al. (2004).
This is an apomictic species of the S. hybrida complex, originating from a cross between S. aria (L.) Crantz and S. aucuparia L.

Sorbus velebitica is an uncertain taxon that may be part of S. austriaca sensu lato, however S. austriaca has been assessed separately, taking a restricted approach to that taxon. Further study is required to confirm the identity of Sorbus velebitica. Kovanda (1996) considered the name to be invalidly published as no holotype was assigned.

This species was previously thought to occur in the Canary Islands, Madeira and the Azores. The distribution of this species has now been restricted to the Azores and the populations in the Canary Islands and Madeira are considered L. novocanariensis.

Includes two varieties;

Helictochloa hackelii var. hackelii
Helictochloa hackelii var. algarbiensis Romero Zarco
A newly described annual species (Romero-Zarco and Arán 2013), it is akin to Juncus tenageia Ehrh. ex L. fil.
This is an apomictic species of the S. latifolia L. complex, originating from a cross between S. graeca (Spach) Lodd. ex Schauer and S. torminalis (L.) Crantz.
This species is possibly derived from ancient hybridisation between A. fontanum and A. petrarchae.

Oxychilus lanzai was described by Forcart (1976) and placed in the subgenus Oxychilus by virtue of the inner ornamentation of the penis. Later on, it revealed to be a wrong interpretation, as the preparations of genitalia performed by Forcart on glass slides deformed the real structure. The species is now considered to belong to subgenus Ortizius (Manganelli et al. 2004). This species was then regarded as a junior synonym of O. paulucciae by virtue of morphological and molecular studies performed on topotypical material (Manganelli et al. 2004).

In the past, A. terorense was not accepted as a good species and was synonymised with Asplenium ovovatum subsp. billotii. This subspecies is a tetraploid, while one of its parents is a diploid that has been called Asplenium obovatum var. protobillotii, so some experts believe that A. terorense is a synonym of this variety, in which case it would not be a Canarian endemic as it would also be present in mainland Spain, Turkey and probably elsewhere in the Mediterranean (F. Rumsey pers. comm. 2016). For the purposes of this assessment, the Euro+Med checklist is followed (Christenhusz and Raab-Straube 2013), which treats A. terorense as a separate species.

This species is similar to I. todaroana Troìa & Raimondo and some authors (e.g., Peruzzi et al. 2014, Troìa and Greuter 2015) consider the two taxa conspecific. However, for the purposes of this assessment, the Euro+Med checklist is followed (Christenhusz and Raab-Straube 2013, following Ernandes and Marchiori 2012), which treats the two species separately.

This species is similar to I. iapygia Ernandes et al. and some authors (e.g. Peruzzi et al. 2014, Greuter and Troia 2015) consider the two taxa conspecific. The Euro+Med checklist is followed for the purposes of this assessment (Christenhusz and Raab-Straube 2013, which follows Ernandes and Marchiori 2012), which treats the two species separately.

authority: C.Brullo, S.Brullo, Cambria & Giusso Del Galdo

taxonomicNotes: Tandonia marinellii externally resembles Tandonia sowerbyi that is present and widespread in Sicily. The epiphallus in T. marinelli is very long and equipped with an evident proximal portion completely absent in T. sowerbyi. The two species are clearly distinguishable mainly by virtue of the morphology of the genital apparatus. The validity of the specific status has also been confirmed by the genetic distance among COI sequences (Liberto et al. 2012).
This is a diploid species. It is also given for the Canary Islands in the Euro + Med, based on information in Dobignard, A. and Chatelain, C. (2010), but this is based on a past misidentification.

This species was previously considered to belong to the genus Tylimanthus, but was then moved to the genus Acrobolbus. It has been considered by Burghardt and Gradstein (2008) to be a synonym of Tylimanthus laxus. However, some authors still consider it a valid species (Stech et al. 2006, Briscoe et al. 2015, Söderström et al. 2016). Further taxonomic research is needed to clarify the validity of this species.
The allozymic pattern of the allotetrapoloid D. corleyi confirms that it derived from D. aemula and D. oreades (Jiménez et al. 2009).

This is an allotetraploid hybrid species whose parents are D. aemula and D. azorica (Juslén et al. 2011), which result into a double chromosome number and therefore into a new species. The name Dryopteris crispifolia has been used in a uniform way.
This is a diploid species (Juslén et al. 2011).
This species is similar to and sometimes treated as a synonym of the Caribbean species E. hirtum (Sw.) C.Chr.

This species is a recent allopolyploid derived from hybridasition of H. tombrigensii and H. wilsonii. This taxon is difficult to differentiate from its parents and from other hybrids. Most of the records are the result of confusion with the primary hybrid, which is sterile (F. Rumsey pers. comm. 2016).
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

Isoetes boryana falls within the I. longissima/I. velata group (Greuter and Troia 2014), a taxonomically difficult suite of species which merits further research. Prelli (2001) questions the validity of I. boryana as a species, while Romero and Real (2005) propose its treatment as a variety of I. velata. In France, this species is considered valid and similar to I. tenuissima.
Until he description of Isoetes fluitans, this species was usually referred to as I. longissima. However, this is the older name for I. velata A.Braun (Troia and Greuter 2014).
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
This species is formerly known as Cheilanthes pulchella Willd., and not as Allosorus pulchellus C.Presl.

Contrary to the suggestion in the original paper (Alonso et al. 1992), clausliaeformis is most probably not a Sculptiferussacia, which is conchologically a very different African genus. Most probably it has to be described as a subgenus within the not yet named genus of Canarian endemic Ferussaciids. The work on that was in progress (K. Groh pers. comm. 2016) and was confirmed in late 2019, when it was moved from genus Sculptiferussacia to genus Ferussacia (E. Neubert (pers. comm. 2019).
Welter-Schultes (2012) states that the identity of this species should be revised since it is very similar to other species in its genus.
Research is needed into the genus Carychium, as the validity of some species is doubtful. This species may be a synonym of C. mariae (A. Jochum pers. comm. 2016).

This is part of a species complex which is in need of revision. Some authors e.g. Manganelli et al. (1995), and more recently, Nardi (2015) consider the species as part of Zospeum globosum, whilst others (e.g., Bank 2017), have maintained the taxon. G. Nardi (pers. comm. 2017) comments that both Z. cariadeghense and Z. turriculatum have very variable shell shape (there are many intermediate forms between the turriculated shells and the globular shells) and anatomical differences (genitalia) are not found.
The identity of records of this species from Navarra (Escolà and Bech 1986) require confirmation. Altonoga et al. (1994) suggest that the Navarra records may refer to another species.
De Mattia (2003) suggests that this species requires review, and that it may be a form of Z. speleum.
Zospeum galvagnii and Zospeum cariadeghense have both been considered to be synonyms of this taxon by Manganelli et al. (1995), although all three are retained as separate taxa by Bank (2017).

This species was considered by Manganelli et al. (1995) to be part of Z. globosum, but kept by Fauna Europea (R. Bank pers. comm. 2017) as a separate taxon. G. Nardi (pers. comm. 2017) comments that there are no anatomical or shell differences found between this species and G. globosum.

This is part of a species complex which is in need of revision. Some authors e.g. Manganelli et al. (1995), and more recently, Nardi (2015) consider the species as part of Zospeum globosum, whilst others have maintained the taxon. G. Nardi (pers. comm. 2017) comments that both Z. cariadeghense (and Z. turriculatum) have very variable shell shape (there are many intermediate forms between the turriculated shells and the globular shells) and anatomical differences (genitalia) are not found.

Several subspecies have been described for this species. Zospeum alpestre kupitzense is now considered a species (Zospeum kupitzense (A. Stummer, 1984); Jochum et al. 2015).

It has also been proposed that subspecies Zospeum alpestre likanum Bole, 1960 be raised to species level (Slapnik and Ozimec 2004, Weigand 2013), however the taxonomic position of this taxon is unclear, and it should be kept as a subspecies of Z. alpestre until more genetic data are available (E. Neubert pers. comm. 2017).

According to Manganelli et al. (1995) this species is conspecific with Z. globosum. G. Nardi (pers. comm. 2017) comments that there are no anatomical or shell differences found between this species and G. globosum.

Taxonomic experts argue that the specimen used to describe the  species could be distorted, thus the species might be misidentified. Therefore, it is very  likely that it belongs to a different species, with a wider  distribution. In the light of this information, the species could be characterized as Data Deficient (DD).

Deroceras bulgaricum was described after a single specimen only, and it has never been collected again after description (Wiktor 1983). According to Welter-Schultes (2010), the holotype was seriously damaged, and the original description was inaccurate.
Falkner et al. (2001) considered that Wiktor (2000) confirmed the validity of this species.

This species was considered valid by Wiktor (2000), but he noted that it looks like a juvenile of the widespread and common D. reticulatum and can only be confirmed by dissection, so it is maybe under-recorded.

There are morphologically similar taxa that warrant research:
(1) slugs from the island of Montecristo near Elba (Giusti 1976)
(2) slugs from Corsica (Wiktor 2000, Fig. 267)
(3) slugs of D. panormitanum of the cecconii or cecconii var. ilvatica morphs (Giusti 1976) from the Italian mainland and Elba.

Taxonomic experts that have examined the type specimens argue that this specimen could have been misidentified. According to their view, the specimen could belong to another Deroceras species that is found in close-by Aegean Islands (Wiktor 2001).
According to Welter-Schultes (2012) the species should be considered a synonym of D. keaense; however this requires further confirmation. Wiktor (2001) considered it as a valid species.
The genus name Deroceras is of neuter gender, so the species name is spelt keanense.
The species is not considered valid by Welter-Schultes (2010, 2012).
Some authors have placed this as a synonym of the widespread species C. acicula, however Stamol (2010) gives shell characters that separate the two taxa.
The validity of the species has been questioned (Vardinoyannis 1994) and the taxon is also presented as a subspecies of A. corrugata (Welter-Schultes 2010, 2012).

More research is required into the systematic position and validity of this species; see Kornilios et al. (2009), who found that the morphological differentiation between this and some other members of the genus was not reflected at the genetic level.

Riedel (1992) reports that the population on the Avgo Islet off Crete almost certainly represents a new species or subspecies. He also reports Lindbergia sp. (nova) aff. pseudoillyrica from the Island of Iraklia (Cyclades), a form similar with L. pseudoillyrica, which is potentially a new species of the genus, endemic to the Island of Iraklia.
The species is accepted as valid by Nordsieck (2016) but not by Welter-Schultes (2010), who considers it as a form of A. violacea.

Örstan (2014) reported three individuals (one mature and two juvenile) from the Karaburun peninsula on the Turkish coast opposite Chios Island, and tentatively identified them as Vitrea storchi. The specimens are considered here as V. aff. storchi (M. Seddon pers. comm. 2017). The identity of these records requires confirmation.
The validity of the species has been questioned (Welter-Schultes 2010, 2012).
Vardinoyannis (1994) and Welter-Schultes (2010) raise some doubts about  the taxonomic validity of the species, which has to be further  explored.
The species is accepted as valid by Nordsieck (2016) but not by Welter-Schultes (2010), who considers it as a form of A. cretensis.
Welter-Schultes (2010, 2012) questions the taxonomic validity of the species considering it as part of A. cretensis. However Welter-Schultes (2013) lists them as different.
Welter-Schultes (2012) suggested that this species may be a form of V. neglecta.
A. unicolor from Saria Island is now considered a separate species.
More detailed studies are required to resolve the systematic position of the taxon.

authority: A. Reischütz, N. Reischütz & P.L. Reischütz, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Following the review of the type series of Cionella disparata Westerlund, 1891 by Martínez-Ortí (2002) and the type series of Ferussacia eucharista Bourguignat, 1864 by Falkner et al. (2002), the species is placed here in the genus Hohenwartiana.
Previously this species was considered a synonym of Ophioblennius steindachneri (Hastings and Springer 2009).
The species was assigned to the genus Roeseliana (from Metrioptera) by Song et al. (2015).

This species has not been recorded or studied since its original description, and as it appears in the Marine List of Europe (CLEMAM) and Gofas (2015) it may be a marine species. This taxon was not mentioned in the revision of the genus Assiminea by Aartsen (2008). Beckmann (2007) indicates that it has not found it. Gofas (2015) indicates that it is a dubious species or inquerendum (under enquiry). Given the impossibility of collecting alive specimens a study of the type series of this species is recommended, since it has not been done before, and perhaps it can help solve its taxonomic status.
This taxon is believed to be the nominal subspecies A. g. guerianus.

This species was previously considered to belong to the genus Tylimanthus, but was then moved to the genus Acrobolbus. It has been considered by Burghardt and Gradstein (2008) to be a synonym of Tylimanthus laxus. However, some authors still consider it a valid species (Söderström et al. 2016, Stech et al. 2006). Further taxonomic research is needed to clarify the validity of this species.
Although apparently published in 2003, the volume of the journal where this species was published did not appear until 29 July 2004.
Since polyploidisation, hybridization, and apomixis are frequent in Sorbus, further studies are needed to understand the genetic relationships of this microspecies (A. Troia pers. comm. 2016).
This species has been considered under the name Sorbus dacica Borbás for many years until Somlyay and Sennikov (2016) resurrected the name S. semipinnata Borbás.

It has been confirmed as a valid species through a morphological (shell characters and anatomy of the reproductive system) and genetic (sequencing of a fragment of the mitochondrial large ribosomal subunit 16S rRNA, and the nuclear internal transcriber spacer 1, ITS-1 rRNA) study (Giusti et al. 1995).

Originally placed in genus Imitatrix, this genus was later found to be so close to Lampedusa that no generic dichotomy was needed. It is distinguished from the other species of the genus by virtue of its peculiar buccal pleats and lamellae arrangement. The species has been cited with two more subspecies (L. i. gattoi and L. i. emersoniana) that are now considered as junior synonyms (Giusti et al. 1995).

Wiktor (2000) suggested that this form should be considered a synonym of D. panormitanum until further evidence is provided that this could be a separate species. Apart from its evenly black colour, nothing was given that would make a difference to D. panormitanum (Welter-Schultes 2012). Reise et al. (2011) considered D. dallaii as a good species without giving any additional justification or information. Welter-Schultes (2012) in fact did not took into account their unjustified opinion.

Deroceras giustianum, described from Erice (Sicily) is considered a junior synonym of. D. panormitanum by Reise et al. (2011), stating that the morphology of D. giustianum falls into the high variability shown by the older species. On the other hand, other authors (Welther-Schultes, 2012; Bank, 2013) still keep D. giustianum as a valid species in the checklists.

The only population of Sorbus pelsoensis had been originally identified as S. udvardyana (Bauer 2015). It seems to be little different, if at all, from the latter species (L. Somlyay and A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016).

The genus Zelkova includes only six species, three of which grow in eastern Asia, one in Transcaucasia, and two in the Mediterranean basin (this species in Sicily and another, Z. abelicea, which is a threatened species endemic to the mountains of Crete (Greece) (Kozlowski and Gratzfeld 2013).

This species is considered a synonym of the widespread Betula pubescens Ehrh. by The Plant List (2017), or as a synonym of the widespread B. alba  (Moreno and Peinado 1990, SIVIM 2017) and it has been questioned whether this taxon should be recognized as a distinct species. However, its geographical isolation and the fact that it can be distinguished morphologically suggest that it is worth recognising. In Flora Iberica, Peinado and Mereno (1990) did not distinguish it from Betula alba and this is also stated in López González (2001). However, it is equally out of place in B. pendula. In fact, it is probably most similar to another 'species' of established hybrid origin, the eastern North American B. x caerulea. It is recognized that further research is needed to clarify the status of this species.
There are at least two morphologically similar species that still remain to be described. Here, we are treating Sorbus herbipolitana in the narrow sense.

Further taxonomic study is required to confirm the separation of S. pseudosemiincia and S. pyricarpa. The two taxa were described from material collected in the same localities, and the morphological difference between the type specimens is unclear.
Since polyploidisation, hybridization, and apomixis are frequent in Sorbus, further studies are needed to understand the genetic relationships of this microspecies (A. Troia pers. comm. 2016).
This species is, following the botanical code, correctly named 'pontis-satanae' rather than 'pontis-satani' (M. Lepší pers. comm. 2016).
The species is considered a synonym of G. tricuspidata in Flora Iberica and in López González (2001).
The phylogenetic review of Sennikov and Kurtto (2017) placed this species within the new genus Normeyera Sennikov & Kurtto, with other taxa from Sorbus subgen. Chamsoraria Májovský & Bernátová.
This name has commonly been misapplied to Cotoneaster tomentosus (Aiton) Lindl.

This species is considered valid as Malva acerifolia (Cav.) Alef. by Euro+Med Plantbase (Valdés 2011).

Individuals from the eastern Canaries are considered a separate variety (var. hariensis Svent.; S. Scholz pers. comm. 2017).

For Muticaria macrostoma a number of subspecific taxa have been described:  M. m. oscitans,  M. m. scalaris and M. m. mamotica (Beckmann 1987). Giusti et al. (1995) did not follow any subspecific ranking while Bank (2013) again considered the subspecific taxa in his checklist. For a complete review of the M. macrostoma subspecies see Giusti et al. (1995: 356 and following).

Sorbus meinichii was originally described from western Norway, and has also been taken as a name for a larger species group that included specimens from Sweden, Finland and Latvia which are here described under the name Sorbus teodori.

Taxonomic studies in progress by the Arboretum and Botanical Garden of the University of Bergen (Norway) and in Sweden indicate that both species are likely to have to be split further (P.H. Salvesen pers. comm. 2016, Artdatabanken 2016).

Sorbus meinichii is a highly variable apomictic species, comprising when taken in a wide sense, triploid as well as tetraploid populations in Norway, and triploid populations in Sweden and Finland. It should possibly be split into several species in the future (Grundt and Salvensen 2011, Salvesen 2012, P.H. Salvesen pers. comm. 2016).

Alosterna pauli Pesarini, Rapuzzi & Sabbadini, 2004 was described in the group of species related to A. anatolica Adlbauer, 1992 and A. tabacicolor (De Geer, 1775) (Adlbauer 1992, Pesarini and Sabbadini 2004). It differs from them on the basis of strong elements while the description paper gives precise drawings. Some mistakes remain in the documentation, like in Fauna Europaea where the description date is 2003 (De Jong et al. 2014) or wrong bibliographic reference for the description (Tavakilian and Chevillotte 2012).

Xestoleptura nigroflava (Fuss, 1852) is very close to the related Siberian species X. rufiventris (Gebler, 1830). For its original descriptions, Fuss (1852) probably did not know this species and did not provide a differential diagnosis (Kadlec and Hajek 2005). Therefore, many subsequent authors have considered the description to be a misinterpretation of another species: Evodinus borealis (Gyllenhal, 1827), Brachyta variabilis (Gebler, 1817), Brachyta borni (Ganglbauer, 1903) or Xestoleptura rufiventris. This last synonymy was largely accepted until now. However, Kadlec and Hajek (2005) collected a male near the Type locality, and have compared it with the Type specimen and with Siberian specimens of X. rufiventris. This has made it possible to strongly establish the true specific identity of X. nigroflava. This opinion is accepted by Danilevsky (2015).

The taxonomic position of the genus Schurmannia is unclear but is most probably a synonym of Alocerus, as Švácha and Danilevsky (1987) first confirmed the strong similarity between the larvae of A. moesiacus and S. sicula. Then Holzschuh (1995), proposed a new combination, Alocerus siculus, but this was not considered by subsequent authors.
As this species is only known from the holotype, taxonomical work is required to confirm the status of this species.

The taxonomy of the genus Zannichellia is complex, with one species recognised throughout much of the World but with many taxa recognised at or below species level in different regions. The distinguishing characters for some taxa appear to be useful, but others appear to have been described based on very few samples and relatively minor morphological differences.

Zannichellia melitensis is treated by Kew as a synonym of Zannichellia palustris subsp. palustris (WCSP 2016), however we follow Euro+Med Plantbase (Uotila 2009) in accepting its species status.

This species was described in 2015, based on genetic analysis (Vanderpoorten et al. 2015), since it is challenging to identify on morphological grounds. Furthermore, the authors suggest that previous reports of four Rhynchostegiella species from the Azores are erroneous and that a single, morphologically variable species, R. azorica, occurs in the archipelago (Vanderpoorten et al. 2015). At the present, this species (R. a.) is considered valid, and is therefore assessed.
Vanderpoorten et al. (2015), suggests that in the Azores, all records of the genus Rhynchostegiella are R. azorica.

Vanderpoorten et al. (2011: p. 346), suggest that "... and Trematodon perssoniorum, are of doubtful taxonomic status and are likely to be conspecific with the widespread ... T. longicollis (Rumsey, unpubl. data)...". The similarity between both taxa was already recognized by Valentine Allorge (1951: 181), when she describes the endemic species: "Cette espèce se rapproche, à première vue, de Trematodon longicollis Michaux", however, she proceeds listing a number of differences between both species, mostly including the smaller size of the Azorean plants, including the size of stomates and spores (21-30 um vs. 50 um). However, recent morphometric studies of T. longicollis, show that the range of spore size is between 24.0-29.6 um (Luizi-Ponzo and Barth 1998, Schwarz 2014). It is thus important that T. perssoniorium is subject to molecular analysis to understand its true taxonomic nature. However, since it was recognized by Hodgetts (2015), and in spite of the uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of this species, it is considered a valid species here.

Recent molecular work by Olsson et al. (2009) suggests that while Thamnobryum fernandesii is a distinct entity, colonies may originate from surrounding colonies of T. alopecurum. Authors differ in opinion on this subject, but for the purposes of this assessment, this is considered a valid species (Sergio et al. 2008, Hodgetts 2015).

Recent molecular work by Olsson et al. (2009) suggests that while T. rudolphiagum is a distinct entity, with a “unique plastid sequence with two autapomorphic substitutions” some of their colonies may originate from surrounding T. alopecurum. Authors differ in their opinion on this subject, but for the purposes of this assessment, this is considered a valid species (Gabriel et al. 2010, Hodgetts 2015).

According to Andrews (1941: p. 99), "... S. nitidulum Warnst. from the Azores is evidently S. capillaceum var. tenellum (Schimp.) Andr. (= S. rubellum Wils.).". However, this species has been considered in several checklists (e.g., Corley et al. 1982, Eggers 1982, Sjögren 2001, Gabriel et al. 2005, 2010) but its status was considered "insufficient" by Crosby (1999), because it was not revised since its pre-1963 publication. Besides, Vanderpoorten et al. (2011: p. 346), suggest that "... Sphagnum nitidulum, ..., are of doubtful taxonomic status and are likely to be conspecific with the widespread ... S. rubellum ... (B. Goffinet pers. comm.)...". The endemic taxa was considered an obscure species due to the presumed destruction of the type (Hill et al. 2006). Many of the Sphagnum species described by Warnstorf have been reduced to synonymy and a critical taxonomic revision of this species is needed. 

However, C. Sérgio and R. Gabriel have seen and photographed the type in 1991, and have recognized some constancy of features such as the stem colour (yellowish-pink), that reappears in several collections over time (LISU, AZU). All the seen samples are taken from the type locality (fumaroles, Furnas do Enxofre). In MOBOT there is a register made by William D. Reese (MO-2465) in Vermont-Lamoille (USA), which could be an erroneous reference of the species. It is thus important that S. nitidulum is subject to molecular analysis to understand its true taxonomic nature.

Since the plant occurs in a very particular aquatic habitat and one locality, it has been suggested that Cinclidotus vivesii may be a variety or an ecological form of C. fontinaloides (M. Brugués and J. Guerra pers. comm. 2018). Plants are aquatic, large and robust, rigid, to 6 cm long, not denudate at base, with reddish-brownish smooth rhizoids. Leaves are lanceolate, plane, straight, slightly incurved or falciform when dry obtuse or acute, margin plane, thick, of (2-)4-6-stratose, confluent at the leaf apex; nerve excurrent in mucro 170-180(-230) μm wide at leaf base gradually narrowed to the apex, here 40-50 μm wide, excurrent in a thick mucro. Sterile.

authority: (J. Guerra, J.F. Jiménez & J.A. Jiménez) Draper, González-Mancebo, O. Werner, J. Patiño & Ros
taxonomicNotes: This species in Spain was discovered for the first time in 1980 (Guerra et al. 1980), but erroneously named as Neckera intermedia Brid., a Macaronesian species. However, this moss was later described as the new species N. baetica (Guerra et al. 2010) and was subsequently published as a new genus Exsertotheca by Draper et al. (2011).

Plants are minute, to 0.2 cm tall. Leaves are oblong-ovate to oblong-lanceolate, concave, margin plane; upper and middle laminal cells quadrate or rounded to rectangular, 6-10 μm wide, papillose; nerve excurrent in mucro or apiculus, prominent on dorsal side, with dorsal and ventral stereid bands. Capsule, globose, brownish, indehiscent and immersed with short apiculus.

authority: (J. Guerra, J.J. Martínez & Ros) R.H. Zander

taxonomicNotes: This species was described on the basis of a single herbarium specimen collected in 1946 from the Krkonose Mountains in the Czech Republic (Ochyra and Bednarek-Ochyra 1999). However, the validity of this species is in question, as it is believed to be a habitat modification of a common species, Rhynchostegium riparioides.

Hypnum aemulans is endemic to Austria, and is known from only two localities in the province of Salzburg (Limpricht 1904). This species is closely related to H. callichroum, H. holmenii and H. hamulosum. Ando (1994)  treats it as a good species. As this species has not been seen for over 100 years, and fieldwork is urgently needed to see if it still exists, a targeted study on the distribution, population size, threats and taxonomic value of this species will be necessary.

authority: Enroth, A. Sotiaux, D. Quandt & Vanderp.

taxonomicNotes: DNA barcoding studies have shown that H. borealis is a Scottish endemic, and Norwegian plants that were previously considered to be this species have been transferred to H. norenus (Bell et al. 2012, Bell and Long 2012). Suggestions that H. borealis is synonymous with the African and Azorean H. dicranus (Taylor) Trevis. (Hodgetts 2003) or the Asian H. delavayi (Feldberg and Heinrichs 2005, Hill et al. 2008), have not been confirmed by these DNA studies.

Thamnobryum angustifolium was discovered in Derbyshire by G.A. Holt in 1883, where it still  occurs. The Cumbria site was discovered in 2008 by M. Lawley. There has been much discussion about the nature of this species. Furness and Gilbert (1980) showed that it maintains its characters distinct from T. alopecurum in culture. There are at least three distinct morphological features that distinguish this species from T. alopecurum. Hodgetts and Blockeel (1992) considered that it is more closely related to T. cataractarum and the Madeiran T. fernandesii than to T. alopecurum.

However, more recent molecular work by Olsson et al. (2009) suggests that, while T. angustifolium is undoubtedly a distinct entity morphologically, colonies of this plant (and of other narrowly endemic Thamnobryum species) may originate from the surrounding subpopulations of T. alopecurum. In this case, the two subpopulations of T. angustifolium are independently derived from local T. alopecurum, and have evolved convergently in response to the rheophilous habitat (Blockeel et al. 2014).
