F. Rumsey (pers. comm. 2016) comments, "My view is that if T. angustifolium and T. cataractarum are retained [as species] then the material from the River Eden also needs to be given the same rank. Each represent local variations from T. alopecurum. To suggest that the Eden material is more similar genetically, etc. to the Cressbrookdale plant than it is to local T. alopecurum, or to T. cataractarum is I believe wrong.".

Thamnobryum cataractarum was discovered in 1991 in Twisleton Glen, a locality well known for oceanic bryophytes (Hodgetts and Blockeel 1992). It is morphologically close to the Madeiran T. fernandesii.

Olsson et al. (2009) used molecular techniques to suggest that, like T. angustifolium, T. cataractarum and T. fernandesii may both be independent local derivatives of T. alopecurum, evolving convergently in response to their habitat (Blockeel et al. 2014).

F. Rumsey (pers. comm. 2016) commented, "My view is that if T. angustifolium and T. cataractarum are retained [as species] then the material from by the R. Eden also needs to be given the same rank. Each represent local variations from T. alopecurum. To suggest that the Eden material is more similar genetically, etc. to the Cressbrookdale plant than it is to local T. alopecurum, or to T. cataractarum is I believe wrong."

This is a recently described species (Bosanquet and Lara 2012). While currently accepted as a species, it is possible that it is no more than a mutant form of O. tenellum (M.O. Hill and C.D. Preston in Blockeel et al. 2014).

This species has been named as A. maritimus by many Spanish botanists, but there is a conflict because some populations of A. maritimus seem to belong to S. tricophilus Bunge and some other populations to S. macrorrhizus. This latter one is located around Mar Menor, southeastern Spain (Pedrol 2013).

In 1985, Sláma described Brachyleptura martini from Crete. However, the name was preoccupied by Leptura semirufula var. martini (Pic, 1945) described from Madrid, and thereafter synonym of Stictoleptura trisignata (Fairmaire, 1852). So, when Brachyleptura was included in the new genus Stictoleptura, the species of Sláma was changed to S. slamai Sama, 2010.

The assessment follows the taxonomy proposed by Brullo et al. (2009) in accepting Allium vernale. The taxon is considered a synonym of Allium subvillosum Salzm. ex Schult. & Schult.f. by some resources (e.g., WCSP 2016).

Allium panormitanum is quite related to A. cupani, although the two species significantly differ in several features. Firstly, A. panormitanum is a typical autumn-flowering (September-November) geophyte, whereas A. cupani flowers from late spring to summer (June-August). Then, A. panormitanum shows higher stem (20-30 cm), apiculate spathe with 5-9 complete nerves, bigger perigon (c. 8-9 mm) and papillose-rugose ovary, while A. cupani is characterized by a shorter stem (8-20 cm), appendiculate spathe with 3-5 complete plus 2 incomplete lateral nerves, smaller perigon (c. 6-7.5 mm) and entirely smooth ovary” (Brullo et al. 2015).
Populations of this species belonging to the Allium cupani group were previously referred to A. hirtovaginatum but described as a separate species by Brullo et al. (2015).
Allium rubrovittatum may be conspecific with A. curtum and further taxonomic study is required.

Fritillaria rhodocanakis hybridizes with Fritillaria spetsiotica in the southern part of Argolida up to Poros Island, and with Fritillaria graeca at the north part of Argolida and at Korinthia. As a result, throughout its distribution on mainland Peloponnisos where it forms scattered, small population patches, F. rhodocanakis has variable populations with morphological characters intermediate between the different species.

Fritillaria rhodocanakis subsp. argolica is distributed in eastern Peloponnisos and is considered a hybrid of F. r. rhodocanakis and Fritillaria graeca as well as other species distributed in the Peloponnisos. For this assessment, only Fritillaria rhodocanakis subsp. rhodocanakis has been considered (P. Trigas pers. comm. 2016).

There are two well-differentiated clades (a northern one and a southern one); their genetic difference is similar to that separating the other species of European cave salamanders (Carranza et al. 2007).

This species was separated from Lyciasalamandra luschani by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).

The three main recognised phyloclades are highly differentiated from each other, despite relatively small geographical distances among them (Veith et al. 2020).

authority: Lanza, Leo, Forti, Cimmaruta, Caputo & Nascetti, 2001
taxonomicNotes: Lanza et al. (2001) described this taxon as a subspecies of Speleomantes imperialis, but it was elevated to species status by Carranza et al. (2007).
We follow Mattoccia et al. (2005) and Canestrelli et al. (2006) in separating Salamandrina perspicillata from S. terdigitata.
We follow Mattoccia et al. (2005) and Canestrelli et al. (2006) in separating Salamandrina perspicillata from S. terdigitata.
Lanza et al. (2001) described Speleomantes imperialis sarrabusensis, but it was elevated to full species status by Carranza et al. (2007).

Gagea pseudopeduncularis is morphologically very similar from Gagea peduncularis (J.Presl & C.Presl) Pascher and its existence was revealed only by recent molecular analyses (Tison et al. 2013). Subsequently to the latter, some morphological markers have been defined (shorter pedicels, smaller and less acute tepals) but these need to be exploited at the larger scale, especially on the ground.

The name Gagea polymorpha Boiss. was traditionally used in a very broad and blurred sense, noticeably including G. lacaitae. However, its typification (Tison 2004) allowed to give it a precise meaning. The species is taxonomically close to G. durieui (Parl.) Parl. and the available molecular data do not separate them, but their morphology and leaf anatomy are clearly distinct (Tison 2004, Tison et al. 2013).
Following the gender of the species name, the correct spelling of the species is dracofolia (A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016).
Following the gender of the species name, the correct spelling of the species is acutiserrata rather than acutiserratus (A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016).
All analysed individuals showed different CCR patterns. Further research is needed to determine the taxonomy of this species (Gömöry and Krajmerová 2008)
It is thought that this taxon could be similarly taxonomically uncertain as S. haljamovae (see taxonomic note for that species) (V. Mikolas and M. Lepsi pers. comm. 2016).

Formerly referred to as Sorbus majeri Barabits, that name has recently been considered to be illegitimate (Somlyay and Sennikov 2014). Information within the assessment from Németh (2013), was given under the name of S. majeri.
Placed within the subgenus Petrochilosina. The species name was erroneously spelled 'octhoniai' in the title, abstract and discussion of the describing paper (Alexiou et al. 2015).

authority: Prieto, de Winter, Weigand, Gómez & Jochum, 2015
Prieto, de Winter, Weigand, Gómez & Jochum, 2015

taxonomicNotes: Sorbus vajdae is a relative of S. hazslinszkyana.

This species was described in Slovakia and since then has been reported from many places in Hungary and in Austria. These records have now been identified as erroneous and the species returns to being a Slovakian endemic (Somlyay and Sennikov 2016, in prep.).

This species is a synonym of Sorbus austriaca subsp. hazslinszkyana (Soó) Kárpáti according to Kurtto (2009) however this requires confirmation.

A record from Hungary is doubtful and may refer to Sorbus buekkensis (A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016).
Sorbus zolyomii is a relative of S. hazslinszkyana.

This is part of an unresolved hybrid complex of S. aria sensu lata known from old collections only. The known locality has been revisited but it can not yet be satisfactorily identified in the field (A. Sennikov pers. comm. 2016). Kovanda (1996) considered the name to be invalidly published as no holotype was assigned.
The distinction between Sorbus lancifolia and Sorbus sognensis need to be established.
This species was described from empty shells only, thus the anatomy of the soft tissues and the operculum are unknown (Torres Alba 2012).
According to Fehér and Szekeres (2016) there is one subspecies in addition to the nominate subspecies: Montenegrina attemsi jakupicensis Fauer, 1993
According to Fehér and Szekeres (2016) its subspecies is: Montenegrina prokletiana subsp. kovacsorum Fehér and Szekeres, 2016

According to Fehér and Szekeres (2016) its subspecies are:

Montenegrina okolensis caesia Fehér and Szekeres, 2006

Nordsieck (2009) considered M. okolensis a synonym of M. caesia Fehér and Szekeres, 2006. New M. okolensis samples confirm the stability of the morphological differences between the two taxa.
Originally M. o. okolensis and M. o. caesia were described as subspecies M. apfelbecki, with which they share similar plicae. However, their reduced clausiliar apparatus and isolated occurrence support their classification within a separate species, which seems more closely related to other north Albanian representatives of the genus (e.g. M. prokletiana sp. n.).

According to Fehér and Szekeres (2016) its subspecies are:

Montenegrina sturanyana gropana Fehér & Szekeres, 2016
Montenegrina sturanyana ostrovicensis Fehér & Szekeres, 2016

According to Fehér and Szekeres (2016) its subspecies are:

Montenegrina tomorosi ampla Fehér & Szekeres, 2006
Montenegrina tomorosi hunyadii Fehér & Szekeres, 2016
Montenegrina tomorosi coerulescens Nordsieck, 1996
This species was previously considered a subspecies of Alopia glorifica, but raised to species level following revision of the genus by Fehér et al. (2013).

This species was previously considered a subspecies of Alopia subcosticollis, but raised to species level following revision of the genus by Fehér et al. (2013). According to the same study, A. grossuana nemethi Deli and Szekeres, 2011 is a subspecies of A. grossuana.

This species was previously considered a subspecies of Alopia glorifica, but was raised to species level following revision of the genus by Fehér et al. (2013). According to the same study, Alopia mafteiana has two subspecies: A. mafteiana mafteiana Grossu, 1867 and A. mafteiana valeriae Szekeres, 2007.

This species was previously considered a subspecies of Alopia subcosticollis, but was raised to species level following revision of the genus by Fehér et al. (2013). According to the same study, this species has four subspecies: A. mariae coronata R. Kimakowicz, 1943, A. mariae hildegardae R. Kimakowicz, 1931, A. mariae mariae R. Kimakowicz, 1931, A. mariae soosi Brandt, 1961.

This species was previously considered a subspecies of Alopia plumbea, but was raised to species level following revision of the genus by Fehér et al. (2013).

According to the same study the following subspecies belong to Alopia regalis: A. regalis deubeli (Clessin, 1890), A. regalis doftanae Nordsieck, 1977, A. regalis glabriuscula (Rossmässler, 1859), A. regalis microstoma (M. Kimakowicz, 1883), A. regalis mutabilis (M. Kimakowicz, 1894), A. regalis nordsiecki Grossu & Tesio, 1973, A. regalis petrensis Nordsieck, 1995, A. regalis proclivis (M. Kimakowicz, 1894),A. regalis regalis (M. Bielz, 1851), A. regalis wagneri (M. Kimakowicz, 1894).

According to Fehér and Szekeres (2016) its subspecies are:

Montenegrina nana gracilis Fehér & Szekeres, 2006
Montenegrina nana barinai Fehér & Szekeres, 2016

M. nana, which was formerly classified as a subspecies of M. perstriata, differs from this species by its smaller size, oblique peristome, and deeper inflexed neck. One of the subspecies, M. n. barinai, occurs syntopically and does not hybridize with M. perstriata ochridensis, indicating that they are distinct species.
The species is considered a synonym of Malva oblongifolia (Boiss.) Soldano & al. by Euro+Med Plantbase (Valdés 2011).
The species (as Thymelaea velutina (Pourr. ex Cambess.) Endl.) is considered a synonym of Thymelaea myrtifolia (Poir.) D.A.Webb. by The Plant List (2016).
Some authors question the validity of this taxon, and it is sometimes treated as Ulex parviflorus.
Originally described as a hybrid between S. aria and S. porrigentiformis (Rich et al. 2009), the species is now considered a valid species (T. Rich pers. comm. 2016).
This taxon has recently being downgraded to a subspecies of Alopia subcosticollis (E. Neubert pers. comm. 2016). It is still regarded as a species by Bank (2017).
This species was originally treated under "36: Sorbus un-named taxon" in Rich et al. (2010).

authority: Fritz, Fattizzo, Guicking, Tripepi, Pennisi, Lenk, Joger & Wink, 2005
taxonomicNotes:
The species was described by Fritz et al. (2005) as a full species in the Emys orbicularis complex, based on molecular distinction; the species is also morphologically indistinct.

Spinks and Shaffer (2009) found E. trinacris to nest within E. orbicularis when using nuclear DNA, however, when mtDNA was used, it appeared to be in a separate clade.

The Taxonomic Committee of the Societas Europaea Herpetologica (Speybroeck et al. 2020) suggested taking a conservative stance and treated E. trinacris as a subspecies of E. orbicularis, pending further studies to resolve the complicated relationships of the Emys complex. This assessment follows Rhodin et al. (2021) in placing E. trinacris and E. orbicularis as separate species.
This species is sometimes treated as a synonym of Isoetes longissima (= I. velata) or I. fluitans.
This taxon is an allotetraploid hybrid apomictic species, between the apomictic diploid D. affinis and the tetraploid sexual D. tyrrhena (Fraser-Jenkins 1981, Fraser-Jenkins and Widén 1993).
Testroet et al. (2013) found there to be almost no genetic diversity amongst specimens collected.
Pyrus castribonensis Raimondo, Schicchi & Mazzola is a wild relative of pear, P. communis L. subsp. communis. It is considered a preliminarily accepted species in Euro+Med PlantBase (Kurtto 2009).

authority: (Casper) Roccia, Gluch, Lampard, A.S.Rob., A.Fleischm., S.McPherson, L.Legendre, Partrat & P.Temple

taxonomicNotes: The species was placed in a new genus, Wollastonaria, by De Mattia et al. (2018a,b).
The species was placed in a new genus, Wollastonaria, by De Mattia et al. (2018a,b).

authority: Neiber, R. Vega-Luz, Ro. Vega-Luz & Koenemann, 2011
taxonomicNotes: This is a recently described species.

authority: D. Holyoak, G. Holyoak, Yanes, Santana, García, Castro, Artiles, Alonso & Ibáñez, 2014
taxonomicNotes: The genus Vermetum was moved from Gastrodontidae to Pristilomatidae (Holyoak et al. 2014).

This taxon is included in a list of Sorbus species described by Kárpáti that are considered to be invalidly published by Kovanda (1996) as no holotype was assigned. A holotype was assigned by C. Németh (2010).

This taxon is included in a list of Sorbus species described by Kárpáti that were considered to be invalidly published by Kovanda (1996) as no holotype was assigned. A holotype was assigned by Németh (2010).
This taxon was often erroneously placed under I. setacea or I. echinospora, but it represents a separate taxon (Troìa and Greuter 2015).

Olea maderensis (Lowe) Rivas Mart. & del Arco is considered a synonym of Olea europaea subsp. cerasiformis G.Kunkel & Sunding by WCSP (2017).

Olea maderensis (Lowe) Rivas Mart. & del Arco is a tertiary wild relative of the cultivated olive, Olea europaea L.
Crataegus sericea is, according to Christensen (1992), a hybrid (C. monogyna × C. orientalis subsp. orientalis).

A. anisochilus is very similar to A. lainzii (which is itself sometimes treated as synonym of A. complicatus subsp. parvifolius) to the extent that Ginés López González (2001) suggests that it should be included as synonymous to it. The Plant List (2016) considers this species to be a subspecies of Adenocarpus complicatus (L.) Gay. However, it is considered as a valid species in Flora Iberica (Castroviejo 1999).

The plants of the Madeiran interior were considered different than the coastal ones, identified as Teline paivae (Lowe) Gibbs & Dingwall, but do not seem worthy of separation, since the plants occupying the northern coastal trip from Seixal eastwards to Sao Jorge constitute a range of intermediates (Cannon and Turland 1994). Due to the discrepancy in the taxonomy, for this assessment, the treatment of Lewis et al. (2005), Legumes of the World, where Genista is the genus name which has been followed.
Cotoneaster cambricus is considered by some to be merely a synonym of the widespread C. integerrimus.

The species is considered 'Preliminary Accepted' in Euro+Med (Sennikov 2009), as there are still taxonomic doubts. This group has not been studied sufficiently in Europe, and more information is needed on the origin of this population.
This species is considered "Preliminary Accepted" in Euro+Med (Sennikov 2009).

Susanna de la Serna (1987) proposed placing this species within the monotypic distinct genus Femeniasia based its outstanding position within the Cardueae tribe and the Centaureinae subtribe. Although widely followed, we at present maintain the species within Carthamus following Greuter (2006-2009).

Some scientists consider this species part of a larger family, the  Saxifragaceae, in which saxifrage- and currant-like species are grouped  together. Others prefer to split such large groups up, preferring to  work with more clearly defined smaller families (e.g. the currant family  Grossulariaceae).

Although Pleurotus nebrodensis demonstrates a (low) in vitro intercompatibility with P. eryngii, a study by Zervakis et al. (2014) using ecomorphological characters and sequencing results advocates for its continued recognition as a distinct species. It is associated with Prangos ferulacea only, but the Zervakis et al. (2014) study indicates that its distribution is not restricted to Sicily (as previously believed) but extends to southern continental Greece and to west Asia as well on the basis of molecular data. The name ‘Pleurotus fossulatus’ previously used to accommodate white-pilei Pleurotus growing on Pr. ferulacea from western and central Asia has been replaced by P. nebrodensis subsp. fossulatus  since specimens described under the former name are linked to European P. nebrodensis material after the comparative evaluation of morphological, mating compatibility and molecular results (Zervakis et al. 2014).
Allium calamarophilon is taxonomically related to Allium thessalicum and to Allium runemarkii, the latter also known from Evvia.

Sorbus maderensis is considered a subspecies of the widespread species, S. aucuparia (Sorbus aucuparia subsp. maderensis (Lowe) McAll. (e.g., Kurtto 2009, The Plant List 2016).

McAllister (McAllister 2005, H. McAllister pers. comm. 2016) treated S. maderensis as a subspecies to emphasise what he considered to be a close relationship to S. aucuparia; the only significant difference found was the uniformly smaller and evenly sized leaflets in S. maderensis, commenting that trees from Corsica have similar leaves but much more slender and longer annual growth increments. S. maderensis does seem to be a much smaller-growing shrub and probably ecologically rather different from most 'other' provenances of S. aucuparia, however possibly still within the same range of morphological difference found with provenances from central Siberia. In cultivation McAllister found S. maderensis to be much slower-growing than any other S. aucuparia, and it appears to be totally self-incompatible.

authority: J.L.Villar, Turland, Juan, Gaskin, M.A.Alonso & M.B.Crespo
taxonomicNotes: In Crete, this species was previously considered to be T. hampeana (Turland 2010).
Epithet to be spelled tyrrhena (according to IPNI). Leguminosae Genista tyrrhena Vals.
Two subspecies considered: Genista dorycnifolia Font Quer subsp. dorycnifolia and Genista dorycnifolia subp. grosii (Font Quer) Font Quer & Rothm.

The Plant List (2016) considers this species to be a subspecies of Adenocarpus aureus (as Adenocarpus aureus subsp. gibbsianus (Castrov. & Talavera) Rivas Mart. & Cantó). However, it is considered a valid species in Flora Iberica (Castroviejo 1999) and this authority will be followed for the purposes of this assessment.

The Plant List (2016) considered this species to be a subspecies of Echinospartum ibericum Rivas Mart., Sánchez Mata & Sancho. (as Echinospartum ibericum subsp. algibicum (Talavera & Aparicio) Rivas Mart.

However, it is considered as a species in Flora Iberica (Talavera et al. 1999) and this will be followed for the purposes of this assessment. Molecular studies on Echinospartiun (Aparicio et al. 2002) support E. algibicum as a species, in addition to having different chromosomic numbers and being geographically isolated (P. Garcia Murillo pers. comm. 2017).

The Plant List (2016) considered this species to be a subspecies of Echinospartum lusitanicum (L.) Rothm. (as Echinospartum lusitanicum subsp. barnadesii (Graells) Vicioso. However, it is considered as a valid species by Talavera et al. (1999) and Lopez Gonzalez (2001) and this will be followed for the purposes of this assessment.

This name is considered 'unresolved' by The Plant List (2017), which cites its basionym (Genista patens) as a synonym of Cytisus heterochrous Colmeiro. The species is accepted by Talavera and Gibbs ).
Pyrus sicanorum is a wild relative of pear, P. communis L. subsp. communis. It is a preliminary accepted species in Euro+Med PlantBase (Kurtto 2009).
Chamaelea pulvurelenta (Vent.) Tiegh. is the accepted name by Canarian botanists.

A recent revision of the genus Atlantica by Cameron et al. (2013) based on shell characters and genital anatomy, promoted the transfer of this genus from Discidae to Gastrodontidae (Gastropoda: Pulmunata). Furthermore, the former taxon Discus guerinianus subsp. calathoides (Lowe, 1863) becomes Atlantica calathoides (Lowe, 1863) according to this revision.
This is a distinct taxon related to the D. oxytropis group, with one further extant taxon and several fossil species. It is recognised on size, morphology and distribution.

authority: A. Reischütz, N. Steiner-Reischütz & P. Reischütz, 2016
taxonomicNotes: According to Lika et al. (2021) it is a junior synonym of Platyla similis (Reinhardt, 1880).

Two subspecies are currently recognised; subspecies decaisnei is native to Gran Canaria (although considered introduced to Lanzarote and Fuerteventura), whilst subspecies purpuriense is restricted to Lanzarote and Fuerteventura.

The taxonomic identity of the subspecies purpuriense requires confirmation. It differs from the nominal subspecies mainly in its broader, somewhat succulent, glabrous leaves (without the stiff, rough hairs of the nominal subspecies). The growth habit is also slightly different: the nominal subspecies often has a main stem and branches higher above the ground, while subsp. purpuriense branches from the very base, thus forming a more intricate bush which in open places finally adopts a semispherical shape and can reach 2 m in height and 2,5 m in diameter, especially in cultivated individuals. Wild plants are usually smaller.

These differences might appear small but are clear when comparing wild specimens of both subspecies. S. Scholz (pers. comm. 2017) treats subsp. purpuriense as a full species, which would then have to be called Echium famarae Lems & Holzapfel. It seems to be an old, relict species (Martín Osorio et al. 2011); in fact, molecular genetics have shown it to be basal in the genus (R. Jaen Molina pers. comm. 2017). The “true” E. decaisnei (from Gran Canaria) is a rather more recent species adapted to the drier parts of Gran Canaria.

Sylvia sarda and S. balearica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. sarda following Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). 
Previously placed in Sylvia but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly treated as a subspecies of C. sarda, but differs in its paler throat (1); paler belly and flanks (1); smaller size (effect size for wing based on published data (Shirihai et al. 2001) –3.5, score 2); somewhat different song (to which the other species does not respond; allow 2); clearly different contact calls (at least 2); and migratory pattern (1). Monotypic.

Previous records of S. olbia from Italy are now recognised as indistinct from S. lingua (L. Peruzzi pers. comm. 2017).

Corsican records of this species could result from one or several distinct recent hybridization events (S. olbia is itself is likely an old stabilized hybrid), and maybe could be treated as simple hybrids, taking in account their very reduced populations. Casual hybrids S. cordigera x S. lingua look like S. olbia but are not (J.-M. Tison pers. comm. 2017) and such plants are not infrequent in Corsica, even in the south (for instance at Porto-Vecchio; J.-M. Tison obs. pers. 2017). However we include Corsican records within this assessment on the advice of B. Schatz (pers. comm. 2017).

Crambe fruticosa L.f. is a wild relative of the oil producing and fodder crop, C. abyssinica R.E. Fr., as well as being related to other brassica crops as a member of the subtribe Brassicinae (tribe Brassiceae) (Maxted et al. in prep.).
The genus Sinapidendron is endemic to Madeira and is part of the brassica complex.
WCSP (2018) considers the senior name for this species to be Arrhenatherum pallens (Link) Link.

authority: Korn, Machado, Cristo & Cancela da Fonseca, 2010

taxonomicNotes:
Originally, it was described as a subspecies of C. sturanii. Based on material from Kijevo in the Zeljeznica Valley, Zallot et al. (2015) claimed that it is distinct from C. sturanii sensu stricto and assigned to the subgenus Wagneriola Zallot et al. 2015, together with C. scalarinum. (which was not accepted by the MolluscaBase (2022)).
The problem with this taxon is that Wagner (1906) provided several type localities, namely “Celebic, Zeljeznicatal, Bistricatal bei Sarajevo, Berg Stolac in Bosnien [with the note “slender, with thin, close by ribs”], Jablanica, Plasa bei Jablanica, Prenjgebirge in der Herzegowina, Cirowa pecina, Botun und Skrecko jezero am Durmitor in Montenegro, Mali Senjt bei Oroshi im Mirditagebirge, Nordalbanien [with the note “body whorl bigger; ribs on the central whorls more spaced]. Berg Maranaj bei Skutari in Albanien [with the note “spotless”]. Baba bei Gacko in der Herzegowina [with the note “dense and fine ribbing”]. Mrtwanje auf der Bjelasnica südwestlich von Sarajewo [with the note: ”more developed and strong lip of the aperture"]". Apparently, these localities host more than one species (not even belonging to the same subgenus), i.e. Wagner described scalariniforme on the basis of a mixture of several species.
It seems necessary to designate a lectotype in the frame of a revision as soon as possible, (practically among the syntypes from the 'Zeljeznicatal'), to ensure clarity on the taxonomic status of the species.This assessment is made using the concept of Zallot et al. (2015).

Morelet described seven species of the genus and subsequent authors have reduced this number in various ways. Mordan and Martins (2001) revised the group and considered Vitrina mollis, from Terceira Island, to be a junior synonym of Vitrina brumalis.

The genus Plutoria was created by Alonso et al. (2000). The group was revised in Mordan and Martins (2001), and then again by Giusti et al. (2011) who, based on a phylogenetic study, reported that the genus Plutonia was not supported, and created a new genus, Azorivitrina.

The genus Plutoria was created by Alonso et al. (2000). The group was revised in Mordan and Martins (2001), and then again by Giusti et al. (2011) who, based on a phylogenetic study, reported that the genus Plutonia was not supported, and created a new genus, Azorivitrina. Following Giusti et al. (2011) this species was moved from the genus Plutonia to the new genus, Azorivitrina.

This species has sometimes been suspected to be an alien species, although known from nowhere else, or to be an artificial hybrid (Couteaux and Pons 1987), although later rejected by Torrell et al. (1999) without clear justification.
This subspecies was formally Euphorbia stygiana, following the submission of recent information it has been realised that this assessment just covered the subspecies E.santamariae.

There are three different opinions on the identity (and distributions) of crassilabrum, obscura, and conica. Gofas (2001) considers there to be two species in the Pyrenees (crassilabrum and obscura), and the latter one also occurs in central France (i.e. conica is a synonym of obscura). Falkner et al. (2002) considers there to be one species in the Pyrenees (obscura, with crassilabrum as its synonym), and the second one in central France (conica).MolluscaBase (2022) considers two species in the Pyrenees (crassilabrum and obscura) and a third species in central France (conica). See also Inventaire National du Patrimoine Naturel.
This assessment follows the concept of conica in the strict sense by MolluscaBase (2022).

Following MolluscaBase (Bank and Neubert 2017), this species was moved from Cochlostoma to Obscurella.

The taxon was previously assessed (as Cochlostoma obscurum) as including O. crassilabrum, which is now considered as a separate taxon.

There are three different opinions on the identity (and distributions) of O. crassilabrum, obscura, and conica. Gofas (2001) considers there to be two species in the Pyrenees (crassilabrum and obscura), and one of these two (obscura) also occurs in central France (with conica as a synonym of obscura).

Falkner et al. (2002) considers there to be one species in the Pyrenees (obscura, with crassilabrum as its synonym), and the second one in central France (conica).

MolluscaBase (Bank pers. comm. 2017) considers two species in the Pyrenees (crassilabrum and obscura) and a third species in central France (conica). This opinion is based on the dendrograms provided by Gofas (2001), which show that there are, based on allozyme data, three clusters: “obscurum” from Arcy, Aisy and Massangis (all from central France = conica), “obscurum” from Pau and St. Martory (all from the Pyrenees = obscura), and “crassilabrum” (all from the Pyrenees = crassilabrum). An additional argument to treat the taxon from central France as a separate species is also the large distribution gap between the populations from Central France and the Pyrenees (about 500 km).
Rivera et al. (2013) revised the Authority for this species from Chabaud to H.Wildpret.

The species is currently considered valid by Bank (2013) as a subspecies of Clausilia whateliana (C.w. brembina Strobel, 1850), but raised to species level by Nägele and Hausdorf (2015). After genetic revision by Nägele and Hausdorf (2015) and Hausdorf and Nägele (2015), the list of the subspecific taxa now treated as valid is the following: C. brembina alanica Nordsieck, 2013; C. brembina brembina Strobel, 1850; C. brembina klemmi Nordsieck, 1966; C. brembina gardonensis Nardi & Nordsieck, 2013; C. brembina umbrosa Kaufel, 1928.

After genetic revision by Nägele and Hausdorf (2015) and Hausdorf and Nägele (2015), two subspecies are considered as valid: C. whateliana exoptata Schmidt, 1856 and C. whateliana whateliana Charpentier, 1850.
Formerly accepted as Cochlodina incisa (Küster, 1876), the species name was revised to Cochlodina bidens (Manganelli et al. 2014).
Possible junior synonym of Parapelecopsis nemoralioides (O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1884) (Wunderlich 1992)
Gensita parnassica is possibly not specifically distinct from G. salzmanii (Gibbs 1966).

The validity of this species must be evaluated with further taxonomic research. This taxon belongs to group of Cecilioides species described by Benoit in 1862 and in strong need of taxonomic revision.

Beckmann and Falkner (2003: 38) stated that "the identity of this species is still problematic" and separates from C. rizzeana only by virtue of its bigger shell dimensions.

Although Bank (2013) lists this species, its validity must be evaluated with further taxonomic researches. This taxon belongs to the group of Cecilioides species described by Benoit in 1862 and is in a strong need to be taxonomically revised.

Beckmann and Falkner (2003: 38) stated that "the identity of this species is still problematic" and separates it from C. petitiana only by virtue of its smaller shell dimensions.

Charpentieria riberothi was described by Brandt (1961) as a subspecies of Siciliaria leucophryna. This species is currently considered as a valid species by Nordsieck (2013) even if this author highlights the problematic systematic situation of this taxon that should be clarified by further taxonomical investigations. Nordsieck's opinion has been later followed by Beckmann (2004) and Bank (2013).

In addition, the actual distribution must be clarified as the type locality provided by Brandt (1961) seems likely to be erroneous as no other Charpentieria is found north of Ribera. This fact, if not clarified, could strongly invalidate the real validity of this species as no clear type locality would be available.

The systematic position of Deroceras sardum is still unclear. Wiktor (2000: 552) stated that Simroth (1886) probably dealt with juvenile specimens when he described the species. Nevertheless Bank (2013) lists the species in his checklist.

This species is not considered by Welter-Schultes (2012), but it is listed as a synonym of O. navarricus (Bourguignat, 1870).

Welter-Schultes (2012) states that Germain (1930) classified this as a synonym of O. lucidus var. navarricus (O. lucidus = currently O. draparnaudi, navarricus = currently O. navarricus (Bourguignat, 1870)). Falkner et al. (2002) argued that "O. colliourensis was a good species, but gave no constraints or arguments to substantiate this hypothesis. More research is necessary. The original information given by Locard (1894) did not provide constraints to classify this taxon as an independent species, so the classification proposed by Germain (who regarded navarricus as a widespread species in southern France and the Pyrenees) is preliminarily accepted, although O. navarricus in the current interpretation is not regarded as a synonym of colliourensis. A new classification should be based on published results of new scientific studies".

In Bank (2017) it is treated as a valid species.
Acanthinula azorica was cited for the Azores as the European A. aculeata (Müller 1774) (Backhuys 1975); Bank et al. (2002) consider it separate from the continental taxon.

This name is based on Hygrophorus lepidopus Rea 1927 with a description based on English material (Herefordshire). After a long gap in British records it was refound in 2004 and recombined at varietal level as Hygrocybe fornicata var. lepidopus (Rea) Boertm. & N. Barden 2007. However DNA analysis (Dentinger et al. unpubl.) supports its recognition at specific rank.
Groenenberg et al. (2016) have placed Superba as a subgenus under Liburnica, and also in MolluscaBase (2022) this species is registered as Liburnica (Superba) grisea (Subai & Fehér, 2006).
Groenenberg et al. (2016) have placed Superba as a subgenus under Liburnica, and also in MolluscaBase (2022) this species is registered as Liburnica (Superba) kulmakana (Subai & Fehér, 2006).

Groenenberg et al. (2016) have placed Superba as a subgenus under Liburnica, and also in MolluscaBase (2022) this species is registered as Liburnica (Superba) skipetarica (Subai & Fehér, 2006). The species is comprised of two distinct subspecies: L. skipetarica skipetarica (Subai, 1995) and L. skipetarica asketa (Subai & Fehér, 2006).

Groenenberg et al. (2016) found that Superba is paraphyletic. As a result, two species of the former Superba complex move to Josephinella: J. vikosensis and J. reischuetzi (E. Neubert pers. comm. 2018).

The genus Herbertus in the Azores is problematic. Historically (e.g., Grolle and Long 2000) it was assumed that there was a single species in the Azores, namely H. azoricus. However, it is now clear that two species are present (Hodgetts and Rumsey in prep.), but further analysis is needed to characterize them. Previous work (Feldberg et al. 2004) suggested that H. azoricus should be placed in the synonymy of H. sendtneri. However, further studies show that spurious lumping of taxa in Herbertus gives a much too simplified view of this complex genus (D. Bell pers. comm. 2018, N. Hodgetts pers. comm. 2018, F. Rumsey pers. comm. 2018), and H. sendtneri is therefore best regarded as an exclusively Eurasian species. Current indications are that H. azoricus is best treated as a synonym or a subspecies of H. juniperoideus, that H. sendtneri does not occur in Macaronesia, and that the second species is closely related to H. dicranus and H. borealis. Until the second species is properly published, all Azorean Herbertus will have to be referred to H. azoricus.

Brassica cretica Lam. subsp. cretica is a gene pool secondary wild relative of broccoli (B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck), Brussels sprout [B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker], cabbage (B. oleracea var. capitata L.), cauliflower (B. oleracea var. botrytis L.), and kale (B. oleracea var. viridis L.) (Vincent et al. 2013). It is also a wild relative of swede [B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb.], oilseed rape (B. napus L. var. napus) and turnip (B. rapa L.).

Brassica cretica Lam. subsp. laconica M. A. Gust. & Snogerup is a gene pool secondary wild relative of broccoli (B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck), Brussels sprout [B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker], cabbage (B. oleracea var. capitata L.), cauliflower (B. oleracea var. botrytis L.), and kale (B. oleracea var. viridis L.) (Vincent et al. 2013). It is also a wild relative of swede [B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb.], oilseed rape (B. napus L. var. napus) and turnip (B. rapa L.).

Recent field work on Azores and Madeira islands revealed that this species might be more frequent. This way a taxonomic revision of all Frullania tamarisci material from Macaronesia (including the Canary Islands) should be developed in the future.
This species was recently described (Lara et al. 2018). It is mainly an epiphytic moss, so far exclusively found in southernmost Spain.

Oceanodroma castro (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) has been split into O. castro and O. monteiroi following Bolton et al. (2008). All Oceanodroma species have since been moved to Hydrobates (del Hoyo and Collar 2014).

Vicia sativa L. subsp. devia is in the subgenus Vicia and the section Vicia (Maxted 1991) and it is a primary genetic relative of common vetch, V. sativa L. subsp. sativa (Vincent et al. 2013). The distinction of this subspecies from V. sativa subsp. nigra is based on the presence of an extended peduncle with flowers attached at the base and apex. It seems likely this is the result of a single gene mutation in the V. sativa subsp. nigra population in Madeira where it is endemic (N. Maxted pers. comm. 2019). Borges et al. (2008) are also doubtful about the taxonomic validation of this species and place it in a list of problematic taxa. The distinction of this variant does seem questionable but has been maintained because of the distinction of the trait.

Glöer and Zettler (2005) noted that in Germany nearly 70 different "species" were originally described, which were reduced by Bolling (1965) to three species, so for some periods there was little recording. In this problematic genus, they continued to list those species and subspecies on CLECOM (Check List of European Continental Mollusca), but noting that as long as we adhere solely to the shells there will be no progress. A revision of this genus is urgently needed and in Stuttgart, research with DNA analysis is ongoing for this problem.

A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology pending the results for full analysis for the group using Falkner and Niederhöfer (2008), however unless there is indicated active specific species survey data, some species listed as or Extinct or Possibly Extinct have been placed into threatened categories.

Glöer and Zettler (2005) noted that in Germany nearly 70 different "species" were originally described, which were reduced by Bolling (1965) to three species, so for some periods there was little recording. In this problematic genus, CLECOM (Check List of European Continental Mollusca) continued to list all the 70 species and subspecies, but they noted that, as long as we adhere solely to identification based on the shells, there will be no progress on resolving the taxonomic issues. A revision of this genus is urgently needed and in Stuttgart, research with DNA analysis is ongoing for this problem. A conservation assessment is made from Falkner and Niederhof (2008) based on data from shell morphology pending the results of molecular analysis for the group. Unless there was recent species survey data (using appropriate techniques), any species listed as  'Extinct' or 'Extinct?' in Falkner and Niederhof (2008) have been placed into threatened categories, pending new survey data.

This species  lies within one of the groups of spring-snails that is currently being researched using molecular systematics to determine their taxonomic status. The species limits in some countries have been doubted by some researchers, however as yet there is no data on Romania. A conservation assessment is made based on data from shell morphology pending the results of the full analysis of the group.

Geiger et al. (2014) placed Pomatoschistus montenegrensis in the genus Ninnigobius.

Pomatoschistus sp. Skadar is a name used in earlier assessments (from Kottelat and Freyhof 2007).
Geiger et al. (2014) placed Knipowitschia punctatissima in the genus Orsinigobius.

Formerly Paladilhiopsis gebhardti (J. Wágner, 1931) was considered as its synonym (see Pintér 1968). Based on combined molecular and morphological evidences, Angyal et al. (2018) have proved that they are two distinct taxa, but left the question open whether gebhardti has a species or just a subspecies status (Angyal et al. 2018). MolluscaBase (2022) lists them as separate species under different generic names: [Bythiospeum gebhardti and Iglica hungarica. Falniowski et al. (2019) made it clear that both taxa belong to Paladilhiopsis. This assessment was done for Paladilhiopsis hungarica in the strict sense.

A 2016 study found that Superba is paraphyletic (Groenenberg et al. 2016). As a result, two species of the former Superba complex move to Josephinella: J. vikosensis and J. reischuetzi (E. Neubert pers. comm. 2018).
We follow Borzatti Von Loewenstern et al. (2013) here in considering B. dubia to be restricted to Sicily, with former subspecies now considered at the species level.

Brassica drepanensis (Caruel) Damanti is recognized at the species level by the GRIN Taxonomy (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019). This choice is supported by a relatively recent molecular study (Tatout et al. 1999).  However, this taxon is included as a subspecies of B. villosa Biv., as B. villosa Biv. subsp. drepanensis (Caruel) Raimondo & Mazzola, in the Italian checklist of vascular plants (Bartolucci et al. 2018) as well as in the Euro+Med Plantbase (Marhold 2011) and in the World Flora Online (WFO 2019).It is a secondary gene pool wild relative of broccoli, B. oleracea L. var. italica Plenck, Brussels sprout, B. oleracea L. var. gemmifera (DC.) Zenker, cabbage, B. oleracea var. capitata L., cauliflower, B. oleracea var. botrytis L., and kale, B. oleracea var. viridis L. (Vincent et al. 2013). It is also a wild relative of swede, B. napus L. var. napobrassica (L.) Rchb., oilseed rape, B. napus L. var. napus and turnip, B. rapa L.

Formerly, Boyeria cretensis was confused with—and regarded as a subpopulation of—Boyeria irene (Fonscolombe, 1838), but both species are clearly distinct (Boudot 1989, Peters 1991, Kohli et al. 2014).

Three subspecies have been described: Cordulegaster helladica helladica, C. h. buchholzi and C. h. kastalia, but the separation between them remains very difficult and even intermediate forms between those subspecies have been described.

Many records of this taxon have been published under the closely related Cordulegaster boltonii, but both taxa are structurally well distinct, although colour pattern is almost similar. Ongoing genetic investigations confirms the full species rank for this taxon.
Originally described as a separate species, this taxon was later considered a subspecies of H. striata but was resurrected as a species by Duda et al. (2018).

According to the original pictures and description, this species appears to be somewhat similar to H. melchori with regard to the sculpture of the shell (Vega-Luz and Vega-Luz 2008). However, this species is described from a locality far away, although also on the island of Tenerife. Genetically, H. modesta belongs to a clade including also species of the H. plicaria group (H. plicaria, H. bethencourtiana) and the H. consobrina group (H. consobrina consobrina, H. consobrina nivariae, H. consobrina retrodens, H. melchori, H. fulgida, H. invernicata) but appears to be more closely related to H. plicaria and H. bethencourtiana than to the other taxa (M. Neiber unpublished data).

According to Bank et al (2002), the name modesta appeared twice as a nomen nudum in A. Férussac in 1821; in both publications, Férussac referred to plate 42 fig. 1. This plate was actually published by Férussac in 1822, but without explanations on the plate or on the covers. However, the identity of fig. 2 can be inferred from the two 1821 publications. Bank et al. (2002) considered 1822 as the publication date of modesta, as the name became for the first time nomenclaturally available in the year the plate was published, and we follow that opinion here.

Sequencing for AFTOL project shows it is not closely related to the type of the genus (Larsson & Larsson 2003). It is expected that it will be transferred to another genus but this has no bearing on its conservation status.

authority: Battiston, Correas, Lombardo, Mouna, Payne & Schütte, 2018

taxonomicNotes: This newly-recognized European monotypic genus has been discovered and described recently (Vujić et al. 2019). The systematic position of the taxon is within the tribe Rhingiini. Katara connexa is shiny, black species with broad, oval abdomen, which is distinctly broader than thorax in both sexes. Eyes are separated in both sexes (Vujić et al. 2019).

Claussen et al. (1994) provided the key in which Heringia adpropinquans is distinguished from H. heringi (Zetterstedt, 1843) and figured the male terminalia. In the male of H. adpropinquans the surstylus is noticeably broader in the apical half of its length, whereas in H. heringi it is almost parallel-sided, from base almost to apex (Speight 2018).

Based on the presence of a precoxal bridge, Cheilosia varnensis belongs to the Cheilosia angustigenis-species group. Claussen (2000) provides features separating C. varnensis from other species in this group and figures the male terminalia.

Cheilosia lucense belongs to the subgenus Montanocheila. It is most similar to C. chrysocoma. Males can be distinguished by using features of terminalia. Females can be separated by angular facial tubercle and pollinose sternum 2. Ricarte et al. (2014) describe both the male and female, figure the male terminalia and show how C. lucense can be incorporated into the key to the European alpina group of species (Claussen 1998).
Cheilosia limbicornis belongs to nominal subgenus. The male is described by Torp Pedersen (1971). Diagnostic features are mentioned by Pérez-Bañón et al. (1996).

Claussen and Kassebeer (1993) provide the key for distinguishing Cheilosia latigenis from the closely similar species C. mutabilis, C. psilophthalma and C. urbana. C. latigenis belongs to the nominate subgenus.
Cheilosia katara belongs to nominal subgenus Cheilosia. An identification key distinguishing C. katara from other related species was provided by Vujić and Claussen (2000).

The species belongs to the nominal subgenus Cheilosia s. str. Torp Pedersen (1971) described the male of this species, and Marcos-Garcia (1987) described the female. This species is apparently similar to C. rhynchops (C. Claussen pers. comm. 2020).
This species was described from North America, however, Speight et al. (2013) confirmed the species to be European in origin.
The species belongs to the Eumerus obliquus group.

The species belongs to Eumerus olivaceus group. E. alpinus Rondani, 1857 is resurrected from synonymy of E. olivaceus Loew, 1848 and considered as bona species in Grković et al. (2015), until than the name of E. olivaceus was used for both species.
<span class="datalabel1">

authority: J. van Steenis and W. van Steenis, 2014

taxonomicNotes: This species has been reported from outside Corsica (the French mainland, Sardinia and from Italy) by other authors (Burgio et al. 2015, Speight et al. 2018), but Eupeodes vandergooti is difficult to distinguish from related species, such as E. lucasi, and has not reliably been confirmed from outside Corsica. The species is considered here to be endemic to Corsica pending further work.
This species is similar to Eupeodes luniger. To date it is known only from the male holotype, an extremely dark specimen. Its validity is uncertain and its identity requires confirmation.

Smit et al. (2004) supports the validity of X. babyssa and placed X. parahyalinatus as a synonym of X. babyssa, following Wakeham-Dawson et al. (2004).

However, there are some doubts about the validity of X. babyssa (Speight 2020), which appears in recent literature as Xanthandrus parahyalinatus. The fact that X. babyssa is found only on Madeira island - from which other endemic hoverflies are known - provides sufficient justification to consider it valid until new studies integrating morphology and molecular biology are undertaken.

Seddon (2008) noted that it was possibly only a giant form of Pseudocampylaea portosanctana, but both have been found alive on Ilheu de Cima and, according to Wollaston (1878), there are a few other conchological differences besides size.

The species was originally assessed as 'Pseudocampylaea loweii' A. Férussac, 1835, however the correct specific epithet is 'lowii' (E. Neubert pers. comm. 2019).
The proper identification of this species, which is very similar to Eristalis nemorum (and Eristalis interrupta), is only possible using the specific key (Vujić et al. 2004).

The subspecies sicula was described by Cristaudo et al. (2007). The taxonomic identity of the subspecies has been questioned by Leonardis et al. (2009), who suggest that the subspecies bears similarity to Vulpia sicula var. sicula.

Epipactis cretica Kalop. & Robatsch is considered a synonym of E. troodi H.Lindb. by Govaerts (2003) and others, however Epipactis cretica is considered here a valid species based on the opinion of S. Tsiftsis (I. Bazos and P. Delipetrou pers. comm. 2013). It is also considered as a distinct species and as a single island endemic by Dimopoulos et al. (2013).

The former subspecies, Centaurea janeri subsp. gallaecica M.Laínz is placed as a valid species following Arnelas and Devesa (2012), although still maintained as a subspecies by some references (e.g., WCVP 2022).
This species belongs to the subgenus Kimakowiczia.

Groh and Hemmen (1986) examined Geomitra coronata, and reclassified it with two other taxa (both extinct) into a new subgenus Serratorotula. Bank et al. (2002) elevated the subgenus to generic status.

This species was previously assessed under the name Serratorotula coronata, however the correctly the valid name is Serratorotula juliformis, due to pre-occupation of the first (K. Groh pers. comm. 2019).
Until recently, this species was affiliated to the family Sphincterochilidae (genus Sphincterochila) (Alonso et al. 1996).

Nordsieck (2007) suggests that Albinaria privigna may be a junior synonym of this species, and in this assessment, we adopt this approach. Albinaria privigna was previously retained as a valid species by Bank (2017), but is now placed as a subspecies of A. olivieri (MolluscaBase 2020).

Sainfoin (Onobrychis spp.) has been cultivated as a fodder crop in the Near East since ancient times (Aygün et al. 2018). Given this, Onobrychis peloponnesiaca may be viewed as a wild relative of Sainfoin under Taxon group 4, according to the taxon group definition by Maxted et al. (2006). The species was originally described as a subspecies of O. aliacmonia Rech.f. (Tan and Iatrou 1996) but has since been elevated to species status (Greuter & Raus (ed.) 1999).
The generic assignment of this species varies between authors; it might be Alinda, Pseudalinda, Alinda (Pseudalinda).
The generic assignment of this species varies between authors; it might be Alinda, Pseudalinda, Alinda (Pseudalinda).

According to Soldati F. (pers. comm. 2016), Allecula suberina might be conspecific with Allecula semilivida Pic, 1891 (now considered junior synonym to Allecula morio (Fabricius, 1787). Research is ongoing to revise the status of Allecula semilivida - type material to be studied and status changes to be published when confirmed.
Alopia bogatensis has two subspecies: A. bogatensis bogatensis (E.A. Bielz, 1856) and Alopia bogatensis angustata (E.A. Bielz 1859).

Although MolluscaBase (2022) treats this as a valid species, Fehér and Erőss (2009) as well as Welter-Schultes (2012) claim this species to be a synonym of Josephinella byshekensis. Its taxonomic position and relationship to J. byshekensis need to be clarified.

The latest revision with generic/subgeneric division of Cochlostomatidae was done by Zallot et al. (2015), according to this it belongs to the subgenus Clessiniella Zallot, Groenenberg, De Mattia, Fehér & Gittenberger, 2015. MolluscBase (2022), however, does not accept this and argues that the name Neglecta A. J. Wagner, 1897 has priority over Clessiniella. Zallot et al. (2015) argue that Wagner's Formenkreis Neglecta should not be interpreted as a generic name but as a superspecies, and therefore Clessiniella is valid.
This species is poorly known and there are few specimens, and there is a possibility that the Romanian and Bulgarian subpopulations represent different species.

Formerly, this species was included within the concept of Astragalus nitidiflorus (Pau 1910). However, following detailed morphological study by Talavera (1999), Astragalus gines-lopezii was identified as a unique species.

Following a recent taxonomic revision, the chorology for Astragalus sirinicus Ten. was confined to mainland Italy (Brullo et al. 2012). Historically, the distribution of the species has included the Balkan region, Sardinia and Corsica (Bacchetta and Brullo 2006); however, records from the Balkans refer to A. tymphresteus Boiss. & Spruner, and A. sirinicus subsp. genargenteus, endemic to Sardinia and Corsica, is now recognised as a synonym of A. genargenteus Moris (Bacchetta and Brullo 2006, Brullo et al. 2012).
The taxonomic status of the species was clarified by Fehér et al. (2009a) and Fehér et al. (2009b).
MolluscaBase (2022) accepts this taxon as a valid species.
This is a replacement name for Helix canariensis Mousson, 1872 (see Seddon and Aparicio 1998).
According to Hausdorf (2002), this species belongs to the genus Semilimax. According to Dhora and Welter-Schultes (1996) its systematic position is unclear.

According to www.animalbase.org "this species was classified by R. Bank in the Fauna Europaea checklist (www.faunaeur.org 7-2008) in the genus Orcula (possibly without any published reference behind), Grossu had originally described it in the genus Sphyradium. We follow Bank and classify it preliminarily in Orcula. More research is necessary.
Páll-Gergely et al. (2013) placed this species into the subgenus Illyriobanatica Páll-Gergely & Deli, 2013, which is not accepted by MolluscaBase.
The taxonomy of Succineidae is not resolved. Much more research is necessary to understand the morphological and geographic boundaries of the nominal species.

The status of this species and its relationship with Canariola nubigena needs to be studied. Both species are flightless, but overlapping ranges have been documented. Canariola willemsei has even been documented from two islands (La Gomera and Tenerife).
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands was treated by Valido et al. (1999).
The family Vitrinidae in the Canary Islands was revised by Valido et al. (1999).
The species is very close to P. globulicollis and its status (valid species or subspecies of P. globulicollis) is unclear, pending molecular data (Rapuzzi and Sama 2013).
The validity of Ruthenica gallinae is questionable. Lengyel and Páll-Gergely (2010) reported large variability of specimens in terms of shell size ranging from typical R. filograna to R. gallinae.

In contrast to Zilch (1952), who divided the Sardinian Tacheocampylaea's in the polytypic species carotii with the subspecies carotii s. str. and T. carotii melonii and T. gennarii as distinct species, the Italian checklist (Manganelli et al. 1995) and Fauna Europaea treat all Sardinian populations as one species under the name T. carotii.

There are four subspecies currently accepted: Tacheocampylaea cyrniaca cyrniaca, T. cyrniaca omphalophora, T. cyrniaca faucicola and T. cyrniaca arusalensis. Tacheocampylaea revelierii (Debeaux, 1867) [Helix] is a synonym to this species. In 2009, a fourth subspecies, T. c. arusalensis (Hagenmüller, 1888) – up to now forgotten – was found back near its type locality by G. Falkner, C. Régnier and B. Recorbet.
This species is considered a subspecies of Cordulegaster helladica, but given the closeness of the two taxa, genetic investigations are in work to provide new taxonomic information.
In addition to the nominotypical one, two subspecies have been described, namely C. h. buchholzi (Lohmann, 1993) and C. h. kastalia (Lohmann, 1993).
This species is considered a subspecies of Cordulegaster helladica but genetic investigations are in work to get new informations about the systematic position of the various members of C. helladica.

Cheilosia candida Vujić et Radenković, 2020 is a member of the subgenus Convocheila Barkalov, and endemic to Europe. The species was described based on a single male specimen. Radenković et al. (2020) provide images of the male, including the male genitalia, and an identification key to separate the species from all other members of subgenus Convocheila. The species is morphologically similar to C. paralobi Malski, and distinguishing characters are provided in Radenković et al. (2020).

Prospero depressum was described by Speta (2000), based on specimens made from plants cultivated in Linz (Austria) and originally collected in Crete. Valdés (2004) transferred the species to Scilla L.

Turland and Chilton (2008) state that the species is treated under P. autumnale sensu lato until further study of Prospero throughout its distribution results in a more satisfactory taxonomic arrangement.

Scilla autumnalis (Prospero autumnalis) sensu lato is an imperfectly understood polyploid complex. Speta (2000) described a number of taxa, all local or regional endemics and based on very fragmentary evidence; they cannot be keyed out on morphological characters (I. Bazos and P. Delipetrou pers. comm.). Prospero depressum is sometimes considered a synonym of the very widespread S. autumnale L. (e.g., Böhling et al. 2002, Strid 2016).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Hyla perrini (Dufresnes et al. 2018).

This species is regarded as being endemic to the island of Karpathos (Greece); populations on Rhodes, in spite of molecular indications that they could be assigned to this species (Akin et al. 2010) are still allocated to Pelophylax bedriagae (Lymberakis et al. 2007). Speybroeck et al. (2020) do not consider Karpathos frog as a separate species.The taxonomy of Pelophylax is complex and further studies are ongoing.
The species status of Pelophylax cretensis is "confirmed" by short mtDNA sequences and a large number of private allozyme alleles not found in any other water frog (P. Beerli pers. comm.).
This taxon was removed from the synonymy of Lissotriton boscai by Sequiera et al. (2020) and Speybroeck et al. (2020).

authority: Díaz-Rodríguez, Gehara, Márquez, Vences, Gonçalves, Sequeira, Martínez-Solano & Tejedo, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Pelodytes punctatus (Díaz-Rodríguez et al. 2017).
This is a split from Rana temporaria, where it was previously considered a subspecies (Dufresnes et al. 2020).
This taxon was originally assessed as a subspecies of Bellevalia dubia (as Bellevalia dubia subsp. hackelii).

This lichen species is easy to recognize in the field by lichenologists. The species' taxonomy is well defined and it is the only species of this genus in the Madeira archipelago. The species grows over rocks and adnate to loosely attached to the substrate. The thallus is orbicular up to 30 cm in diameter, dying at the center of the thallus; the colour is pale grey. The thallus has numerous apothecia. Lobes are 1-2 mm wide, dichotomously branched, more or less overlapping, lobe tips showing calcium oxalate deposits. The medulla has a chondroid axis. The lower side is with a black, foam-like layer of short, interwoven rhizines characteristic of this genus. Secondary metabolites include atranorin and several unknown terpenoids.
Fringilla teydea and F. polatzeki (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as F. teydea following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Fringilla teydea and F. polatzeki (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as F. teydea following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

There is marked genetic differentiation between populations on central and eastern islands in the archipelago, indicating that they have evolved in relative isolation for a long time (Salgueiro et al. 2004).

This species is sometimes placed as a subspecies of Centaurea janeri (as Centaurea janeri subsp. gallaecica), by WCVP (2022) for example, but we place it at the species level following Arnelas and Devesa (2012).
This group was revised in Mordan and Frias Martins (2001).
The group was revised in Mordan and Frias Martins (2001).

Morelet’s (1860:179) Bulimus pruninus variety ξ alabastrinus was raised to specific status by Martins (1989) and restricted to Terceira Island. Recorded from Pico Island by Nobre (1924) as Bulimus pruninus; unpublished molecular research has shown the specimens from Pico Island to be conspecific with those from Terceira.

Morelet and Drouët’s (1857) original description does not mention type locality, so “The Azores” is currently accepted. However, Morelet (1860:190) states that this species is found on Santa Maria only, and the provenance of the type material confirms it, thus enabling the restriction of the type locality to this island.

The type locality, stated originally as "probably belonging to South America", was restricted to São Miguel island, Azores (Martins 1989). Lectotype (inadvertently selected by R. I. Johnson 1964, Bull. United States nat. Mus., 239: 38 as the "figured holotype") USNM 5485 (Bank et al. 2002).

The species is very variable, the shell and the anatomy resembling sometimes either N. alabastrinus or N. tremulans. It appears also to be some introgression with N. vulgaris, already pointed out by Morelet (1860). The taxon is currently under revision, but here N. pruninus is taken in its currently accepted form.

The taxonomic status of the species was confirmed by Spitzenberger et al. (2006). There are no significant genetic differences between populations on the different islands (Juste et al. 2004).

Here we refer to P. teneriffae as the population on the Canaries. Northwest African populations previously assigned to teneriffae are currently included in kolombatovici, and Balkan populations are assigned to austriacus.

This variety is distinguished from Anacamptis pyramidalis (which it is sometimes synonymised with) by morphological and phenological characters. It is found in the same habitat as A. pyramidialis s. str. but flowers about six to eight weeks earlier, very rarely with a marginal overlap at the end of April. A. var. urvilleana is a distinctly a smaller plant with paler pinkish flowers, and smaller tepals apart other minor differences in their shape (Sommier and Caruana-Gatto 1915, Pignatti 1982, Delforge 2005, Mifsud 2016).

For a long time, the westernmost representatives of the genus Spalax were identified as a single species, Spalax graecus. According to the recent studies (Németh et al. 2013, Csorba et al. 2015) the three known subpopulations, separated by the Carpathian Mountains, represent separate species which can be assigned to described taxa. One of them is Spalax antiquus Méhely’s Blind Mole-rat. The separation of Méhely’s Blind Mole-rat as a distinct species is highly supported by the combined evidences of morphology, multilocus phylogeny, biogeographical evidences and species congruence with past tectonic and climatic events (Németh et al. 2013).

Spalax istricus was previously listed as a subspecies of S. graecus but has since been recognized as a separate species due to recent molecular genetic and detailed morphological studies (Németh et al. 2013).

The three known subpopulations, separated by the Carpathian Mountains, can be regarded as separate species, and assigned to already described taxa, this includes the Oltenia Blind Mole-rat.

This species represents an isolated population originally assigned to the Mosor Rock Lizard, Lacerta (now Dinarolacerta) mosorensis (Ljubisavljević et al. 2007). The specific identity of a recently-discovered Albanian population of  “D. mosorensis” not included in genetic analysis is unclear, but may represent this species (Ljubisavljević et al. 2007).

According to Snogerup (1995) this species is of interest for further studies of the infrageneric taxonomy and differentiation of the genus Bupleurum. It was placed with some hesitation in subsect. Aristata as, it was difficult based on its morphology to assign it in one of the otherwise well-separated subsections of Aristata and Juncea (Snogerup and Snogerup 2001). Moreover, it has several characters of its own, and it is therefore difficult to point out any very closely related species (Snogerup 1985). It is probably a very old isolate on the island of Gavdos (Snogerup and Snogerup 2003). Acccording to Strid (2016) Bupleurum gaudianum is possibly related to B. glumaceum and B. libanoticum.

The species was first discovered by Heldreich in 1846. Very little is known about the taxonomic relations of Chaerophyllum creticum and further research is required using molecular methods (Turland 2009). The nearest relative may be Chaerophyllum coloratum L. occuring in the West Balkan Peninsula (Strid 2016).

Bellevalia brevipeticellata is related to B. sitiaca Kypriotakis & Tzanoud, another endemic to Crete. B. sitiaca formerly considered a tetraploid form of B. brevipeticellata (Bareka 2009). Moreover, according to Strid (2016) it is also related to B. sessiliflora (Viv.) Kunth from Egypt and Libya.

In the framework of EURO+Med Plantbase, the genus Cyanus Mill. was separated from the genus Centaurea L. by Greuter (2006+). However, in all other taxonomic and flora literature related to Greece, eg. Greek Checklist (Dimopoulos et al. 2013, 2016), the Atlas of the Aegean Flora (Strid 2016), the Flora of Greece Web, Cyanus is considered as a subgeneric entity within Centaurea L. (Centaurea sect. Cyanus (Mill.) W.D.J. Koch; Centaurea subg. Cyanus (Mill.) Hayek (Raus and Strid 2020).

Two native species of the section Cyanus are found in Crete: Centaurea baldaccii Degen and Centaurea depressa M. Bieb. The presence of the latter was recently confirmed (2009) in Crete from Mountain Dikti (Herbarium MAICh - MAIC:11822). The other species of the section, Centaurea cyanus L., was probably only recently introduced in Crete (Strid 2016).

According to Galbany-Casals et al. (2006) Helichrysum heldreichii belongs to Sect. Stoechadinas and “resembles H. rupestre and H. angustifolium in its robustness and leaf length, although it seems more closely related to the latter”. According to Turland (2009)  further study is required to clear the taxonomic relationships of the taxon.

This is a particularly distinctive taxon, it was first collected by Tournefort and was described in 1785 by Lamarck and its taxonomic status has not been debated since then (Strid 2016). The species is considered as a taxonomically isolated taxon (Strid 1995).

According to Strid (2016) historical records from the mountains of southwest Turkey are probably incorrect, and they are excluded from this assessment.
According to Strid (2016), Myosotis solange is probably related to M. alpestris subsp. suaveolens, although study of fruiting material is needed to ascertain its status and affinities.

Thlaspi L. was revised by Al-Shehbaz (2014), who transferred the majority of Thlaspi species to Noccaea Moench. However, according to Özüdoğru (2019) Noccaea is taxonomically one of the most problematic genera of the Brassicaceae, and further work is required.

According to Turland (2009), the closest relative of the species is A. nebrodense subsp. tenuicaule Hartvig, a local endemic of central Greece (Mt. Vardousia). The species genus has been recently revised to Odontarrhena by Španiel et al. (2015).

Hypericum aciferum is a rare local endemic, discovered in 1962 (Greuter, 1965). A member of Hypericum sect. Adenotrias (Jaub. & Spach) R.Keller, related to H. aegypticum and to the Anatolian H. russeggeri (Fenzl) R.Keller; the members of this section among others are characterized by heterostylous flowers (Robson 1996, 2012).
Nepeta sphaciotica is a paleoendemic species of the Cretan flora (Baden 1987). It belongs to Nepeta argolica Born & Chamb. group (Ν. Sibthorpii Bentham).
